The Weser breakthrough in March 1981 occurred in the northwestern German city of Bremen and was a relatively spatially confined flood event. However, due to its intensity and the extensive urban transformations it triggered, it holds ongoing significance in the city's history. The flood is considered the culmination and northern endpoint of a geographically broad flood situation that dominated the course of the Upper and Middle Weser as well as some of its source and tributary rivers at that time. Flood peaks caused by rain and snowmelt of the Weser and its tributary Aller converged near Verden. In Bremen, the floodwater encountered a critical river bend at the Weser dam, which had a significantly reduced outflow cross-section, and instead sought a new bed. As a result, two summer dike breaches occurred immediately above and below the dam. Over 120 allotment gardens were destroyed, causing massive landscape damage. Although the plots were located in the designated overflow area and the flood remained within its limits, hardly anyone had expected that a flood of such magnitude would occur "from above" – that is, as an inland flood. All dike construction measures up to that point had been aimed at protecting the gardeners from storm surges from the sea. In the wake of the Weser breakthrough, the responsible authorities designed a new flood management concept for the affected areas, which was gradually implemented in the following years. Relocations, expansions, and new constructions of dikes, roads, and waterways permanently changed the cityscape.

Essentially, the Weser breakthrough in 1981 affected the southern Bremen district of Habenhausen, which is part of the Obervieland district. However, there were also landscape damages in other districts. Habenhausen – a neighborhood that was then still almost exclusively characterized by residential development – is bordered by the Weser to the east and north. The river makes a tight bend to the west around the district, where the Weser weir is located. The old structure, which still existed in 1981, was built between 1906 and 1911 to create an artificial boundary for the tides and simultaneously to ensure a minimum water level for inland shipping through a weir. It separates the Middle Weser from the Lower Weser. Within this sharp river bend, a wide area with grassland and small garden areas opens up, which today occupies about one-fifth of the area of Habenhausen. The heaviest destruction due to the flood was recorded in this area. The area is shielded from the Weser only by low summer dikes; only immediately before the regular residential development further south does a winter dike protect the houses. With the Werder Bridge (officially known today as Karl-Carstens Bridge, colloquially referred to as Strawberry Bridge), Habenhausen has had a long connection to the north to the district of Hastedt, which belongs to the Hemelingen district, since 1971. At the southern foot of the bridge, there was a notable bend in the winter dike in 1981, which the floodwater pressed against with full current intensity. This spot was later straightened. The second significant body of water in Habenhausen is the then 2.7-kilometer-long Werdersee. It was created between 1953 and 1960 in an east-west direction according to plans by Wilhelm Hübotter, south of the city weir, as a flood channel and ended in 1981 about 180 meters west of the bridge. It was intended that the lake should protect Habenhausen from storm surges if dikes broke along the Weser, which flows almost parallel further north. Additionally, it was meant to absorb floodwater that – like the Weser breakthrough – originated east in the designated overflow area of the Weser bend. The lake extended to the west up to the dike chart path, which ran on a small dam in a southwest-northeast direction. On the other side of the dam, the Kleine Weser continued, a small tributary of the Weser. There was only a connection between the Werdersee and the Kleine Weser through a few small openings.

On November 13, 1980, a routine flushing of the weir chamber was carried out in the left sector of the Bremen Weserwehr, which had been put into operation in 1911. A defect occurred when the sector, due to advanced corrosion of the locking structure, broke through the upper end position and destroyed the seals. It could be reset immediately after the damage incident, preventing the outflow of the dam. By December 24 of the same year, the damaged seals were partially renewed; however, an emergency locking mechanism still made control of the sector impossible. As a result, a serious problem arose: the more water flowed downstream, the more the functioning right weir field was burdened, while at the same time the outflow was increasingly slowed down. According to calculations, only 1,500 m³ of water could flow out regularly. In the early days of March the following year, maritime polar air flowed into Germany, bringing light rain or snowfall. At that time, the snow cover in the Harz was slightly above the long-term average. Between March 6 and 11, several low-pressure systems moved northeast across Germany, initially bringing tropical warm air and, from March 10, again maritime polar air. This resulted in partly prolonged rainfall, which was particularly abundant from March 9 to 11 (for example, in the area of Hameln or with 96 mm on the Kahlen Asten and 131 mm in the Sankt Andreasberg district of Oderbrück) and, together with rapid snowmelt in the low mountain ranges – for example, in the Weserbergland and in the Rhön – quickly caused the Weser and Aller tributaries from the low mountain ranges to swell. Favorable temperatures also caused the snow in the Harz to melt almost completely. The volumes of water flowing from the mountains exceeded the flood storage capacities of the Eder and Diemel dams; three reservoirs in the West Harz also overflowed. Although the peak wave of the Fulda was significantly ahead of that of the Werra, considerable flooding already occurred at the Upper Weser. The peak of the flood passed the Weser gauge at Hannoversch Münden on March 12 and reached the gauges in Vlotho and Porta Westfalica on March 14. The Middle Weser area was also affected by the flood situation, particularly downstream of the confluence with the also flood-prone Aller. Thus, the immense influx caused the outflow of the Weser to swell to critical levels, leading to the flooding of the meadows at Thedinghausen. Initially, this did not provoke any press reports, as these uninhabited areas were often at least partially underwater. Between March 12 and 14, further rain fell from west to east due to low-pressure systems. Only from March 15, with significantly lowered temperatures, did little precipitation fall. However, in some places above Bremen, the winter dikes soon came under threat, and on March 12, the Weser-Kurier informed in a small, 18-line report under the headline "Flood wave endangers the allotments" for the first time about an impending flood in the Hanseatic city. Subsequently, various allotment gardeners in the city began to clear their houses located in the officially designated overflow areas. The summer dike, which ran a few hundred meters upstream of the Weserwehr on the left bank, was designed for up to 1,300 m³ of water per second. Therefore, flooding was expected on March 13, which would have resulted in flooding of the adjacent allotment areas Hastedter Bulten and Fresenbulten before the water could have been directed back into the river via the overflow channels Werdersee and Kleine Weser. Initially, this did not occur, but was then scheduled by experts for the early morning hours of March 14; however, it did not happen again. Meanwhile, at the Weserwehr, due to the exceptionally high water level, there was hardly any noticeable difference in level between the gauges of the Middle and Lower Weser.

The first serious damage from the flooding occurred in Bremen on the morning of March 15, when around 7 a.m. the riverbank path below the so-called "Wehrschloss" on the right bank began to sag directly at the weir. The fire department dispatched twelve emergency vehicles and secured already slipped trees with wire ropes – on one hand to avoid hindering shipping should they fall into the river, and on the other hand, to use them as a natural protective barrier for the riverbank. Four trees (poplars and beeches) had to be cut down, and 18 others were tied down with steel cables. By noon, however, the water had washed away three meters of the bank. The backflow at the defective weir caused the Weser River – as had been expected for two days – to overflow the summer dike, which was between 6.50 and 6.70 meters high, partially washing it away. After the westward flowing water poured over fields, grasslands, and bird meadows, the designated flood channel Werdersee was filled, but the majority of the flood unexpectedly flowed further north, destroying several allotment garden areas in the process. About 120 meters east of the Karl-Carstens Bridge, the water crashed from the land side onto the summer dike (on the left Weser bank) and stressed it so much that it gave way and broke around 3 p.m. Within an hour, this breach had enlarged many times over. Thus, the water flowed back more than four kilometers upstream from the point where the Werdersee would have had its regular inlet. About 100 allotment plots were swept into the Weser. The water police attempted to stop and secure floating huts, cars, and detached boats with small tugs. This was only partially successful six kilometers further downstream. The river had bypassed the weir in a short distance and created a new, deep bed within a few hours. A large part of the Weser water was now flowing around the weir on the left side. Quickly, this stream – from the overflowed summer dike at the Middle Weser through the overcrowded area occupied by plots to the breach of the winter dike and backflow into the Lower Weser – was designated as the "Neue Weser." The water also caused severe damage along the banks of the targeted flood channel. Particularly affected was the dike bend of the winter dike at the Karl-Carstens Bridge, as the water pressed directly against this projection. Around 6 p.m., an inflow of 1850 m³ per second with an increasing trend was measured at the weir. The police closed the roads leading directly into the flood area, including the accesses and approaches to the Weser weir. In the evening, about 3.3 kilometers in a straight line from the main flooding area, a breach occurred in the road leading from the Buntentors-Deichschart in Bremen Neustadt to the "Kuhhirten" restaurant on the Stadtwerder. It separated the Werdersee from the Kleine Weser with its dam. The breach allowed for better drainage of the Werdersee, which, although it contributed only slightly to the rapid improvement of the situation, resulted in the lake emptying into the Kleine Weser after the peak of the flood. The next day, March 16, a new flood wave of 1900 m³ per second turned the already wide breach in the winter dike from the previous day into a powerful stream that swept away another 50 plots into the river. The water flowed back into the Weser but was not absorbed by its current; instead, it pressed further downstream against the bank on the opposite right riverbank, causing significant damage there as well. Trees that had previously been secured with steel cables were washed away. In some places, the bank eroded up to five meters. The promenade between the fish ladder – where the force of the water broke apart the concrete boxes – and the Jakobsberg sports field completely sank, for example. The Hemelinger harbor facilities on the right Weser bank above the weir were also flooded knee-deep despite high sheet pile walls. Work had to be halted in the Allerhafen. Water seeped out between the gates that had sealed off the roads to the harbor. Sandbag barriers were erected in the area of the feeder to the A1 motorway. While in the afternoon a Weser outflow of up to 2,650 m³ per second was reported from Verden, despite the efforts of the helpers who had now arrived, the promenade at the dike bend at the bridge slid down by two-thirds by noon. If the winter dike had broken here, large parts of the residential areas of Habenhausen would have been flooded. It was considered to dig a channel for water intake immediately west of the bridge, but the work took too long. At 5 p.m., 200 helpers from the fire department, the Technical Relief Organization, and the riot police began constructing a relief dam from the damaged dike bend to the bridge base. On the morning of the following day, March 17, this dam was completed around 4 a.m., and the flood risk for Habenhausen was temporarily averted. On both days, March 15 and 16, the grotesque image of the devastated allotment gardens attracted thousands of onlookers who gathered on the Werder Bridge. They sometimes cheered individual huts that were swept into the Weser. Even snack stands were set up on the slightly elevated foot and bike path. The police had up to 120 officers on site at times and struggled to keep the roadway clear for vehicle traffic. During the flood and especially in the aftermath, the behavior of the "disaster tourists" was heavily criticized. A total of about 550 allotment gardeners were affected by the flood, with the Hastedter Bulten e.V. being hit harder than the neighboring Fresenbulten e.V., where initially only about 40 huts were underwater. Around 6 a.m. on March 17, the road surface of Hannoversche Straße in Hemelingen partially collapsed, presumably due to undermining from the flooded Allerhafen. By late afternoon, the water level at the Weser weir had fallen by six centimeters, and the feared weir break was thus temporarily no longer a concern. Nevertheless, in the now 150-meter-wide "Neue Weser," erosion of up to twelve meters deep was observed. In this area, in addition to the allotments, eight network stations of the municipal utilities (now swb AG) were destroyed. By the afternoon of March 18, the water level at the Weser weir had fallen from 7.04 to 6.95 meters, according to the Bremen Water Management Office. In the residential area located immediately behind the softened dike on the southern edge of the flood area, the fire department had to pump out basements on Habenhauser Dorfstraße and Holzdamm. As the peak of the disaster seemed to have been surpassed, another small embankment above the Weser weir on the left bank – the so-called Bootshafendeich at the marina of the Oberweser Sailing Club e.V. – broke at 2 a.m. on the night of March 19, and in the following days, the local sheet pile walls, a small land spit, and the regatta tower were washed away. Although club members erected sandbag and stone barriers, they could only limit the washouts and not stop them. This resulted in the Weser weir being further relieved, but on the other hand, the "Neue Weser" was additionally nourished with several million cubic meters of water. Consequently, the breakthrough back into the Weser east of the Werder Bridge intensified again throughout the morning. Around 1 p.m., another section – about 30 meters east of the bridge – was washed out, measuring 15 meters long and five meters deep from the earth of the dike. The additional water masses caused significant damage again on the opposite Weser bank after the backflow into the Weser, where they crashed at nearly a right angle. Although the Water Management Office made efforts to fill the holes in the bank, it was largely unsuccessful. By around 10 a.m., the Hastedter allotment area Im Suhrfelde had been evacuated as a precaution. Subsequently, both the Osterdeich between Stader Straße and Weser weir and, due to concerns about structural integrity, the Werder Bridge were closed to all traffic for several days. The "Neue Weser" continued to carve deeper into the subsoil of the fields, allotment gardens, and marshes hour by hour, so that the flow velocity in the area of Hastedter Bulten initially changed little. The Weser outflow fell to 960 m³ per second by March 24, but the water receded only slowly from the flood areas. It was not until April that an average water flow was reestablished at the weir. Just under two months later, on June 9, another flood with a peak flow rate of 1100 m³ per second reached the Hanseatic city but remained largely without consequences.

Whole_Text.header: Cleanup work in the first year
Whole_Text.content:
Five days after the first breakthrough of the Weser into the overflow areas, the securing and later cleanup work began. On the morning of March 20, during one of the regular static measurements at the Werder Bridge, it was found that one of the pillars had twisted by one and a half centimeters. A seven-meter-deep hole had formed around it. However, the authorities stated that there was no danger. To support the pillar, on the same day, they began lowering normal stones as well as over 150 tetrapods and so-called delta stones at the relevant location. Additionally, the officials at the water management office voted for the construction of a pontoon bridge over the water surface of the "New Weser," which was to follow the course of the interrupted weir road and be built by the Bundeswehr. It was planned that starting March 23, trucks would transport stones to fill the breach in the dike above the weir over the bridge. The dike closure work was to begin at the site of the Oberweser Sailing Club, where the "New Weser" started at a width of 180 meters. Also on March 20, the budget committee of the finance deputation allocated 500,000 D-marks to be advanced for dike repairs. Meanwhile, the SPD local association in Hastedt called on the Senate and its own citizens' faction to restore the recreational and green areas in the district between the weir and Jakobsberg as quickly as possible. On March 22, 150 soldiers from the floating bridge battalion 160 from Minden and the heavy pioneer battalion 11 from Dörverden began constructing a 500-meter-long steel mat road on a sand bed from the southern beginning of the weir road in the Habenhauser residential area directly towards the Middle Weser over the flooded meadows. A prior reconnaissance had shown that the original plan – construction along the weir road – was not possible. The current in that area would have been too strong for the bridge. Additionally, there were concerns that the Bundeswehr vehicles could get stuck in the mud after a rapid draining of the "New Weser."

Other flood-damaged areas were also taken into account during the rescue operations in those days. On March 22, they began filling the heavily affected weir promenade in Hastedt with slag and natural stones. To prevent the progression and expansion of the breakthrough at the Werder Bridge, a 300-meter-long sheet pile wall was driven across the remaining Hastedter Bulten starting March 23. For this, 16 previously undamaged small garden plots had to be sacrificed. From March 23, a Bundeswehr pontoon ferry also transported machines and filling material to the Oberweser Sailing Club. Initially, a small dam had to be pushed over a creek to the Werraweg before the actual dike construction work could begin with the lowering of tetrapods. They worked on both sides of the breakthrough to better control the current. The open spaces were filled with water construction and slag stones and sealed with a mineral mixture. By March 24, the new dike had already grown to a length of 20 meters. To relieve the "New Weser" in the construction area from the excessive water pressure, the weir was set to its lowest possible position to allow additional water to flow out over the "Old Weser." In addition to the previous filling material, employees of the water management office supplemented the construction site starting March 26 from a pontoon maneuvered by rope with initially around 1,000 three-meter-long special sandbags made of nylon. These were intended to help reduce the water flow speed, as otherwise, the filling material of the new dike could be washed away. However, the bags were partially pushed away by the current, so they refocused on stones and tetrapods. On March 28 and 29, there were unexpected delays in closing the dike. The rope of the pontoon broke several times, and Hans-Dieter Bücken, head of the Bremen water management office, stated that they would probably still need about 5,000 special sandbags for the remaining 40 meters. The current of the "New Weser" remained very high, and the water was eroding the Hastedter Bulten with a slightly changed impact direction. Individual plots were still being destroyed during these days. In the aftermath of the actual flood disaster, the Weser breakthrough still caused injuries. A construction worker had to be treated in the hospital after getting his leg caught between a freight cart and a device pole on March 29. A major setback occurred at the breach site on April 4 when the current tore a 30-meter-wide hole in the nearly finished dike around 6:30 PM. More than 30,000 tons of natural stones had already been used, but it gave way at its weakest point, where no stones could yet be sunk for transport reasons. In light of this development, Hans-Dieter Bücken emphatically called for the construction of the originally planned pontoon bridge on March 5, as more material was needed and the ferry was not efficient enough. The conditions for bridge construction were now significantly better due to the changed current conditions than they had been two weeks earlier. Subsequently, the pioneers began bridge construction on the evening of April 6, which could be completed by noon on April 7. The bridge consisted of 100 hollow bodies and could carry a weight of 50 tons. After completion, it was used continuously by trucks. In addition to filling the dike breach, cutter dredgers, as a supporting measure, washed sand from the Middle Weser in front of the newly emerging dam. Starting April 8, about 20 tetrapods were to be launched daily. Additionally, it was expected that several thousand tons of stones and filling material would still be needed. In the night of April 9, the dike breach was finally closed. In the following weeks, the area was continuously reinforced and sealed with a mineral mixture. The costs for this spatially limited measure amounted to 3.2 million D-marks. 36,000 tons of filling stones, 3,000 tons of mineral mixture, 635 tetrapods, and over 4,000 sandbags were used. However, during the tidal high water, which affected the Lower Weser up to the Weser weir, the "New Weser" still periodically transformed into a river behind the dike, as the incoming tide pressed into the erosion channel through the breach at the Werder Bridge. Nothing changed in this situation throughout the summer. Initially, the water construction experts had to address more pressing issues. For the residents in the area of Werraweg, a temporary path was created on the dike, and on April 9, chief building officer Winfried Reiner from the water and shipping office announced that the steep bank at Jakobsberg in Hastedt would be retracted. It had been pushed too far into the Weser after World War II. Primarily, engineers were to focus on repairing the still defective weir body starting mid-April. On April 9, the head of the Hemelingen local office, Hans Dieter Rissland, demanded that the Hastedter promenade and greenway below the weir be completely restored, as the industrialized district already had very few recreational areas. In that area, a 40-meter-wide section had been washed away. Rissland accused the federal and state authorities of indifference regarding the protection of green spaces. Meanwhile, several dredging ships on the Lower and Middle Weser cleared the river of numerous sandbanks and shallows that had formed due to sedimentation from the flood. By noon on April 14, ships with a draft of up to 2.20 meters were again allowed to navigate the Middle Weser, but only for a limited time: lockages for upstream travel occurred only two hours before and after the tidal high water. Starting April 14, 600 tons of earth were moved to replace the broken dike chart path at the western end of the Werdersee with a temporary sand dam. The filling was to be completed by Easter (April 19) to provide a temporary connection for pedestrians and cyclists. If the water level of the lake rose again, the path connection was to be maintained via a pontoon bridge. Local politicians from Neustadt demanded that the Werdersee be temporarily dammed again to revive the local recreational factor and limit ecological damage. However, the bottom would first need to be cleaned of debris. Together with the water management office, the Bremen dike association began in May to repair the damages to the Habenhauser winter dike along a length of one kilometer on the left bank of the Weser. The extremely endangered dike bend at the foot of the Werder Bridge was also straightened. The renovated dike section is one kilometer long. 50,000 cubic meters of clay soil had to be moved for these measures, and 60,000 square meters of embankment and foreland areas were reseeded. The Werdersee tributary at the foot of the dike was filled with 75,000 cubic meters of sand. Dietrich Harborth, spokesperson for the building senator, predicted at a meeting of the Neustadt local council on May 6 that the Werdersee would probably not be used by the public as a sports and recreational area until at least 1983. He explained that the lake was completely silted up and might need to be manually excavated. If machines were used for sand removal, the insulating clay layer would break. When news of another impending flood reached Bremen, the recently completed dike above the weir was hastily raised from five to six meters for 80,000 D-marks and with the help of several thousand cubic meters of clay soil starting June 4. The flood passed without consequences, allowing focus to shift to work at the western end of the disaster area. Starting June 11, the plans from mid-April were implemented, and dredging and cleaning of the Werdersee began – despite the sensitive clay soil with heavy machinery. The silt removed was at least partially used to fill the edges of the Hastedter Bulten. On July 2, Hans-Dieter Bücken informed the Obervieland local council about the progress of the plans. The work on the Habenhauser winter dike, which had begun in May, was nearing completion, with a flattening of the embankment and a widening of the crown path. Repairs were to be completed by the end of August. Bücken pointed out that the filling of the Werdersee tributary was necessary because it ran too close to the foot of the dike and could soften it during high water. The summer dikes were also to be closed and supplemented again. Additionally, a clay wall was planned for better protection of the bank edge. SPD local politician Egon Hartwig expressed the view that the landscape altered by the "New Weser" could later also be used as a recreational area. On August 10, the awarding committee of the building deputation decided on five construction and planning measures in the flood-damaged floodplain. Among other things, the weir road was to be rebuilt for 670,000 D-marks in accordance with its former course, but this time elevated. The dam received three water passages. Even more important was the decision to close the backflow breakthrough in the Hastedter Bulten. It was feared that otherwise, the winter storm floods would lead to renewed flooding of the meadows and the remaining small gardens. The gaping hole was to be sealed with a new dike six meters high, on which a two-meter-wide asphalted foot and bike path was to be laid. The costs for this were estimated at 2.5 million D-marks. The costs to restore the revetment on the southern shore of the lake over a length of one and a half kilometers were estimated at one million D-marks. On September 1, this construction site at the Werder Bridge was established. Initially, 25,000 tons of sand from the "New Weser" were piled up to form a dam; the same amount was supplied by dredging below the Stephanibrücke. The sand core, the cover layer of clay soil, and the dike crown were secured with a 60-centimeter-thick layer of stones. The angle of the dike slope allowed for water overflow in case of emergency. To reinforce and secure the new dike, a steel sheet pile wall was driven parallel to the Weser, connecting to the one from spring. It later disappeared into the revetment and was no longer visible. To continue ensuring a connection between the "New Weser" and the river and thus maintain water exchange, the construction workers laid a pipeline with a sluice through the dam. A flap at the Weser end of the pipe closed under the water pressure during incoming tide, thus preventing a rise in water in the "New Weser." On September 17, the breakthrough site could be closed by bulldozers at 11:05 AM – 186 days after its formation. The "New Weser," now re-diked on both sides, had thus become a lake. By the end of the day, the dike was further raised to three meters. In total, 35,000 cubic meters of sand, 10,000 tons of filling stones, and an additional 10,000 cubic meters of clay soil for stabilization were needed for this dike closure. By the end of October, the repair and renovation work at the Weser weir could also be completed. The costs for restoring flood protection burdened Bremen with nine million and the federal government with 13 million D-marks in 1981.

Already on March 16, just one day after the dike breach, Bremen's mayor Hans Koschnick reminded that the affected small garden areas had been designated as overflow areas and therefore the city could not be legally held liable for compensation payments. However, he promised a favorable review of financial assistance by the Senate, as the deficit of small gardens should not be increased. To free the city from demands for compensation, Building Senator Bernd Meyer critically noted on the same day that Johann Dreyer, chairman of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends, stated that the affected individuals did not want or could bear the water damage alone. Despite the financial plight of the state, the Senate had to help the small gardeners, especially since the flooding area also served as a local recreation area for tens of thousands of Bremen residents. He emphasized that the damages were not insured but also admitted that every small gardener was aware of the risk of owning a hut in the designated overflow area. His association called for a fundraising campaign on March 18, as neither he nor the affected individuals could replace the damages even remotely. The chairman of the opposition FDP parliamentary group, Horst-Jürgen Lahmann, pointed out the next day that the small gardeners were aware of the risks of their location and therefore could not expect compensation from the state or city budget. He proposed a tax deferral as an alternative. This idea was taken up by Finance Senator Moritz Thape on March 20, when he decided, with the approval of Federal Finance Minister Hans Matthöfer, on a regulation for tax assistance for flood-affected citizens. Thus, tax debts could now be deferred upon request, advance payments on income, corporate, and trade taxes adjusted, and enforcement actions suspended. Also on March 19, the small gardeners intensified their own relief efforts. The Federal Association of German Garden Friends called on its ten state associations to organize fundraising campaigns, and independently, the State Association of Garden Friends in Hamburg pledged its support and assistance. Furthermore, the SPD local association Hastedt announced that it would conduct a fundraising campaign among the population and local businesses. On March 22, the Bremen small gardener association Werder decided at a general meeting that each member should donate 15 D-Mark. The board intended to increase the total amount from the association's funds to 7,500 D-Mark. The association also reserved five newly created plots for the flood victims. At the same time, the SPD parliamentary group made its own assessment of the situation on site in the flood area. Parliamentary group leader Klaus Wedemeier pointed out that the Weser was a federal waterway. Therefore, the regulation of damages could not essentially be a Bremen matter. On March 23, Building Senator Meyer offered the affected individuals quick and unbureaucratic assistance from the state government. From now on, 100 new plots could be created in the Wolfskuhle park in the Kattenturm district, for which the Senate would provide 1.2 million D-Mark. At that time, around 10,000 D-Mark had already been received in the small gardeners' donation account. A large automobile factory had sent a check for 1,000 D-Mark and also offered "quick and unconventional help." Another company provided the small gardeners with fertilizers and peat products for a fresh start free of charge. Following urgent requests, the board of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends received approval on March 28 at a general meeting in the Lower German Theater from the 276 delegates to allocate 100,000 D-Mark from the association's assets. Additionally, a solidarity levy of ten D-Mark per member for the Hastedter Bulten association was decided. By that time, 307,000 D-Mark in donations had been raised. The next day, March 29, the benefiting small gardeners of Hastedter Bulten held an extraordinary meeting with 500 members and relatives in the community hall on Drakenburger Straße. They called on the Senate not only to provide them with the compensation areas at Wolfskuhle but also to help them financially. Furthermore, the authorities had to "fully restore" the small garden area as soon as the water had receded. In a letter to Johann Dreyer dated May 5, Meyer announced that a perspective for joint action had been found, which should be perceived as fair, especially by the flood-affected small gardeners: "The clarification of the legal situation revealed that appropriate compensation must be paid by Bremen for the plots claimed on the sheet pile wall route." Although, due to a lack of legal basis, no compensation for flood damage could be considered for private individuals, the Senate agreed to help the affected small gardeners—those who wanted to continue—financially and through services from the offices. There should be no distinction between the establishment of a new garden and the takeover of an existing free garden. "Moreover, I will advocate for a quick decision to ensure that in these cases, leaf loans of up to 7,000 Marks can be granted," Meyer continued. On the same day, recipient Dreyer estimated the damage at 1.2 million D-Mark. He stated that the small gardeners wanted to raise 300,000 from solidarity donations themselves, and 30,000 D-Mark had been donated so far by outsiders. The next day, on May 6, he increased his damage assessment to 1.5 million D-Mark and stated that no politician had yet promised concrete help—which, however, contradicts the offers of assistance from the city. However, on the same day, Ludwig Meyer, chairman of the most severely affected small garden association Hastedter Bulten, expressed similar sentiments. He found it outrageous that Bremen politicians had not yet made any proposals to alleviate the plight even almost two months after the flood. However, the small gardeners were pleased with the spontaneous willingness to help that they received from the population and associations from across the country. By the end of the first week of May, 65,000 D-Mark in donations had already been collected. Additionally, various garden associations from the Hanseatic city provided over 17,000 D-Mark, and the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends contributed 300,000. Its chairman Dreyer emphatically pointed out that the members felt abandoned. The argument that the small gardeners had known from the beginning how endangered their settlement area was was not accepted by him: After a visit from the CDU parliamentary group in Obervieland, its chairman, opposition leader, and CDU state chairman Bernd Neumann called on May 7 for unbureaucratic help for all small gardeners who had lost their plots in Hastedter Bulten. They had informed themselves about the flood damage, which must now be estimated between 40 and 50 million D-Mark, Neumann continued. Almost word for word, SPD building deputies and members of the board of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends reaffirmed their willingness to help the victims quickly and unbureaucratically after a joint discussion on the same day. At the same time, the Social Democratic deputies appealed to the small gardeners to make more use of the replacement garden offer at Wolfskuhle. After all, leaf loans of up to 7,000 D-Mark would be granted for this, regardless of income. The operating company of the city hall organized a benefit concert on May 13 as part of the relief efforts—officially referred to as "Bunter Abend"—for the benefit of the affected individuals. All artists and catering businesses waived their fees or revenues. They expected 5,000 spectators in the city hall and a corresponding revenue of about 100,000 D-Mark. The nearly four-hour event under the motto "Bremen helps Bremen" was moderated by Jo Hannes Müller and Manfred Ebel. In addition to Heinz Eckner, Rudi Carrell, the pop band Ebony, the Friedel-Ropers choirs, the dance formation "Bremer Schlüssel," singer Rolf Simson, and the Three Sihoclas, the A-Team in Modern Latin formation dance from TSG Bremerhaven, which was the reigning world champion at the time, also performed. Furthermore, chamber singer Georg Koch and soprano Helga Hildebrand from the Bremen Theater, as well as Erika Rumpsfeld and Hans Rolf Radula from the Lower German Stage, appeared. The musical arrangement of the evening was provided by the Bremen Entertainment Orchestra under the direction of Herbert Plümecke, the Army Music Corps 11 from Grohn under the direction of Captain Wintering, and the Music Corps of the Bremen Protection Police under the direction of Max Milde. The Bremen-born James Last could not attend the evening due to a stay in the USA but donated 100 long-playing records, which were sold on-site. Federal President Karl Carstens, also from Bremen, took over the patronage of the event and had greetings conveyed by the president of the parliament, Dieter Klink. However, the "Bunter Abend" met with extremely little interest despite numerous media announcements and the presence of prominent artists. Only about 1,000 Bremen residents wanted to experience it—nearly 300 Bundeswehr soldiers were even ordered as "fillers" into the largely empty hall. The revenue ultimately amounted to only 15,000 D-Mark. Building official Götz Neuber quoted a report already presented to the parliament regarding damage regulation at a public meeting of the Obervieland local council on June 11, according to which no culpable behavior by public authorities was recognizable. Therefore, the state could not be liable for direct flood damage and losses. Compensation could only be paid by the Senate to those whose property was affected by flood control measures (farmers whose land was used for emergency access routes / small gardeners whose plots were used for driving the sheet pile wall before the bridge's pillar foundation). Within this "framework of what is legally permissible," the senatorial offices were committed to helping the small gardeners and compensating for the damage caused. Economic Senator Karl Willms stated that he wanted to examine in discussions with the Chamber of Agriculture to what extent farmers could be compensated for loss of income. Subsequently, on June 23, there was a controversial debate in the parliament regarding a major inquiry from the CDU parliamentary group. Building Senator Bernd Meyer emphasized that only areas were flooded that "by their natural function and according to applicable law are to serve as flood discharge." This had also been taken into account when approving small garden huts on Hastedter Bulten. Therefore, Bremen could hardly provide financial assistance to the privately affected. However, he reiterated the plan to offer replacement small gardens in the Wolfskuhle area, to grant leaf loans to plot holders, to enable tax relief, and to provide unbureaucratic individual assistance. Peter Willers from the Bremen Green List criticized the confusion of competencies regarding responsibilities between the federal government and the states of Bremen and Lower Saxony. He attributed the flood significantly to the intervention in nature—such as the canalization of the Weser—therefore, the small gardeners certainly had a legal claim to compensation. In the summer, the small gardeners received several large donations. On June 26, Horst Reich, as the first chairman of the Leisure Community Arsten, presented Johann Dreyer with a check for 3,500 D-Mark on the occasion of the tenth anniversary of the association, collected from the 116 members. The donations received by that day totaled 220,000 D-Mark. Wolfgang Schreck, head of the Daimler-Benz plant in Sebaldsbrück, handed Dreyer a check for 26,000 D-Mark on July 22. About a year after the Weser breach, 570,000 D-Mark had been raised, donated by Bremen residents for the small gardeners. On August 20, several soldiers from the Heavy Pioneer Battalion 11 from Dörverden visited the small garden association Weserwehr. Its plots on the so-called "Wehrinsel" had been completely surrounded by water during the flood but had not been flooded due to their elevated location. Nevertheless, the association members were particularly dependent on the pontoon bridge and wanted to thank for the assistance provided with this meeting. The local council and the local office of Obervieland supported this initiative, "because the deployment of the Bundeswehr soldiers is not taken for granted, but a committed thank you should be expressed."

In order to make the largely devastated harbor of the Oberweser Sailing Club e. V. usable again directly at the Weser bend, club chairman Helmut Steinmetz estimated a sum of one million Deutsche Marks on March 20. Only the boathouse and the winter storage halls remained undamaged. In this emergency, the camaraderie of the athletes came into play, and they were taken in as guest moorers by neighboring clubs. The Weser Sailing Club e. V. was affected somewhat less severely, as its grounds are located directly west of the Weser Stadium. By the end of April, a quarter of the capacity of 15 berths for larger dinghies had become silted up and unusable after silt had deposited from the upstream floodplain area behind the club's sheet pile wall. However, chairman Helmut Barenborg stated at the end of April that the club was prohibited from dredging its own harbor bed and dumping the sand into the Weser. Therefore, the Waterways and Shipping Office had to address the problem using floating dredgers and barges. However, this request was denied after a few days. In a letter, the authority rejected the sand extraction, citing the small amount. At the same time, they indicated that they would approve the club's request to flush the silt into the Weser at their own expense. Threatened in its financial existence, the Weser Sailing Club e. V. then sought help from Sports Senator Henning Scherf. At the public meeting of the Obervieland local council on June 11, Scherf promised to organize assistance for the Oberweser Sailing Club, and indeed, Hans-Dieter Bücken informed the council on July 2 that as part of the dike renovations, the bank protection work at the club would also be restored. A point of contention on its grounds was the construction of the harbor boundary. Before the flood, a sheet pile wall had been used as a barrier to the Weser. After the dike closure in early April, there were plans to limit the newly created harbor with a stone embankment. However, this would have significantly narrowed the harbor basin. No one was willing to cover the additional costs of 350,000 Deutsche Marks for the construction of a new sheet pile wall. After lengthy negotiations, the Senate ultimately decided to partially finance the solution favored by the club. Although the Oberweser Sailing Club still had to take on 100,000 Deutsche Marks in debt and cover the costs for the construction of the 95-meter-long landing bridge opposite the sheet pile wall, it was able to be saved. This was made possible not least thanks to donations amounting to 50,000 Deutsche Marks – including from SC Niedersachsen Werder and WV Woltmershausen. On May 9, 1982, the new harbor was inaugurated in the presence of numerous local politicians.

The Weser breakthrough of 1981, during which the Weser sought a new bed, is recorded in the city's annals as one of the worst floods in Bremen, even though "only" parcels were affected. Although it significantly changed the landscape, it only represents part of the threat at that time, as during those days, a storm surge also reached the Hanseatic city along with the flood of the Upper and Middle Weser. An area of 70 hectares was flooded during the Weser breakthrough, destroying 44 hectares of agricultural land, between 127 and 150 parcel houses on the eastern city island were destroyed, damages amounted to about 56 million Deutsche Marks, and more than 1.5 million cubic meters of soil and sediments were washed into the Weser. Large parts of the affected area were subsequently covered by a layer of silt, mud, and sand, which was contaminated with heavy metal deposits, up to one meter thick. The majority of the uprooted allotments have not been rebuilt. Their location – the breakthrough of the "New Weser" back into the river – is now dominated by wild growth. Particularly from a bird's eye view, the course of the flood can still be well traced. The parcel area Hastedter Bulten is thus divided. The water flow at the threshold from the Middle to the Lower Weser increased massively as a result of the Weser breakthrough and the forcibly created additional outflow option. For example, on March 20, only about 300 m³ per second flowed over the weir itself, while 1000 m³ per second sought the path of the "New Weser." As a result, the water level of the Middle Weser upstream to Langwedel fell dramatically in places. In the short term, there were fears that it could drop to 60 to 80 centimeters. Combined with the sandbanks created by the flood, this was one of the main reasons for a nearly month-long closure of the corresponding section of the Weser for inland shipping.

In 1981, the Senate commissioned the Franzius Institute for Hydraulic Engineering and Coastal Engineering at the University of Hanover to conduct hydraulic model tests on future flood discharge options in the area of the Weser breakthrough. The large-scale model experiment began at the end of October and cost around 500,000 Deutsche Marks, of which the federal government covered 40% and the state of Bremen 60%. Scientists from the University of Hanover and the Technical University of Braunschweig also began working on this topic in mid-June. An investigation commission was established, which concluded only that the dyke breaches resulted from a chain of unfortunate circumstances. On one hand, the weir should have been repaired much earlier, and on the other hand, the flood protection measures taken in the 1950s "from above" – namely the construction of the flood channel – had failed. On April 21, 1983, work began to at least partially refill the deeply excavated bed of the "New Weser" east of the Werder Bridge, aside from previous repair and security work. Trucks transported around 125,000 cubic meters of earth to the area in the following months. This was excavated material from the Krimpelsee, located in the districts of Habenhausen and Kattenturm. This effort managed to fill the erosion channel by about two-thirds. However, the future of the "New Weser" remained unclear for several years. While the Bremen Water Management Office wanted to wait for the results of the Franzius Institute's report at the end of May 1983, nature conservation experts believed that the habitat interesting for flora and fauna could be preserved regardless of flood protection strategies. Farmers affected by the Weser breakthrough, on the other hand, advocated for refilling the "New Weser" to regain lost arable land. Hermann Cordes, a professor of vegetation science and nature conservation at the University of Bremen, explained that remarkable plant species had quickly established themselves along the water's edge. These were primarily species that had previously been counted among the common flora of large primeval river valleys. From an ornithological perspective, the shallow water zones on the Hastedter Bulten were also interesting, as they attracted numerous feeding guests – such as herons and sandpipers. Cordes stated that the area did not necessarily have to be designated as a nature reserve. It could also be preserved as a remarkable landscape formation and recreational area without special protection status. Hans-Dieter Bücken, head of the Water Management Office, also said it was highly unlikely that the "New Weser" would have to be removed for flood protection reasons. However, Holger Schmidt, the spokesperson for the Obervieland local council, pointed out that private property had been affected by the "New Weser." Therefore, the farmers' desire to restore the original state was quite understandable. Furthermore, the preservation of the "New Weser" and the construction of a nature conservation-friendly inlet facility would be difficult to realize together. During the Weser breakthrough in 1981, the Werdersee had proven to be almost ineffective in its intended protective function: while it protected the Neustadt from storm surges, it could not secure Habenhausen from inland floods of the Middle Weser. This circumstance, the already partially completed remodeling of the dykes, and the still perceived foreign body of the "New Weser," along with the question of how to deal with it, ultimately led to the decision for a large-scale redesign of the area. The holistic and nature-oriented concept aimed to prevent a similar disaster and targeted a more controlled flow of potential floods. The most visible measure was the extension of the still dry Werdersee by 1.07 kilometers eastward beyond the Werder Bridge to protect the structure from uncontrolled undermining and to provide a quicker catchment opportunity for incoming inland floods. A deepening of the lake in the area of the bridge was also intended to keep flowing water away from the foundations. The eastern basin of the overflow area was extensively raised to slow down the flow velocity of the overflowing Weser water. The weir road was reinstated in its old course and now passes directly by the Werdersee at its eastern end. Here, the new inlet flows into the lake, branching off from the left bank of the Weser above the Oberweser sailing club and ensuring the supply of fresh water and circulation to the lake over 738 meters. The slightly winding canal features artificial rapids, was constructed far from any winter dyke, is equipped with sluices at two summer dyke passages, and is designed in a very nature-friendly manner as a compensatory measure for construction work in the port area. A crucial intervention in the redesign was also the removal of the land bridge at the western end of the Werdersee, which separated it from the Kleine Weser. Since then, the dyke path has crossed over a bridge for pedestrians and cyclists, which had been requested as early as 1981, under which the two bodies of water were completely connected. They now form a continuous left-flowing watercourse from the weir road to the confluence with the Weser in the city center at the Bürgermeister-Smidt Bridge, measuring 5.7 kilometers in length. This allows potentially overflowing floodwaters from the Middle Weser to flow unhindered into the Lower Weser. Finally, in 1987, the Werdersee was flooded again, and since then it has served as one of the largest contiguous and most frequented recreational areas in the city. The floodwaters in March 1981 eroded marsh soil and sand layers, rearranged them, and created a patchwork of various soil types that offers diverse niches for plants with different requirements. As Hermann Cordes had already predicted in 1983, this provided nature conservationists with the opportunity to preserve a small area of vibrant river dynamics in the midst of the city. The lake remaining in the floodplain was ecologically redesigned. Certain shore areas were flattened, and a buffer zone was established around the reservoir to prevent excessive eutrophication from the surrounding agricultural land. Finally, on December 28, 1988, the lake and surrounding green spaces were designated as a nature reserve "Neue Weser," covering 34.8 hectares. The area is left to the natural, human and livestock-unaffected vegetation development, which is scientifically monitored. It now hosts a diverse natural landscape with numerous habitats such as reeds, grasslands, tall herb communities, flood meadows, still waters, near-natural floodplain shrubs, and trees, and is designated as a European Bird Area. As such, it is of great importance for both migratory and breeding birds. For example, numerous species of ducks and gray herons live there, and river terns nest on an artificial pontoon. The water body is fed by bank filtrate from the Weser and drains through discharge pipes into the Lower Weser. In summer, there is no stable temperature stratification. As early as June 11, 1981, Chief Building Officer Winfried Reiner from the Water and Shipping Office admitted at a public meeting of the Obervieland local council that the Weser weir no longer met the then-current DIN standards. For new constructions, there must be three independently controllable flow openings according to the safety standards valid after 1981, so that in the event of damage to one weir, the majority of the floodwater can still flow through the other two. One of the most practical solutions in the context of the new regulation of flood discharge in Habenhausen was therefore a modernization or new construction – in any case, an increase in the capacity of the weir. Ultimately, a new Weser weir was built 180 meters downstream from the old site starting in 1989, with costs amounting to approximately 287.5 million, including the new lock facility. It was put into operation on June 10, 1993. The new control concept for inland floods is designed for a Weser discharge of up to 4,200 cubic meters per second – this value corresponds to the flood event in February and March 1881 and has a recurrence interval of 600 years. Of this, 3,400 m³ are to flow through the weir, and the remaining 800 m³ through the so-called "flood discharge channel," which consists of the Werdersee inlet, Werdersee, and Kleine Weser.

The critical comments following the Weser breakthrough of 1981 primarily targeted the flood control concept that existed at the time – which many commentators retrospectively deemed inadequate – as well as the behavior of political decision-makers. On March 16, Johann Dreyer, chairman of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends, spoke out. He criticized that at the western end of the Werdersee, the Deichschartweg had been laid over a dam. Dreyer preferred a bridge with a small weir instead of just the existing narrow passage. However, the official admitted that he could only assess this technical problem as a layperson. Wilhelm Mahrtens was the head of the Water and Shipping Directorate Northwest and was responsible for the Jade-Weser area. On March 21, he attributed the "delayed" break of the boat harbor dike not to the water pressure from the direction of the Middle Weser, but rather to the backward erosion in the floodplain. This was made possible primarily because in the area of the undermined weir road, loose farmland had been converted into relatively solid meadows, which, according to him, should never have happened. The plowed soil had provided the water with significantly better opportunities to dig deep. Furthermore, the flood was by no means a result of the malfunction of any of the weir structures. Mahrtens considered the overflow basins between Werraweg and Bullenwerder to be a serious planning error. Without them, the first flood wave would have taken its predetermined path through the flood channel to the Werdersee. Even the former river construction director Ludwig Plate had criticized the establishment of the small garden areas in the flood-prone area, Mahrtens said. Archive documents indicate that the responsible parties had already demanded in 1928 that no parcels be built in the water drainage area. Building senator Bernd Meyer responded on March 23 with the words: "There are now far more important things than discussing questions of guilt." At the extraordinary general meeting of the Hastedter Bulten small garden association on March 29, several discussion participants expressed disappointment and anger at the absence of the dike captain at the beginning of the events. The association chairman Ludwig Meyer criticized the "human inability" and the failure to put the defective weir structure back into operation in time. Already in January, the authorities should have ensured a regulated drainage of the Upper Weser through the Werdersee channel as a compensatory measure. "Hanoverian merchant's stinginess" had also prevented the Deichschartweg from being designed as a bridge. They had saved in the wrong place, as the summer dike at the Werder Bridge could only have broken and caused the violent backflow into the Weser because the water that had actually flowed further in the intended flood channel had been backed up by the reinforced Deichschart dam. Meyer summarized: "The Werdersee has not passed its first stress test." Anyone who blames the small gardeners must also hold accountable those who granted building permits for Hastedter Bulten. Likely encouraged by Meyer in his opinion, Johann Dreyer brought the topic up again at a meeting of the Neustadt local council on May 6. At the public meeting of the Obervieland local council on June 11, Meyer renewed his criticism: The dike chart path dam, which additionally dammed the floodwater, and the winter dike bend at the Werder Bridge were the results of "catastrophic planning errors." It was possible that a merely makeshift flood drainage had been designed out of frugality. During the meeting, members of the Fresenbulten small garden association also expressed concern about being affected by future floods. The safety of their gardens was already at risk during the next summer storm surge. Due to the commissioning of the sluice works at Lesum, Hunte, and Ochtum not even two years prior, the Weser water could rise significantly higher than before and reach the garden sheds unhindered through the (not yet closed at the time of the meeting) damage site at the Werder Bridge. However, chief building officer Winfried Reiner from the Water and Shipping Office gave them little hope for a quick remedy. The restoration of a flood-proof dike, both for Middle Weser floods and for storm surges from the opposite direction, would cost four million marks. This expenditure could only be justified if the model tests yielded corresponding results. Furthermore, Reiner countered criticism of an allegedly too-late repair of the Weser weir. They should have immediately begun repairs after the defect in November 1980, but could only work until Christmas because then winter and the high water level thwarted any further activity at the weir for safety reasons. He further expressed the suspicion that the Bulten with the small garden areas would likely have been flooded during the March flood even with a fully intact weir.

This page is a verified version Accuracy verified The flood of 1775 devastated Pest, Buda, and Vác on February 15, destroying a total of 611 residential buildings. After the flood, the Vác embankment was built between today's Nyugati Square and Lehel Square, the Soroksár dam, which extended from Boráros Square to Haller Street, and the so-called frost dam along the line of today's Közraktár Street to Fővám Square.
This page is a verified version Accuracy checked The 1821 Makó flood was the overflow of the Maros River out of its bed in Makó and the surrounding area.

Makó was located directly next to the river before the regulation of the Maros. Since the 1800s, the idea of creating a new riverbed further away from the town had been continuously raised; the most dangerous section was considered to be the winding bends between the Makó timber market and Kiszombor. Surveyor József Vertics prepared a regulation plan in 1814, but it was thwarted due to the resistance of Károly Oexel, the landowner of Kiszombor: the owner did not want to hear about cuts through his lands. In 1815, royal navigation engineer Fábián Dániel Őry, sent to the site, proposed cutting through three bends of the Maros. In 1816, a committee of experts, led by royal commissioner Miklós Vay, navigated the Maros. As a result of the inspection, in November of that year, the governor's council ordered the commencement of river regulation works, but the digging of the new riverbed was interrupted due to lack of financial support. In 1820, Mihály Buday prepared a new regulation plan, but the city also did not receive financial support for its implementation. The well-known fortune teller of the Makó area, Teknyőkaparó, repeatedly predicted the impending destruction. He foretold things like: "Soon they will see, the flood is coming quickly. It will destroy man, animal, and tree." "A flood is coming upon us so great that on Száraz Street, Barna the fisherman will catch catfish."

Oexel Károly's stubbornness and the treasury's stinginess ultimately took their toll: in 1821, the greatest flood of all time struck Makó and the surrounding settlements. In the two weeks leading up to the flood, continuous flood protection work was carried out; nevertheless, on July 2, 1821, the river flooded Apátfalva and Csanád, then broke its way towards the city near the forests of Csipkés and Szugoly. At the same time, the levee broke at Kakás; the rushing flood could only collect a small part of it from the Mikócsai and Margitai streams. Once they were full, the flood washed away the Dali and Margitai bridges, inundated Belsőnyomás and the Jángor meadow. Although the above-mentioned outskirts were submerged, on that day the inner city of Makó was still not underwater. The river continued to rise, and on the morning of July 3, it broke through the levee section at Szentlőrinc. First, it flooded the vineyards, and then within a few hours, it flooded the city itself. By 9 a.m., almost the entire city was underwater. After that, the city was surrounded by the Maros for nearly a week; the troubles of the locals, stranded far from their lands, were alleviated by aid packages and donations sent by the residents of Hódmezővásárhely and Szeged, which were delivered to Makó by boats. The damage in the city and vineyards exceeded 270,000 forints. One-third of the residential houses were damaged or collapsed; 10,600 quintals of salt dissolved in the salt barns, which exceeded the half-year salt requirement of the area belonging to the Makó salt house.

As a result of the flood in 1821, 4-5 million grapevines were cut down. Their place was taken by vegetable gardens, where large-scale onion cultivation began. Thus, after the flood, the size of the vineyards shrank to a fraction, but the world-renowned and beloved Makó onion, the city's most famous landmark, was created. The flood provided an opportunity to organize the streets and squares of Makó: at the instruction of Bishop László Kőszeghy of Csanád, surveyor Antal Giba, the designer of the town hall, prepared a partial planning scheme for the area around the Reformed Old Church after the water receded, and the streets of the Jewish quarter were straightened according to the plans of Ferenc Fejérváry, with the plots proportionally measured.

This page is a verified version Accuracy verified The flood of 1838 was the most devastating natural disaster in the history of Esztergom, with seventy percent of the buildings in the royal city collapsing.

A huge amount of snow fell in the upper section of the Danube, and the river froze at Visegrád as early as December 1837. Following the spring thaw, the Danube could not recede. According to a contemporary description by city councilor József Helischer, on March 5, the lower streets of the city were already flooded with water. On March 6, despite efforts to defend against it, the icy flood broke through the dikes, and by the 8th, everything in the city center, except for the area around the Franciscan church, was submerged. The water level continued to rise until March 13, "surpassing even that of 1809 by five feet, flooding the entire inner city." "The Captain's Office promptly announced and proclaimed with drumroll that everyone should transport their movable property and livestock to a safe place, carry their fodder to the road next to the upper hemp fields, and reinforce their houses exposed to flooding. It was also communicated to millers, fishermen, and timber merchants to keep their barges, boats, and rafts ready for use in case of necessity." The flood lasted until March 14, that is, for nine days. Some residents left the city; they fled to higher places such as Szenttamás, Szentgyörgymező, and cellars, wine houses, or cemeteries in the surrounding mountains. The Franciscan monastery provided shelter and assistance to 760 people. However, on March 12, water also penetrated the church and the monastery, forcing everyone to leave the building, which suffered significant damage. The crypt remained underwater for days, the walls loosened, and the church, which became life-threatening, could only be restored to a condition safe for worshippers with the support of benefactors in 1857.

As the danger slowly increased, there were no casualties among people or cattle. Out of the 853 houses in the city, 614 completely collapsed, leaving only 150 somewhat intact. The collapse of the houses was facilitated by the fact that residents had moved their furniture to the attics, which the walls could no longer support. During this time, the relief center of the city of Esztergom was set up in the economic office of the cathedral chapter. The building now houses the Danube Museum. After the water receded, the damage was estimated at one and a half million forints. The government sent Pethőfalvi Uzovich János, the deputy governor, who began the restoration on the 16th. During the reconstruction, schools and barracks were given priority. The House of the Aged, which had been operating on the main road for 120 years, also became unusable, and the institution had to leave its old location. János Packh, who led the construction of the Basilica, prepared plans for a new hospital free of charge at the corner of Csillag Street and Hosszú Row, which opened its doors a year and a half later. A new plan was developed for the regulation of the streets, and Esztergom received a loan of one hundred thousand forints from the government for the reconstruction.
