Whole_Text.content: A great flood occurred in the Hungarian kingdom in 1838, which particularly affected present-day Budapest.

Earlier in 1775, a flood occurred, which led to the construction of dikes to protect primarily the cities of Vác, Buda, (then independent) Óbuda, and Pest (city). In the early months of 1838, a full ice cover covered the Danube, and at that time, a lot of precipitation fell. In early March in Vienna, the ice was already floating. The first danger occurred in Vác, where despite the dike, a flood happened. This was repeated in Pest on March 13, but only part of the city was under water. Many believed that the flood could not spread. The river built a dike with ice just after the cities of Buda and Pest, but soldiers constantly fired cannons at the dike. This maneuver was unsuccessful. On the 14th, the level reached the record set in 1775, and rescue efforts began. The residents partially took refuge in churches, which were very stable. In contrast, the houses began to collapse. 50,000 people became homeless. On the 15th, the remaining dikes could no longer protect the houses, and a catastrophic flood occurred. The most notable helper was Baron Miklós Wesselényi, who saved people sitting on rooftops by boat. (After the flood, all Hungarians added the epithet "the flood sailor" to Miklós Wesselényi. On that day, in some places, nearly 3 meters deep waters were measured. In Pest, 2,281 houses were destroyed, 827 houses were damaged, and 1,146 houses remained untouched. In the opposite Buda, 204 houses were destroyed, 262 houses were damaged, and 2,023 houses remained untouched. In summary, in the Kingdom of Hungary, 10,000 houses were destroyed, and 4,000 houses were damaged. In total, 153 people died, of which 151 lived in Pest. When Franz Liszt learned about the flood, he immediately traveled to Vienna and organized 8 concerts, the proceeds of which helped the homeless. After the flood, new dikes were built, and the new houses became more stable. At that time, Újpest was founded. The next flood occurred in 1876, but the dikes defended the then newly established city of Budapest (although some damage occurred in Buda and Óbuda). During the suppression of the Habsburgs, memorial plaques were placed regarding the water level at that time, but it is mentioned that the mentioned day, March 15, reminded Hungarians of the Hungarian Revolution of 1848, and not of the flood in 1838.
This page is a verified version Accuracy checked The great flood of spring 1970 was the overflow of the Maros River out of its bed in Makó and the surrounding area.

The year 1970 was rich in precipitation, with the first-level flood protection alert declared on January 6 and the third-level on February 2. In the city's deepest area, in the Honvéd district, which already struggled with social and infrastructural deficiencies, and in much of the surrounding arable land, groundwater, rainwater, and melting snow simultaneously caused problems. In January, 21 families were evacuated from the Lesi district, located between the Békéscsaba–Kétegyháza–Mezőhegyes–Újszeged railway line and the flood protection embankment. On May 12, 100 millimeters of precipitation fell in the Maros watershed area within 48 hours, triggering an unprecedented flood wave in Transylvania, in the upper section of the river.

On May 16, 1970, 398 centimeters were measured at the Makó section of the Maros River; a day later, a third-level flood protection alert was ordered, and a city defense committee was formed. Water was increasingly seeping through the saturated and soaked levees, and at the border of Makó, water overflowed from several channels, with the water from the Sámson-Apátfalvi channel being backed up by the Maros River ten kilometers away. On May 19, massive forces were assembled in the city, at which point the receding flood wave reached the Hungarian-Romanian border. The Maros River peaked at 624 centimeters on May 20, 1970, at 10 PM, while a large amount of water burst forth from a spring group (spring water on the protected side of the levee) four kilometers from the city. During the critical hours, full mobilization was ordered, and the city was defended by 56 engineers, 92 technicians, 178 water management professionals, the Makó fire department, 2,600 civilians, two military units, a Soviet military unit, a technical battalion, as well as one law enforcement unit, a 120-member police unit, a civil defense unit, a workers' militia, and a Red Cross battalion.

The Flood and Inland Flood Protection Regional Committee (ÁTB) decided on May 21, one day after the river peaked, to evacuate the then 32,000 residents of Makó, as well as Maroslele, Földeák, and Óföldeák, considering the effects of the flood, the paralyzing downpour, and the risk of dam failure, in order to avoid a potential mass disaster. In the event of a dam failure, the lowest parts of the city would be covered by four meters of water, while the highest point would be submerged by two meters. A total of 18,000 people were evacuated from the four municipalities and surrounding farms in a single night, most of whom – 16,000 individuals – were relocated to Hódmezővásárhely, but Szentes and several other municipalities also took in refugees. The measures, carried out with great organization and exemplary discipline, mark an important milestone in the technical history of flood defense. This was the largest evacuation in all of Europe to date. The evacuees were able to return to their homes on July 3, after the immediate danger had passed.

After the flood wave receded, the damages and the costs of evacuation were assessed on June 10, amounting to over 294 million forints. To encourage reconstruction, the government provided long-term construction loans, and the Hungarian Red Cross distributed aid to the affected for several years. The banks of the Maros River were raised by an average of 1-1.5 meters, and their foundations were widened. The flood marked a turning point: upon the river's return to its bed, the then-government saw it as the right time to develop the settlement—up until then, the proximity of the Yugoslav border and the predominance of individual farming had excluded the area from development policy. The reconstruction of the main square was carried out, and several larger residential estates were created. Although delayed, industrial development also began, exclusively establishing subsidiaries of national and county factories.

The Heinrich flood or July high water, also known as Black Friday of Waldeck, refers to the flood disaster that struck North Hesse, South Lower Saxony, and East Westphalia, as well as parts of the present-day federal states of Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, and Saxony, following severe storms on July 15 and 16, 1965. A total of 16 people died in the subsequent flooding caused by extreme heavy rainfall, three of them in the GDR. Damage amounted to hundreds of millions of DM and DDR marks. The catchment areas of the Twiste and Diemel rivers, the town of Bad Karlshafen located at the mouth of the Diemel, the catchment area of the Lippe and the Altenau, where seven people died, as well as the Ilme were particularly hard hit. The present-day districts of Göttingen, Holzminden, and Kassel were also severely affected. Significant damage occurred in the city centers of Paderborn, Lippstadt, and Kassel. In the GDR, the districts of Erfurt, Suhl, Gera, Karl-Marx-Stadt, Leipzig, Dresden, and Halle were heavily impacted.

The Heinrich flood of July 1965 occurred at a time when modern information technology and the methodology of hydrology and meteorology were still in their infancy. There were no weather satellites, and the responsible authorities operated on a national level; international networking was only rudimentary. Particularly for smaller rivers and streams, the runoff behavior in flood situations was completely unknown. In many places, there were no gauges. Sudden weather deteriorations or a sudden rise in water levels could often only be recognized when it was already too late for timely warnings to the population. Communication means were limited to analog techniques in the form of telephones, teletypes, and radio. Notices, newspapers, air raid sirens, and loudspeaker vehicles from the police and fire department served as a link between the authorities and the population. Television and radio broadcast only limited programs for a few hours a day. Ongoing programs were often taken over by other German broadcasters and were very difficult to change or interrupt. Another problematic aspect was that even in the 1960s, the power supply in residential areas, both in rural and urban areas, was provided through overhead lines. If they were damaged by lightning or storms, it led to widespread, prolonged power outages – further reducing the possibilities for remote communication. Under such conditions, the population could only be warned by loudspeaker vehicles from the police and fire department or by officials going door to door. If power and telephone connections were interrupted and access routes were impassable, only rescue measures could be initiated.

After an unusually wet and cold spring and summer, warm air masses from the subtropics flowed north in mid-July 1965, where they met cold Scandinavian air masses. This resulted in the formation of a so-called cold air drop on the back of the incoming warm air over northern France, which caused the very moist warm air to be completely surrounded by cold air. The warm air glided over the cold air, leading to severe thunderstorms with torrential rainfall. Already in the late evening hours of July 15, severe storms with torrential rain occurred in the Einbeck area, leading to widespread flooding. Due to the situation, the authorities responsible for disaster protection in the then district of Einbeck were forced to issue a disaster alarm at 8:45 PM, three-quarters of an hour after the storm began. In the following hours, the precipitation area, which was accompanied by severe thunderstorms, moved further west and also led to thundery precipitation in the area of the later disaster zone. In the morning hours of July 16, severe storms began in the Stadtoldendorf/Heinade/Mackensen area, which led to a worsening of the flood situation in the Ilme area. The storms moved off to the west with reinforcement and reached the Paderborn/Warburg area around noon. From 12:00 PM, almost complete darkness over the Paderborn highlands, the Warburg Börde, and the Waldecker Tafelland saw about two hours of torrential and thundery rainfall over an area limited in the west by the Rothaargebirge and in the east by the Eggegebirge and Reinhardswald, which slowly shifted eastward, weakening, until it reached the Einbeck/Göttingen area in the evening hours. During the storm, rainfall amounts of over 100 mm were recorded at weather stations in an area between Paderborn in the north, Brilon in the southwest, and Warburg and Hofgeismar in the east, as well as in the Kassel and Fritzlar area, most of which fell within a two-hour period. In the area between Paderborn and Höxter in the north, as well as Warburg and Hofgeismar in the south, there was about 200 mm of rainfall over 72 hours between July 14 and July 17, and in Dalheim, even over 200 mm in 24 hours. During this time, maximum rainfall intensities of up to 4.5 mm/minute were recorded. Further severe storms particularly worsened the situation in the following days, especially in the Kassel and Hannoversch Münden areas.

In the catchment area of the Diemel and the Twiste as well as the Lippe and Altenau, the rainfall could no longer be absorbed by the already saturated soils; likewise, the underground cave systems typical of karst landscapes were already so filled beforehand that a catastrophic runoff event occurred. Due to the surface runoff and the erupting karst springs in the area of the Paderborn high plateau, as well as in the area of Stadtoldendorf and Heinade in the Holzminden district, previously unobserved water levels were reached in the rivers and streams within a very short time. The erupting karst springs on the slopes of the typical box valleys of karst landscapes and the high intensity of the rainfall led to large amounts of water not only flooding into the villages from the rivers but also flowing down directly from the mountain slopes as flash floods. In unfavorable slope areas, numerous mudslides occurred. Retaining structures such as road embankments, too small bridges and culverts, as well as field walls and even pasture fences that held back the debris led to temporarily even higher water levels. Due to the extreme rainfall on water-saturated soil, there was a rapid rise in water levels in streams and rivers in the rainfall area. Depending on the size of the catchment area, the possibility of overflow, and the capacity of the riverbed, maximum water levels were reached shortly after the midday storms subsided. At the Schmittwasser, a flow of 15.4 m³/s was recorded on July 16 at 1:57 PM, and at the Ellerbach, a flow of 20.6 m³/s was recorded at 2:38 PM. In Paderborn, on July 16, the flow at the Pader gauge was 47.3 m³/s, which is almost ten times the average flow. At the Pader spring, it took until the end of August for the values to normalize. This extreme flow led to widespread flooding in the urban area. The Altenau brought a flood wave to the Lippe, which caused flooding up to the mouth of the Lippe. The flow at the Lippe gauges was ten times the five-year average. The gauge of the Diemel at its mouth in Bad Karlshafen rose by 5 meters within a few hours in the morning of July 17. In Eberschütz, which was hit by the flood peak during the night from July 16 to 17, the Diemel swelled so quickly that the town was flooded within half an hour. At the gauge on the upper reaches of the Diemel in Westheim near Marsberg, the flow on July 16 was 225 cubic meters per second (average 1954/2006: 5.26 m³/s). In Helmarshausen near Bad Karlshafen on the lower reaches of the Diemel, the flow even reached 820 cubic meters per second, while the normal flow here is about 10.4 m³/s. The flood wave of the Diemel led to a water level in the Weser at Bad Karlshafen that exceeded the summer flood of 1956. However, the flood peak of the Weser flattened significantly along its course to the Weser dam in Bremen-Hastedt and was no longer noticeable at the tide gauges of the Weser below Bremen, unlike the July flood of 1956. At the gauges of Fulda and Eder, the situation remained relaxed despite the extreme rainfall, as the water level of the Edersee had already been lowered several days earlier. Thus, the partially drained reservoir could absorb and store 29 million cubic meters of water that flowed in from the heavy rainfall in the catchment area of the upper reaches of the Eder.

The starting point for many very severe damages were numerous damming structures. These included the small dams built at the many water mills at that time, as well as outdated road bridges and culverts that were not designed for such loads and were heavily damaged or destroyed. In the settlements, the river cross-sections were greatly constricted by installations and were therefore unable to accommodate the water masses coming from the upper reaches. The large debris carried along proved to be very dangerous, blocking culverts and bridges. The stone arch or vaulted bridges that were common in the region at that time were particularly vulnerable, with 40 of them in the catchment area of Alme, Altenau, and Lippe being destroyed or so severely damaged that they had to be replaced by new constructions. The flood waves, some of which were meters high, resulting from dam breaks destroyed or severely damaged numerous massive bridges, thereby interrupting regional road connections as well as power and telephone lines. Field walls built across the valley cross-section or near the banks also proved to be a cause of high flood waves, as they could not withstand the high water pressure over time. The collapse of the medieval monastery wall in Dalheim, the break of a road dam at Wrexen, the break of the medieval city wall at the Esse culvert in Grebenstein, and the collapse of a wall that dammed the floodwater in Etteln led to meter-high flood waves that occurred completely unexpectedly for the population and rushed down the valley. Severe damage occurred on agricultural land where grassland in floodplain locations had been converted into arable land, as well as in areas where river straightening had taken place as part of land improvement measures. There, not only were there severe damages to the banks, but also, as at the Dalbach below Oesdorf near Westheim, the river course was reverted to the old riverbed. Banks consisting only of individual trees were also severely damaged. There were significant bank collapses, severe scouring, and deepening of the riverbeds of rivers and streams. In the district of Paderborn alone, 24 road bridges were destroyed. Above damming road dams, there were large deposits of silt and gravel. Over-siltation also led to severe damage on agricultural land, which was deposited there by the layer floods and debris flows rushing down from the slopes of the valley. These floods had a similar character, depending on the slope inclination, to what is observed in alpine torrents. The German geologist Ecke von Zezschwitz, who was in the disaster area during the storm, witnessed a layer flood about 1.5 km long and several hundred meters wide at Elisenhof. On the slopes of the valley, there were many large landslides, and in unfavorable locations, entire old forest stands slid down, for example, in the forest areas near Blankenrode. In some areas, due to the special geological structure of the karst as well as the slope and soil conditions, badlands were formed. In the Minstal located about 1.5 km southeast of Etteln between Donnerberg and Ettlerberg, a 1.5 km long and up to 5 m deep erosion channel was washed out, reaching into the rock. Not only loose material but also large rock material was washed out of this channel. A cloudburst is assumed to be the cause, during which a rainfall amount of over 150 mm fell in a very short time.

In the catchment area of the Diemel and its tributaries, the towns of Wrexen, Grebenstein, Helmarshausen, Trendelburg, and Bad Karlshafen were particularly hard hit. A significant damage hotspot was located in Wrexen. After 156 mm of rainfall fell in Rhoden in a very short time and immediately flowed into the Rhodener Bach, which drains into the Diemel, the water masses accumulated in front of the bridge located in the road embankment of the federal highway 252, which was not designed for such a flood, rising so high that the embankment was flooded. The excessively steep outer slope gave way under the now overflowing water masses, and the dam broke over a length of 80 meters. As a result of the dam break, the previously accumulated water masses suddenly poured into the areas below the dam. On their way down, three water mills and their associated buildings were caught by a four-meter-high tidal wave and severely damaged or destroyed. On the way to the Diemel, the massive road bridge along Ramser Straße in Wrexen was completely washed away. Numerous houses and businesses were severely damaged, and building debris and agricultural equipment were transported over long distances. In Wrexen, a woman lost her life during the storm. She was in a house that was hit by a mudslide. The bridge over the Diemel along federal highway 7 near Warburg was destroyed by the flood. This interrupted an important regional road connection between Kassel and Paderborn at the time. At the Immenhausen train station on the Kassel–Warburg railway line, hundreds of passengers of the Deutsche Bundesbahn were stranded, as the line was no longer passable due to the flooding of the station in Grebenstein. In Grebenstein, the Esse, a tributary of the Diemel, carried logs from a sawmill upstream to the city wall. The river, initially dammed by the floating debris made of long wood, then caused part of the city wall to collapse at the entrance of the Esse at the Hilte, after which the water suddenly poured into the city center in the form of a meter-high tidal wave, causing severe damage along with the carried logs. In Helmarshausen, over 100 people were trapped by the rapidly rising water of the Diemel. They could only be rescued with the help of helicopters. There was one fatality during the rescue. There were also severe damages from flooding in Trendelburg and Bad Karlshafen. The entire historic old town of Bad Karlshafen was flooded several meters high. The water level of the flood exceeded that of 1956 on the Weser. Debris and animal carcasses were transported as far as Hameln.

Whole_Text.header: Catchment area of Lippe, Alme, and Altenau
Whole_Text.content: The area most affected was the catchment area of the Lippe and its tributary Alme. The focus was on the Paderborn high plateau with the towns of Etteln and Borchen along the Altenau (Alme). In Etteln, 200 people were trapped by rapidly rising floodwaters, and 7 residents were killed, including 4 children, after a field wall that had initially kept the water of the Altenau away from the town gave way under the pressure of the water masses. After the wall broke, a two-meter-high tidal wave suddenly poured into the village. Four people, including three children, were swept away from a residential house and drowned. Many of the residents of Etteln, who were in life-threatening situations, could only be rescued from their homes by helicopters or heavy military equipment. In Schloss Neuhaus, two people lost their lives in the flood. Here, the bridge over the Alme was destroyed as part of the federal highway 64 after it became blocked with debris. The flood wave of the Alme, as well as the rainfall that could no longer be managed by the rainwater drainage system, flooded parts of downtown Paderborn, where some streets were flooded up to one meter high. Severe damage occurred in the flooded houses in the city center and in shops and businesses. Severe flooding also occurred in Schwaney, where the entire town center was flooded, and in Lipperode. In Lippstadt, the city center was flooded up to one meter high. Numerous important buildings, including both hospitals, were also no longer accessible to emergency services. Flooding also occurred further along the Lippe in the areas of Hamm, Haltern am See, and Dorsten; however, no residential areas were affected, as the Lippe dikes controlled by the responsible authorities held against the floodwaters.

In the valley of the Schede, there were severe damages in Volkmarshausen, where a felt factory was flooded and its stock was washed away. Here, as well as in the other disaster areas, completely clogged drainage ditches caused major problems.

The places Mackensen, Einbeck, and Dassel were flooded at the Ilme. The Spüligbach had brought a flood wave of previously unknown height from the karst areas in Hellental and from Holzberg. A landslide at Bierberg near Dassel caused the failure of telecommunications facilities.

Whole_Text.header: River basins of Fulda and Werra
Whole_Text.content: Landslides and flooding interrupted numerous train connections. In the Kassel area, rail traffic on the Kassel–Eichenberg line was halted on the section between Kassel and Hannoversch Münden and Kassel and Waldkappel due to landslides. In Kassel, traffic on some main roads came to a standstill because the drainage system was not designed to handle such large amounts of rainfall in a very short time. A campsite on the Fulda River in Hannoversch Münden was evacuated as a precaution. In Wilhelmshausen near Reinhardswald, a flood wave carrying large debris and gravel from a stream coming from Gahrenberg flooded parts of the town. Here, as well as elsewhere, bridges were blocked with debris, severely hindering drainage.

Neighboring areas of the former GDR were also affected by severe storms, such as in Großengottern and Torgau. A total of three people lost their lives. Intense thunderstorms on July 16, 1965, particularly affected Thuringia and the western Ore Mountains, leading to precipitation amounts of up to 75 l/m² there.

Due to the catastrophic rainfall in the midday and early afternoon hours and the rapidly swelling rivers and streams, the responsible authorities declared a disaster alarm. This led to the deployment of thousands of civilian and military helpers. In addition to the local fire departments, the Red Cross, church aid services, the police, and the Technical Relief Agency, soldiers from the Bundeswehr as well as the British Rhine Army stationed in Detmold, Hameln, and Senne were involved. While in Lower Saxony the disaster plans established after the weather disasters of August 1955 and June 1961 in the Leine area, as well as the July flood of 1956 on the Leine, Aller, and Weser rivers, were implemented and more severe impacts were prevented by a centrally coordinated deployment of rescue forces, the disaster response in the affected North Rhine-Westphalian regions proved to be inadequate. During the cleanup operations, the then North Rhine-Westphalian Interior Minister Willi Weyer had to admit serious deficiencies in disaster protection. Due to a lack of coordination among the rescue forces, there were initially significant problems with the rescue measures. Military units from the Bundeswehr as well as Belgian, Dutch, and British military units stationed in the region set out on their own after the responsible local commanders recognized the existence of a catastrophic emergency. Other rescue units such as the fire department, THW, and Red Cross were unaware of these operations. The complete collapse of the telecommunications network and the absence of radios had particularly devastating effects. The responsible authorities of the districts had to send messengers in some areas to warn the municipal administrations in the affected areas. These reached the affected areas only after hours in some cases. In the particularly hard-hit municipality of Etteln, the Technical Operations Center set up by the municipal administration had only a single radio. Significant problems were caused by the numerous destroyed bridges and the local, regional, and interregional roads that were impassable even for high-wheeled emergency vehicles. This meant that in some cases, long detours were necessary to reach the sites of operations. The inadequate equipment of the rescue teams prevented the rescue of those trapped in many places. At the Kuhlemühle Küting near Ossendorf, the Bundeswehr's attempt to rescue eight people and several children with a helicopter not designed for this situation failed. In Etteln, a woman and a child fell from the makeshift rescue rope attached to the helicopter. Some people sat on the roofs of their houses in the flood area for 17 hours. A woman also lost her life during a failed rescue operation by a helicopter at the Diemel. Below the Wrexer Pond between Wrexen and Rhoden, where a catastrophic flood wave occurred after the break of a road dam, a dramatic rescue operation took place. The people trapped in the mill building threatened with collapse, including two children, could not be rescued from the air because the helicopters in operation were only equipped with ropes that were too short, making it impossible to reach those trapped. Louiza Ramus, a citizen of Wrexen, who, along with sport diver Horst Richard Platt, rescued the trapped individuals from the building, was honored for her selfless act in December 1965 by the then Hessian Prime Minister Georg August Zinn with the Rescue Medal of the State of Hesse.

Whole_Text.header: Investigations and measures after the flood

Whole_Text.content: Already a few weeks after the disaster, extensive investigations into the course and the damage caused by the flooding were initiated. Noteworthy are the investigations by geologist and then director of the Geological State Office of North Rhine-Westphalia in Krefeld, Herbert Karrenberg, "Precipitation Intensity and Erosion in the Karst Area of Paderborn during the Storm of July 16, 1965," the work of geologist Ecke von Zezschwitz "Soil and Vegetation Influences on Flooding and Erosion during the Storm of July 16, 1965 in the Area of the Paderborn Plateau" (1967), as well as the report "Flood-Related Landscape Damage in the Catchment Area of the Altenau and its Tributaries" by Walter Mrass, with contributions from Wilhelm Lohmeyer and Gerhard Olschowy, prepared by the then Federal Institute for Vegetation Science, Nature Conservation, and Landscape Management on behalf of the Landschaftsverband Westfalen-Lippe. Of particular importance is the work of Ecke von Zezschwitz, as he experienced the storm firsthand and made detailed observations as an experienced geologist, which could be incorporated into both his work and that of Herbert Karrenberg. In the investigation by Mrass, Lohmeyer, and Olschowy, the focus was primarily on the damage that occurred outside of settlement areas. They found that river sections whose banks were lined with a closed tree stand, preferably consisting of ashes and willows, withstood this extreme flood without significant damage. This applied to both flat banks and erosion-prone undercut banks. The ash tree proved to be optimal, as its dense root system stabilized the bank so that the water masses could not wash away the loose material at the bank. In certain areas, Mrass, Lohmeyer, and Olschowy also found that stands of perennials, especially nettles, were extremely effective in protecting the banks during the Heinrich flood. The nettles anchored the bank substrate with their extensive root system, and the plants lay down on the bank bottom with the strong current, thus preventing erosion. In sections with sparse tree cover along the banks and those without any tree cover, the heaviest damage occurred according to Mrass, Lohmeyer, and Olschowy. This was particularly true for river sections where grassland use extended right up to the bank. A destroyed grass sward due to livestock trampling in the area of watering places greatly favored bank destruction. Similarly, fencing had a very negative impact. Dam structures, especially bridges and culverts with insufficient flow capacity, promoted bank collapses and the formation of deep pools below the structures. River sections consisting of single trees or small groups of trees also suffered severe damage. Unlike a closed tree cover along the bank, here the vortices intensified the effect of the strongly turbulent floodwaters. There was a very strong formation of pools, and the trees standing on the bank were uprooted, subsequently creating obstacles in front of culverts and bridges as driftwood. This driftwood not only worsened the situation in front of dam structures, such as bridges and culverts, but also caused pasture fences to develop a damming effect on the floodwaters due to the accumulating driftwood.

Following the July flood of 1965, flood protection and the system of water associations in the affected areas were restructured. To prevent similar events, significant interventions were made in river management. This included the straightening, deepening, and channeling of riverbeds, widening of bridge cross-sections, and the creation of large retention basins, such as in the catchment area of the Alme near Husen-Dalheim and at its tributary, the Sauer near Sudheim and Ebbinghausen. The Aabach dam near Bad Wünnenberg, which had been planned before World War II, was also tailored to flood protection needs, creating additional storage options in the event of flooding in the Aabach catchment area. In the jurisdiction of the water association Obere Lippe, founded in 1971, 23 flood retention basins were built. There were also significant interventions in the Diemel catchment area in the form of river straightening and the construction of dikes. At the Twiste, the previously planned but repeatedly discarded Twistesee was constructed in the first half of the 20th century to improve flood protection. In Lower Saxony, measures had already been initiated following the storm disaster of August 1955, the flooding of the Weser, Aller, and Leine in July 1956, and the June flood in southern Hanover, as well as the flood disaster of 1962 on the North Sea coast. These included, among other things, an improvement in disaster protection, a fundamental reform of the partially centuries-old water association law, and above all, the establishment of the Aller-Leine-Oker plan. By the time of the Heinrich flood, the planning processes for the construction of flood protection structures in Lower Saxony were already in full swing.

Although the Heinrich flood caused a stir in the national press, it is largely forgotten today outside the affected areas. Due to the narrowly defined disaster area, it remains overshadowed by the storm surge of 1962 on the German North Sea coast, Hurricane Quimburga in 1972, and the catastrophic floods on the Oder in 1997 and the Elbe in 2002 and 2013. However, in many places, flood marks still attached to buildings serve as a reminder of the event. Commemorative events are regularly held on the anniversaries of the disaster. The regional press and regional magazines of the West German Broadcasting also remember the anniversaries of the disaster. For the 40th anniversary of the Heinrich flood, Osnabrück Bishop Franz-Josef Bode visited Etteln, where he witnessed the disaster as a teenager. For the 50th anniversary, a stele was erected in Etteln in July 2015.

Heinrich's flood was called the event because in Catholic-influenced regions, the Heinrich Festival is traditionally celebrated on the second weekend of July, which commemorates Heinrich II, among others, the founder of the Diocese of Bamberg.

Throughout history, there have been numerous floods in Hanover. One of the oldest protective measures is the construction of the Schneller Graben mentioned in 1449. The worst flooding in Hanover occurred in 1946 shortly after World War II.

The Leine flood in Hanover was part of the Weser flood of 1946. The peak of the catastrophic intensification of a flood situation occurred in the catchment areas of the Weser from February 2 to 11, 1946. After a winter frost period, a thaw began on January 28, 1946. Neither the frost-induced impermeability of the soils in January 1946 nor the snowmelt in the Harz that began at the end of January 1946 played as significant a role in the catastrophic extent of the February flood as in previous extreme floods in the Hanover area. The unusual heavy rainfall in early February 1946 was responsible for the disaster. As a result, on February 10, 1946, the largest flood disaster in the city of Hanover occurred. The rivers Leine and Ihme, as well as the Maschsee, overflowed their banks. This was exacerbated by the natural narrowing of the 900-meter-wide flow area of the Ihme at Waterlooplatz to 400 meters at the Glocksee Bridge. Additionally, around 700,000 gasoline canisters were washed ashore from a British depot at the Schützenplatz Hanover, further blocking the water flow under the bridges. Consequently, 1,666 hectares were flooded to a height of 3 meters, including the districts of Altstadt, Calenberger Neustadt, Südstadt, Linden, and Ricklingen. The water level of the Leine in Herrenhausen rose to 6.44 meters, a level that has not been reached since. This water level is considered a once-in-a-century flood for the city of Hanover. The flood claimed three lives and caused significant property damage. After the flood, there was uncontrolled removal of historical documents in the Hanover city archive, which were burned for heating in the winter, resulting in the loss of 80% of the city's 19th-century historical records.

Already in the 1950s, extensive safety measures were taken, especially in dike construction. As a result of climate change and to defend against possible extreme weather events, construction measures were carried out between 2010 and 2013 along the Ihme at the Peter-Fechter-Ufer near the Ihme-Center. Upstream on the left bank of the Ihme, the existing dike in eastern Ricklingen was extended by one kilometer in 2013 and 2014 with a dike that connects to the south and a flood protection wall at the Michaelis Cemetery. During the renewal of the Benno-Ohnesorg Bridge over the Ihme between 2008 and 2013, the bridge structure was extended to avoid backwater. During the flooding in Central Europe in May and June 2013, the water levels in Hanover were also high, as heavy rainfall occurred in the catchment area of the Leine. In the floodplain of the Leine in the Stöcken district, a woman died on May 30, 2013, after being swept away by the current while crossing a flooded street.

The flood in the Ore Mountains in 1927 occurred in the river basins of Gottleuba and Müglitz in the Ore Mountains. On the night of July 8 to 9, 1927, after several days of rainfall during a Vb weather situation, a thunderstorm front passed through, which caused 113 millimeters of precipitation in the source area of Gottleuba and Müglitz, in the Ore Mountain ridge around Sattelberg, Mückentürmchen, and Geisingberg, within 25 minutes. In Dohna, the flow of the Müglitz reached a value of 330 m³/s, while in the town of Gottleuba, the flow of the Gottleuba even reached 400 m³/s. For comparison: the Elbe reaches an average flow (MQ, referring to the years 1980–2008) of 305 m³/s at the gauge in Schöna. The water masses surprised the residents of the valley settlements during the night hours. There was almost no warning time, resulting in a total of about 160 fatalities, 88 of which were in Berggießhübel alone. Thus, the flood in the Ore Mountains in 1927 is considered one of the most devastating flood disasters in recent German history.

The Ore Mountains, and here especially the catchment areas of Gottleuba, Müglitz, and Weißeritz, are among the classic flood generation areas in Saxony. Since 1560, heavy rainfall with devastating flash floods that caused significant damage and claimed numerous lives has been repeatedly documented. In the Müglitztal alone, eighteen severe flood disasters occurred between 1609 and 2002. According to records, nearly 60 severe floods have occurred in the valleys of Gottleuba and Müglitz in the last 500 years. Among these, the floods of more recent times, namely in the years 1897, 1927, 1957, and 2002, caused particularly devastating destruction. Among these more recent floods, the event of July 8/9, 1927 stands out in a particularly tragic way due to the estimated 160 fatalities.

The origin, course, and consequences of the disaster of July 8/9, 1927, as well as numerous other severe floods in the Ore Mountains, were determined by the complex interplay of precipitation events and regional characteristics.

The location and shape of the Ore Mountains have always favored the formation of orographically induced air mass boundaries and thus the occurrence of high precipitation. Initially multi-day rainfalls have repeatedly developed into torrential downpours in the past, with precipitation totals in the higher elevations reaching extreme values, sometimes close to the limits of what is physically possible. The flood of 1927 was attributed to a Vb weather situation (as were the floods of 1897, 1957, and 2002). In this case, low-pressure areas brought extremely moist and warm air with high precipitation potential along the path from the Mediterranean region to the Polish Baltic coast, which caused strong and prolonged land rain (area-wide precipitation). Since Saxony was caught on the western flank of this low, the air masses were pushed from the north against the Ore Mountains. The blocking effect led to the precipitation of the saturated air masses on the northern side. At the same time, the decreasing movement speed caused a longer stationary stay over the mountains. This resulted in the complete precipitation of convective rainfall with torrential showers and thunderstorms.

The rivers of the Ore Mountains have relatively energy-rich catchment areas. While the source areas of the Müglitz and Gottleuba are located at an altitude of about 700 to 800 meters, the mouths reached after 34 and 49 kilometers of flow length are at an altitude of about 110 meters. Thus, the rivers exhibit a steep gradient with significant height differences in a very small area. As a result, the river valleys have cut steeply and narrowly into the underlying rocks. Natural retention areas, such as larger valley widenings, are hardly present or have been utilized since the mid-19th century for settlement and transportation development. The high gradient and insufficient retention areas lead to high flow velocities of the waters, especially during floods.

The river basins of Gottleuba and Müglitz belonged to the dense forest area before their settlement, which extended from the edge of the Elbe valley widening to the ridge areas and the Bohemian southern slope of the Ore Mountains. At the time of the flood in 1927, however, the source areas of both rivers could be described as low in forest cover. Even today, only about 45% (202 square kilometers) of the approximately 460 square kilometer catchment areas of Müglitz and Gottleuba are forested. The comparatively low forest proportion for a medium mountain range is, among other things, a consequence of the settlement that began in the 12th century. With the land acquisition, the forest landscape in the Eastern Ore Mountains transformed within a few decades into a cultural landscape characterized by villages, towns, fields, and transport routes. This settlement activity led to extensive deforestation, as the consumption of firewood alone in the 16th century was estimated at a minimum of 20 cubic meters per household per year. Additionally, there was consumption for the construction of houses (half-timbering, shingles, etc.) and the production of everyday goods (home furnishings). Even after fires, larger amounts of wood were needed for reconstruction. The total wood consumption of a settler amounted to over 500 kilograms per year by the mid-16th century. The settlement-related demand on the forest was further intensified by iron ore mining in the region around Berggießhübel and Bad Gottleuba and tin mining from Altenberg and Zinnwald. Both mining itself and the smelting industry were existentially dependent on wood as a building material and on charcoal as an energy source. The production of just one kilogram of iron required the use of 29 to 46 kilograms of wood. The required amounts of wood were largely harvested without regard to the regeneration capacity of the forests, leading to their depletion and devastation. The iron ore mining or the iron ore smelting in the central Gottleuba area consumed one to two square kilometers of forest per year during its peak (16th century). The fact is that forests can mitigate the effects of floods. They have an intense and extensive root system that is highly water-conductive and water-retaining. While about 65 to 70 liters of water per square meter can seep into a flat forest floor, only 20 liters can do so on an equally sized pasture. Another part of the precipitation can be retained by the crown canopy and evaporates from there again. In the coniferous forests that prevail in the Eastern Ore Mountains, about 30 to 40% of the precipitation does not reach the ground at all, as it is converted into water vapor by the trees and released back into the atmosphere.

The flood was caused by a thunderstorm front that moved in from the southwest, from Bohemia (the region around Děčín) over the Ore Mountains ridge. At Mückenberg (Komáří hůrka) and Sattelberg (Špičák u Krásného Lesa), it split and rained down in the Müglitz and Gottleuba valleys. Part of this thunderstorm was stopped by the Schneeberg (Děčínský Sněžník) and later poured into the source areas of the Müglitz and Gottleuba. Between 10:00 AM and 11:00 AM, the thunderstorm settled in the Sattelberg area after having hit the town of Schönwald. The Gottleuba, which normally has a width of three meters, widened to 80 to 100 meters. Flood waves formed that crashed into the valleys up to six meters high. The amount of water that fell was estimated at 120 to 150 liters per square meter. In Schönwald (Krásný Les), 209 millimeters of precipitation fell. No further precise data is known, as several measuring stations of the national weather service fell victim to the storm.

The high number of fatalities was primarily due to the rapid rise in water levels, high current speeds, debris flow, and short warning times. Additionally, many people were caught off guard by the second flood wave that broke in around midnight while they were asleep. A particular tragedy arose from the partial annihilation of entire families. However, the exact number of people who lost their lives in the devastating storm cannot be precisely determined to this day, as the number of guests, day-trippers, and workers (who were involved in laying a telephone line towards Vienna, among other things) present on site remains uncertain. Therefore, the literature varies the number of victims between 146 and 158 dead. It seems realistic to assume about 160 victims. The numbers provided below include all flood victims who died in the municipalities, i.e., both residents and guests (spa guests, workers, etc.).

Damage also occurred to tributaries and streams such as the Bahra, the Trebnitz, the Red Water, as well as the Fürstenwälder, Liebenauer, and Hartmannsbacher village stream. The rainfall, which poured down in a very short time, often got dammed up by driftwood at valley constrictions and bridges. This led to the formation of reservoirs up to 8 meters high, which repeatedly broke and further intensified the flooding with tidal waves. The inferno surpassed the severe flooding from July 30/31, 1897, which had occurred only 30 years earlier, by a multiple. Property damage to buildings and infrastructure amounted to over 100 million Reichsmarks. The following places were particularly affected:
In the municipality of Schönwald, 26 houses were severely damaged or destroyed.

On the railway lines from Pirna to Gottleuba and Großcotta, seven and two bridges were completely destroyed, respectively. Between Pirna and Gottleuba, continuous railway traffic was only possible again in September. In the Gottleubatal, ten bridges of the valley road and its connecting roads were severely damaged or completely torn down. The town of Berggießhübel was almost completely destroyed along the Gottleuba.

In the Oelsengrund, a lot of wood and rubble was washed ashore. The water swept away 17 quintals of heavy rock fragments. The Köhler mill (Friedrich Gotthard Köhler) disappeared completely, as did the outbuilding of the Meisel mill. The barn and the side building of the Paust mill and the Clemens mill were also destroyed. The forestry house Haselberg and the Hammergut were almost completely destroyed as well. The connecting road from the Bährmühle to Gottleuba and the bridge to Hartmannsbach no longer exist. Two residents died.

The road from Bährmühle to Bad Gottleuba was completely destroyed. The Zimmermann property with the feed and grain supplies located there was heavily damaged, so it had to be demolished. In the city center, residents had to be evacuated from the upper floors using ladders, as the ground floors of numerous buildings were completely filled with mud. Several buildings collapsed during the flood, while others were so severely damaged that they had to be torn down afterward. This included the Gottleuba school building. The Gottleuba bridges to Helleberg and Giesenstein collapsed under the force of the water masses. In total, there were nine fatalities, including two summer guests. The Gottleuba victims of the disaster were buried on July 12, 1927, in the municipal cemetery.

The storm began with thunder and lightning around 4:00 PM and lasted for about ten hours. By 9:00 PM, heavy rain set in, and by 10:00 PM, the riverbanks were already half a meter underwater. Above the town, water accumulated at the railway bridge of the Gottleubatalbahn, which was blocked by driftwood, rising to seven meters. Around 11:30 PM, the water broke through this barrier and poured over the town as a flood wave two to three meters high, with a flow rate estimated at 400 m³/s, without warning. The Gottleuba left only a field of debris in the center of the town. 15 houses were immediately destroyed, another 22 had to be demolished later, and 23 houses were severely damaged. All roads and bridges in the area were completely destroyed. A food shortage was looming, as, for example, all three master butchers lost their lives, and the grocery stores and bakeries were destroyed. Of the approximately 1,300 residents, 88, including 12 children, lost their lives. In the district of Zwiesel, two buildings were swept away, and a third was so severely damaged that it had to be demolished. Here, seven fatalities were reported.

The mill ditch of the Schmidt & Co mill is destroyed. The power plant and the mill residential house at the Hering sawmill are gone. A rubble heap of four meters was located in the yard of the Bähr mill.

On July 8 at around 8:45 PM, flooding was reported from Gottleuba. At around 2:30 AM, residents were awakened by the fire department's sirens and the calls of "Flood is coming." A hole approximately fifteen meters wide and four meters deep was torn between Carolabad and the former rowing club house. The (partly former) streets that were completely flooded included: Breite Straße (Dohnaische Vorstadt), Dohnaische Straße (Old Town), Gartenstraße, Reichsstraße, Klosterstraße (Westvorstadt), Bahnhofsstraße, Grohmannstraße, Schmiedestraße, Lange Straße, and Rottwerndorfer Straße (South Town). Extensive damage occurred at the former Rottwerndorf manor, which belonged to the city at the time. Rough estimates indicated material damage of 25,000 marks, construction damage of 35,000 to 40,000 marks, and crop damage of 15,000 to 20,000 marks. In the Neundorf district, the floodwaters rose one and a half meters higher than in 1897. The flood wave was temporarily up to three meters high. At around 11:30 PM, the telephone connection to Berggießhübel was interrupted, and the lights went out. Several people were killed in the subsequent flood. The former blacksmith shop and the associated residential building were swept away. Some residents were able to hold onto drifting wood and building materials and thus escaped the flood.

The railway facilities of the Müglitztalbahn, which runs alongside the Müglitz in many sections, were largely destroyed or severely damaged in the section between Lauenstein and Dohna. The evening train standing in Glashütte was swept away by the second flood wave for over 300 meters. In total, the flood destroyed about 20 kilometers of track, while the remaining sections were largely rendered impassable due to scouring, siltation, and the deposition of debris. Of the 28 railway bridges located between Köttewitz and Lauenstein, 24 collapsed. This caused one of the main transport routes in the Eastern Ore Mountains to be out of service for an extended period. For passenger transport, a replacement bus service was established via Dippoldiswalde. Freight transport was also shifted to the road (as far as possible and necessary given the destroyed business locations). The reconstruction of the line resembled a new construction due to the financial and material effort involved. The first section between Heidenau and Köttewitz was able to be put back into operation on July 26, with the remaining sections following gradually: August 15: Lauenstein–Altenberg, August 18: Köttewitz–Weesenstein, October 3: Weesenstein–Häselich, October 13: Häselich–Oberschlottwitz, November 15: Oberschlottwitz–Glashütte. It was not until December 1 that the line was fully operational again. The recommissioning of the "lifeline" of the valley was celebrated enthusiastically in the neighboring communities. At the same time, the severe destruction and the extensive reconstruction measures sparked considerations for converting the narrow-gauge line to standard gauge. The goal of these considerations was to raise the track by up to 15 meters to reduce future flood damage.

The Hammergut Kratzhammer, located at the northern end of Fürstenwalde, was one of the first settlements affected by the Müglitz flood. The masses of water turned the valley into a rubble desert and completely destroyed two houses. Eight people died in one of the two houses.

In Lauenstein, the flood raged as strongly as in Berggießhübel. However, since the center of the town is located on a terrace above the Müglitz and there were no continuous rows of houses along the river in the town, the flood damage was far less dramatic than in the neighboring Gottleubatal. However, the railway facilities located in the valley were severely damaged. Thanks to the efforts of the two railway officials from Lauenstein, the evening train of the Müglitztalbahn was able to be stopped in Glashütte, which likely saved many more lives. However, the two officials themselves perished in the flood.

In the watchmaker town of Glashütte, located at the confluence of the Prießnitz and Müglitz rivers, a flood alarm was triggered around 7:30 PM. Immediately afterwards, the first rapidly advancing flood wave reached the town. However, this only caused material damage. The second flood wave, which reached the town around 11:45 PM, had a significantly more devastating effect. Within a few minutes, the water surged back into the town with great force. The Müglitz, carrying large amounts of debris and driftwood, swelled to 100 meters wide and two meters high in the lower part of the town around the train station. Individual flood waves are said to have reached heights of up to six meters. The evening train of the Müglitztalbahn, which was standing at the station, was completely surrounded by the floodwaters, with some cars being swept away up to 300 meters. Two of the swept-away cars smashed into the Kurfürst-Moritz Bridge over the Müglitz, which had been built in 1545 and had withstood the severe flood of July 31, 1897. The passengers trapped in the cars were rescued by the fire department around 2:30 AM. After the flood receded, the train station area was covered about one meter high with mud, debris, and sludge. The city estimated the flood damage at around 100,000 Reichsmarks. In total, twelve people lost their lives in the waters in Glashütte.

Many basements were flooded and a shed and stables were swept away by the flood. Many bridges were severely damaged. The Ploschwitz Bridge, which carried the main lines of the water and gas supply, was heavily damaged, causing both lines to burst and the power and gas supply to come to a standstill. Hundreds of meters of wood were washed away from the Köttewitz paper factory.
Many residential and commercial buildings were affected. The Mühlenstraße was severely damaged. The bridge that spanned the Müglitz at the mouth of the Elbe was completely torn away.

In the narrow valley basin below Kuckuckstein Castle, a flood wave from the Seidewitz and its tributaries poured into the town of Liebstadt around 11:30 PM, completely flooding the city within two minutes. The water levels were likely about one and a half meters high in the streets and houses, as eyewitnesses reported that residents were standing in water up to their necks, trying to secure their belongings. At that time, Liebstadt was already cut off from the power supply and was in complete darkness. The water masses, enriched with extensive debris, receded after midnight, but in that short time, they severely damaged or destroyed the town's roads and bridges, cutting the area off from the outside world for the time being. Several houses suffered significant damage from collapsed gables and torn-down walls, while smaller outbuildings (sheds, storage), including parts of the Carlowitz manor, were completely washed away. One residential building had to be demolished after the flood. The lower mill and the middle mill were heavily devastated by the floods, and the old sawmill of the lower mill was subsequently torn down. In total, about 100 residents in Liebstadt were affected by flood damage. In contrast to the towns in the neighboring valleys, there were no fatalities in the city, as the Seidewitz is still a relatively small river compared to the Gottleuba and Müglitz, and due to the narrowness of the valley, people were able to quickly flee to the valley slopes from the back exits of their houses.

The so-called Thuringian deluge was a flood disaster in 1613, during which parts of Thuringia were affected by a flood. On May 29, 1613, heavy thunderstorms unleashed over parts of Thuringia, causing many rivers to rise several meters within a few hours. The affected area extended from Mühlhausen, Langensalza, and Artern in the north to Stadtilm and Ichtershausen in the south, from Erfurt and Gotha in the west to Naumburg in the east. The weather disaster is described as the "Thuringian deluge" in the chronicles of many localities: In Kahla, there were several fatalities, and in Jena, large parts of the city were flooded. In Zottelstedt near Apolda, the water level of the Ilm rose by 6 to 8 meters, almost completely destroying the village along the riverbank. In Apolda itself, eight houses were washed away, and 24 animals drowned. In Weimar, 44 houses were destroyed in the flood disaster, in Bad Berka 23 houses, and in Erfurt 125 houses. In Mattstedt, the water level of the Ilm rose by 6 meters, flooding the entire lower village. The disaster resulted in the further development of the area shifting to higher ground. In Bad Sulza, the saline built a few years earlier on the Ilm fell victim to the flood but was rebuilt at the same location. The total number of fatalities is reported to be 2,261 people. Historical flood events like the Thuringian deluge also play an important role in current research on this topic as hydrological-meteorological extreme situations. See also: century flood.

In the year 1720, Georg Wilhelm von Lage's work "The Complete Acts of the Thuringian Flood of 1613" was published, this book was published by the Lackische Bookstore in Weimar and Leipzig (Format 4° meaning: quarto) digitalized. The same book was part of the estate of the mining councilor Johann Karl Wilhelm Voigt, who passed away in 1821 in Ilmenau ("List of the mineralogical library left by the late mining councilor Voigt, who died on the first of January," published by his son, the bookseller and later publisher Bernhard Friedrich Voigt, Sondershausen, Ilmenau or Weimar). Another copy is located in the central church archive of the Johannes community. The meteorologist Gustav Hellmann compiled a bibliography on the Thuringian Flood, which lists the writings available at his time along with reprints of the title pages. The July flood of 1956 was a catastrophic flood in the Upper and Middle Weser as well as the Aller and Leine due to days of continuous rain in the mountainous regions of Thuringia, Lower Saxony, Hesse, and East Westphalia.

In June 1956, there were heavy rainfall events. In Lower Saxony, precipitation exceeded 300 percent of the long-term average in some areas. Between July 14 and July 16, 1956, there was nearly 50 hours of heavy rain in the mountainous regions of Lower Saxony, Thuringia, Hesse, and East Westphalia, as well as severe thunderstorms in the lowlands. These rains fell on water-saturated ground, causing the precipitation to only flow off the surface. In a very short time, water levels rose dramatically, leading to widespread flooding. By July 16, 1956, the water level of the Weser River in Minden rose to 4.50 meters above the average water level; shipping on the Upper and Middle Weser came to a standstill. In the city area of Braunschweig, 681 hectares of green and arable land were flooded in the Wabe and Mittelriede areas by July 17. In the lignite mine of Retterode near Hessisch Lichtenau (Werra-Meißner-Kreis), massive water ingress occurred on July 15 due to the rainfall, leading to partial flooding of the underground facilities. The situation worsened along the Aller and Leine rivers and in the Hessian highlands after further severe rain on July 18 and 19, 1956, resulting in dike breaches, riverbed relocations, and uncontrolled overflow of the Eder dam. The Free Hanseatic City of Bremen narrowly avoided a severe flood disaster solely because the floodwaters were diverted through the overflow routes that still existed at the time near Thedinghausen into the Ochtum lowlands, which, however, flooded the municipalities of Stuhr and Hasbergen. Due to the flooding on the Middle Weser, over 240,000 hectares were flooded by July 25. The estimated damage amounted to over 170 million DM. The Porta Westfalica gauge of the state water authority showed an extreme value of 1180 m³/s and 629 cm on July 17, 1956, which was nearly as high as the century flood of the Weser at 2300 m³/s and 790 cm on February 10, 1946.

The Oder flood disaster of 1947 was the most consequential flood caused by an Oder high water in modern times in Germany.

The worst Oder flood disaster of the 20th century in the Oderbruch occurred in the spring of 1947. On the evening of March 21, ice floes formed a barrier due to ice movement near the bypass canal at Küstrin-Kietz. Ice displacements also formed north of Reitwein. This quickly dammed large amounts of water. On the morning of March 22, 1947, at 1 a.m., the Oder dike at Reitwein was finally flooded. The dike crown was overtopped by water at two points over a length of more than 100 meters. Quickly, areas of the dike crown were destroyed over a width of about 300 meters and a depth of one meter. The flood even reached Bad Freienwalde (Oder), several kilometers from the river, where the main post office building in the city center is located, where a memorial stone can be found today. More than 20,000 people became homeless at that time. The head of the disaster protection department of the Märkisch-Oderland district administration also confirmed a ultimately unsuccessful deployment of Red Army bombers against the dangerous ice displacements on the Oder in 1947. On the morning of March 22, Soviet aircraft dropped eight bombs, and in the afternoon, four more bombs were dropped. Further bombings were also carried out on March 23. However, all measures did not yield the hoped-for results. It was not until March 24 that the displacement dissolved around 9 p.m.

The floods in Thailand in 2011 occurred at the end of March 2011 due to heavy rain. At least 51 people lost their lives. The hardest-hit area was Southern Thailand, where many mudslides also occurred. The heavy rain and mudslides were very unusual for this time of year because the monsoon rains only become active in the summer, and it should have been bone dry at that time. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs advised against traveling to the affected area unless absolutely necessary. The airport in Koh Samui was also temporarily closed, leaving thousands of tourists stranded. It is estimated that about 265 thousand people were affected by the floods. At the end of July, new floods occurred, this time in the north, which slowly spread northward (mainly towards the capital Bangkok). These floods were of significantly larger scale and claimed more lives.

Whole_Text.content: The extreme winter of 1783/1784 in the Northern Hemisphere was part of a natural climate fluctuation and is considered one of the harshest ever in Central Europe, but it was also unusual in North America and Asia. It was followed by extreme flooding in February and March 1784 in Central Europe, which is regarded as one of the greatest natural disasters of the early modern period in this region. The cause is attributed to particularly sulfur-rich or particularly violent and ash-rich volcanic eruptions that occurred in Iceland.

During the eruption of the Laki craters in Iceland (starting June 8, 1783, lasting about 8 months), a total of about 130 craters produced a total volume of approximately 12 to 15 km³ of lava. In addition, gas and ash clouds were released. The extensive amounts of sulfur dioxide emitted reacted with the water droplets in the clouds to form sulfurous acid and sulfuric acid. Alongside an estimated 122 million tons of sulfur dioxide, 15 million tons of hydrogen fluoride (HF) and 7 million tons of hydrogen chloride (HCl) were released. This had devastating consequences for the entire country: due to poisoning, livestock suffered (→ fluorosis); and the resulting famine caused an estimated 9,350 people to die in the following years, more than one-fifth of the population of Iceland. The eruption also affected Western Europe, as the toxic aerosol cloud spread over the entire continent, particularly over the British Isles, and was perceived as high smoke or "dry fog." Records report that the smog lingered in the sky for weeks. Symptoms of poisoning manifested as shortness of breath, making it difficult for farmers to carry out their fieldwork. Alone on the British Isles, around 25,000 people died. The eruption of Mount Asama in Japan in 1783 had a relatively minor impact on climate changes compared to the eruption of the Laki craters.

Benjamin Franklin reports on a remarkably cold winter in Philadelphia. He was then the American ambassador in Paris and suspected that the cold was the result of a dust haze in the atmosphere over Europe and North America. The cold was so severe that the harbor of New York City froze for ten days and sleds were able to cross the Long Island Sound.

The winter was exceptionally cold and snowy across Europe. Scientists believe that in 1784, the average temperature was one degree Celsius lower than usual. The frost period lasted a total of 13 weeks in Mainfranken. The cold began in December 1783, and almost all bodies of water in Central Europe froze over. The Great Belt in Denmark was frozen so solidly that it could be crossed with sleds and carts. Around December 26/27, 1783, there was a brief improvement in temperatures, but by the end of the year, they dropped sharply again. This extreme cold lasted until mid-January 1784. From mid-January to February 21/22, this cold phase was repeatedly interrupted by short periods of slightly milder temperatures. During this time, it also snowed frequently. The winter was very snowy from December to February. From December 24, 1783, to February 21, for example, 29 snowfall events were observed in Mannheim, some lasting for days. In some regions, the snow accumulated to more than 150 centimeters, with around 45 centimeters falling in the Rhine-Neckar area on December 27 and 28, 1783. February also brought a lot of snow and ice. All of Europe was affected by a cold wave from late December 1783 into January, stretching from the Black Sea to the Atlantic. In France, it was so cold that wolves appeared in the villages to prey on livestock. The snow amounts in the winter of 1783/84 severely restricted agricultural production in various German states, leading to significant supply shortages. To bridge these shortages, the respective governments intervened with controls. In Königsberg, so much grain was stored that there was not enough space for it. Several people froze to death in Darmstadt. Ice floes formed on the Saxon Elbe, becoming denser, and on the night of December 28 to 29, the river froze before the Augustus Bridge in Dresden. In Frankfurt am Main, bread and wood collections were conducted in January 1784 due to the ongoing severe cold and to support the poor. A total of 14,752 loaves of six pounds each were distributed. In Speyer, a modest celebration was held on the frozen Rhine to counteract poverty with the proceeds from this charity event. Out of fear of possible ice movement, public prayers were ordered in Cologne and Bamberg. In Stuttgart, a balloon was released in the courtyard of the military academy, illuminated and accompanied by a small fireworks display. The proceeds from this event were used to buy wood for the city's poor, as prices were very high. On January 7, temperatures of minus 17.5 degrees Réaumur (−21.9 °C) were recorded in Leipzig at seven in the morning. In Weida in the Vogtland, the Réaumur thermometer also showed minus 21 degrees Réaumur (−26.3 °C) on January 7 in the morning. However, even in the cold January of 1784, warmer periods were recorded in Saxony. From January 15 to 17, there was a thaw, with a maximum temperature of +5 °C reached. This meteorological pattern, alternating between colder and warmer periods, continued in February 1784 and led to a buildup of ice on the Elbe, as the cold January period in Germany was followed by a cold section that was repeatedly interrupted by short warmer phases until February 21/22. The severe frost lasted until the end of February 1784, causing ice masses on the Elbe to pile up to 110 centimeters. Additionally, significant snowfall in the Electorate made the supply situation more difficult.

Around February 23, a sudden influx of warm air caused the enormous snow masses that had accumulated during the winter to melt. This warm air was triggered by a blocking high-pressure area over Eastern Europe, which resulted in a southward-oriented circulation in Central Europe. The change in the large-scale weather situation brought warm air masses from western and southern directions to Mainfranken as well as to large parts of Europe. The winter had previously been characterized by above-average long periods of high pressure over Central Europe and the East, with very cold air masses being brought in from northern and eastern directions. The warm air influx was marked by widespread uplift movements leading to heavy precipitation. Due to the rapid and intense warming, accompanied by heavy rainfall, the last days of February 1784 saw the breaking and accumulation of ice in Germany's rivers. Because of the enormous amounts of meltwater, the ice jams, and the heavy precipitation, water levels began to rise very quickly. Ice movement occurred simultaneously on all major main and tributary rivers. Complicating matters was the fact that several ice layers had been pushed on top of each other during temporary thaw phases, which then refroze. Shortly after this warm air influx, cold weather returned due to another change in the large-scale weather situation, precipitation decreased, and water levels fell rapidly. The blocking high had dissolved, and the previous weather patterns could re-establish themselves. Cold air from northern and eastern directions flowed back into Central Europe.

The flood event is considered one of the largest natural disasters of the early modern period in Central Europe. The flood devastated entire valleys, and countless bridges were destroyed. It is also referred to as the "century ice flow" or "ice flood" or "winter flood of 1784." Cologne was struck by the worst flood ever recorded. During the mentioned temperature rise, the Rhine was completely frozen, while the melting snow and breaking ice caused a record level of 13.55 meters – for comparison, the normal level is 3.48 meters. The floods, on which heavy ice floes floated, devastated large parts of the riverbank construction and destroyed all ships. Individual buildings, including fortifications, collapsed due to the ice floes. There were 65 fatalities. In Beuel, only a few buildings with stone foundations survived the ice blocks; all half-timbered houses were washed away. The old Bergisch town of Mülheim on the right bank of the Rhine, now a district of Cologne, was completely destroyed. The trees of the famous walnut forest on the Namedyer Werth (since 1857 a peninsula) near Andernach were literally cut off by the ice floes above their roots. The Andernach Old Krahnen escaped the disaster due to the basalt icebreaker built upstream on the Rhine. At the Moselle, the ice flood of 1784 is the highest winter flood documented by flood marks to this day. In Trier, the highest water level was observed on February 28, 1784. The water reached there up to the horse market and into Jakobsgasse. A plaque on a building at the Great Market in Saarlouis marks the water level of the Saar from 1784. The Neckar caused the largest flood in historical times in Heidelberg. The consequences of the flood were exacerbated by the ice flow. In addition to the Old Bridge, 39 buildings were destroyed and 290 were damaged. Other communities, especially Neckarhausen, were similarly affected along the Neckar's route towards the mouth, including Mannheim's city center. After Seckenheim, the river partially took the path of an old mouth arm and flooded the Neckarau several kilometers away. The natural disaster prompted the establishment of the first flood protection measures between Edingen and Mannheim. Among other things, under the reign of Elector Karl Friedrich of Baden, an icebreaker made of sandstone was installed on the banks of the Neckar in Edingen. The Main also experienced extreme flooding. This second highest flood after 1342 (Magdalene flood) is classified as a 300- to 500-year event in the middle Main area. The flood mark at the town hall portal of Würzburg shows a maximum level of 173.83 m above sea level for this flood, which is 94 cm above the value from 1845. Compared to the flood recorded at the gauge in 1845, the flood of 1784 had a water level of 928 centimeters, with a discharge of 2600 m³/s. In Bamberg, the largest flood of all time claimed the riverbank construction in the mill district. The bridges were also heavily damaged. In particular, the Sees Bridge, completed in 1756, now known as the Chain Bridge, with its baroque design, was destroyed by ice floes and uprooted tree trunks. In Marktbreit, the half-timbered loading crane of the time was destroyed and later replaced by a stone structure with an icebreaker. At the end of February / beginning of March 1784, one of the most severe spring floods ever recorded occurred in the Bohemian and Saxon Elbe valley. The Elbe, which had been frozen for weeks, broke up in a very short time, rising by up to 32 cm per hour and reaching a level of 8.57 m in Dresden on March 1 (discharge 5200 m³/s). This was the highest level since 1655. In the entire Elbe valley, cities and villages were extensively flooded. In Dresden, the water stood one meter high in the courtyard of the Zwinger. The destructive power of the flood was particularly great due to the force of the debris and ice floes carried along. In Wegstädtl in Bohemia, the Gothic church collapsed. The Elbe bridges in Dresden and Meissen were heavily damaged. While in numerous places livestock could not be saved, the number of fatalities was relatively low given the severity of the flood. In Meissen, nine people lost their lives in the floodwaters. The old postal road between Meissen and Dresden was relocated to flood-safe areas due to the flood. Although the Elbe had already returned to its original course by March 6, the cleanup efforts were difficult as the onset of frost covered the flooded houses and areas with a layer of ice. The water levels at that time were only surpassed in many places during the Elbe flood of 1845. Further downstream in the Duchy of Magdeburg between Aken and Sandau, extreme floods with dike breaches occurred only in early April, including between Cracau and Prester near Magdeburg. The area around the mouth of the Saale into the Elbe at Calbe (Saale) and the section north of the city of Jerichow to Sandau were also heavily affected, all areas that were particularly impacted by the flood of 2013. After the Lahn in Weilburg destroyed a bridge with a water pipeline, the first chain bridge on the European continent was built here after reconstruction. Smaller rivers like the Glan in Ulmet (Pfalz) or the Paar in Baar-Ebenhausen (Bavaria) also experienced flooding.
