On November 5 and 6, 1994, the provinces of Cuneo, Turin, Asti, and Alessandria were heavily affected by a violent flood event that caused the overflow of the Po, Tanaro rivers and many of their tributaries (in particular the Belbo stream, an important right tributary of the Tanaro), resulting in 69 fatalities and 2,226 displaced persons.

The event can be characterized through three successive phases, which involved distinct territorial areas (ARPA Piemonte). The first phase, which occurred on November 4th, was marked by heavy thunderstorm-like precipitation and primarily affected the southernmost sectors of Piedmont and the Ligurian territory: the maximum intensity of rain was reached during the night between November 4th and 5th with hourly values exceeding 35 mm/hour and a peak of 55 mm/hour around midnight (Cairo Montenotte, Acqui Terme). Subsequently, on the 5th (second phase), the precipitation extended to the areas of Astigiano and Cuneese. In many locations in the basins of the Tanaro, Bormida, and Belbo rivers, rainfall exceeded 200 mm in 24 hours. The maximum accumulation over two days was recorded in Levice (CN) with 293.8 mm; the maximum for one day was also recorded in Levice with 264.6 mm (Luino, 1999). In the third phase of the event, the most intense precipitation affected the pre-Alpine belt between the Pellice Valley and the Sesia Valley in the afternoon and evening of the 5th, easing in the morning of the 6th. On the 6th, precipitation practically ceased in the southern part of the region, while it continued in the central-northern part, with modest hourly intensity, but still with significant daily totals.

After several days of continuous rain, the Tanaro rose to frightening levels. A flood wave formed on November 5 upstream of Ormea and, rushing downstream, devastated with unprecedented fury its entire course and the dozens of inhabited centers along its banks until it reached the confluence with the Po in the early hours of November 7. During the flooding event, the Tanaro reached record flow values never before achieved in the century: The stretch between the municipality of Ormea and the confluence with the Stura di Demonte near Cherasco was particularly devastated by the flooding event, where the Tanaro almost completely destroyed most of the civil structures present (houses, bridges, roads, etc.), also permanently altering the shape of its bed and the valley floor over large stretches. The municipalities affected by the flood wave included: The cities of Ceva, Alba, and Asti were particularly hard hit, flooded for 1/3 of their surface area, and especially Alessandria, submerged by almost 50%, where 14 people lost their lives.

In those 3 days of rain (over 200 mm in 24 hours just on November 5), the stream swelled excessively, reaching exceptional flow values of 1,330 m³/s in Santo Stefano Belbo and almost 1,000 m³/s in Castelnuovo Belbo (respectively 220 and 167 times the normal flow), overflowing along its entire course and brutally devastating almost all of its valley floor. The municipalities particularly affected by the fury of the waters were Rocchetta Belbo, Cossano Belbo, Santo Stefano Belbo, Canelli (the hardest-hit center, which also recorded 3 victims), and Incisa Scapaccino; only Nizza Monferrato was spared from the disaster, although it suffered heavy damage to the roads adjacent to the watercourse and flooding in some basements.

Due to the heavy rains, the river level rose significantly, and in addition to the damage caused by the flow of the Tanaro downstream, upstream the river swollen by the inflow, particularly from the Orco and Dora Baltea tributaries, overflowed in various areas causing extensive damage and flooding. Areas heavily affected included Chivasso, where the confluence with the Orco created a flood wave that caused the bridge over the Po to collapse on the night of November 5th to 6th, and Trino, where the entire town center was submerged and damage was recorded at the former Enrico Fermi nuclear power plant. Other affected or submerged areas included Verolengo, Crescentino, Palazzolo Vercellese, and Morano sul Po.

The affected areas also included those of Canavese; on the basin of the Dora Baltea, as mentioned earlier, the flood was over 3000 m³/s. The Mazzè power plant and the intake of the Depretis Canal in Villareggia were severely impacted, resulting in damage to the structure.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Veneto in 2010 occurred following a strong Atlantic disturbance that brought persistent rains to the region starting from October 31, 2010. Additionally, the warm sirocco wind, which melted the snow that had fallen in the mountains weeks earlier, hindered the normal flow of rivers into the Adriatic Sea.

The flood affected 130 municipalities in the Veneto region across all provinces and flooded 140 km² of land; the hardest-hit areas were those of Vicenza and its province, the province of Padua, and the province of Verona. The heavy rains caused the rivers Timonchio, Bacchiglione, Retrone, Alpone, Tramigna, and Frassine to overflow. In the provinces of Treviso and Belluno, there were numerous landslides. The number of people affected was 500,000. In the province of Padua alone, 4,500 people were evacuated, and two people died in Vicenza.

20% of the city of Vicenza has been flooded by the waters of the Bacchiglione and Retrone rivers. The first river overflowed in the early hours of the morning on November 1, affecting the area around the old Araceli church and Viale Rumor, with the nearby Querini park turned into a swamp. Consequently, the provincial headquarters of the Red Cross and UNICEF located in Contrà Torretti were evacuated. At 7:30, the Bacchiglione also overflowed at the Ponte degli Angeli, blocking access from the north and east to the historic center; however, the Olympic Theatre was spared thanks to the activation of three pumps (added to the two always present in the famous Palladian structure). The waters also flooded Contrà San Pietro, Corso Padova, Via IV Novembre, the riverside areas of San Biagio/San Marco, and the area around the Menti Stadium. The Bacchiglione overflowed again at the Viale Diaz bridge, blocking traffic on one of the main arteries of the outer ring road, flooding the San Paolo neighborhood (sports hall, swimming pools, athletics field) and the Carmini area with the northern part of Corso Fogazzaro. The Santa Bertilla area (customs and fruit and vegetable market) was also flooded, as was the Viale Trento area. In the afternoon, the Retrone overflowed in the S. Agostino neighborhood, and all residents on the ground floors of the Debba neighborhood were evacuated. Traffic in the city was paralyzed: the A4 motorway was closed, as well as the Southern Bypass and all railway lines that start or pass through the city. Urban mobility bus lines operated by AIM were also altered, and some lines were suspended due to the impossibility of traveling through the city streets. Twenty-one electrical cabins ended up underwater, leaving over 3,000 users without power. These are the data from the flood: As soon as the waters receded, Mayor Achille Variati made an appeal for any volunteers who could help the city and the people of Vicenza return to normalcy soon. The next day, more than 200 people showed up to provide assistance, first to the AIM Valore Ambiente workers to clean the streets and then to the citizens. In four days, the number of volunteers reached 2,483 people who, in three daily shifts meeting in Piazza Matteotti, were dispatched to the most critical points in the city. On November 3, almost all schools reopened, and the usual Thursday city market was confirmed; on the same day, Guido Bertolaso arrived in Vicenza, declaring a state of crisis and bringing the army to the city. Following Bertolaso's visit, among others, Silvio Berlusconi and Umberto Bossi visited on November 9. On November 11, the President of the Italian Republic, Giorgio Napolitano, arrived in the provincial capital, at the explicit invitation of the mayor. The President first went to Piazza Matteotti (where volunteers awaited him with a personalized vest) and then to the town hall. "You have shown that it is not true that you are waiting for help from the State, that you do not ask but do, that you have understood how in a moment like this cleaning is a noble job. No one was ashamed to put their hands in the mud and use a broom" (Giorgio Napolitano in his speech to the volunteers during his visit to the city on November 11). Following the flood, 46 Vicentine artists (including Los Locos, Stefano Centomo, and the Lost) joined together in the style of Artists United for Abruzzo, recording the piece "Un cuore grande così," the proceeds of which will go to the flood victims.

The city found itself managing new flood alarms on November 16, December 23, 2010, March 16, 2011, November 11, 2012, and May 16, 2013. In all 5 cases, the municipal emergency plan was activated, which included an announcement (through the loudspeakers of local police patrols) to secure belongings and cars located on lower floors, the positioning of pallets of sandbags ready or to be packaged at 11 strategic points in the city, and the acceleration of any flood prevention work through technical supplies from AIM Vicenza and Valore Città by the patrols of various public safety agencies. On November 16, 2010 (just 15 days after the most critical situation), volunteers were requested to help package sandbags, and precautionary evacuations of some schools affected by flooding on November 1 were carried out. On December 24, 2010, given the upcoming Christmas holidays, the municipality called upon the American army stationed at Ederle barracks, as well as on March 16, 2011 (the celebration of Italy's unity). Fortunately, all alarms subsided fairly quickly, with flooding limited to the "historically" more vulnerable areas.

In the Vicenza area, the Bacchiglione River has overflowed in several places, although the most difficult situation was recorded in the outskirts of Vicenza, particularly in Caldogno in the neighborhoods of Rettorgole and especially in Cresole, which was completely submerged and where the first victim was recorded (a man who drowned in his garage). In Valli del Pasubio, Torrebelvicino, and Recoaro Terme, various landslides forced the evacuation of about forty families. Numerous landslides occurred in the Chiampo Valley.

In the Padua area, the Bacchiglione broke at the height of the Ponte San Nicolò landfill, flooding not only the Roncajette district of Ponte San Nicolò but also the municipalities of Casalserugo, Bovolenta, and Maserà in the Pratiarcati area of the Bertipaglia district. The Frassine also overflowed, causing numerous floods. On the night of November 1-2, 2010, in Veggiano, the Tesina Padovano broke the right bank before merging with the Bacchiglione, shortly after the Fratta pump station, flooding a large part of the municipal territory on November 2, 2010. The force of the water flattened 40 meters of embankment (which would only be partially repaired with giant boulders brought by helicopter days later), forcing the evacuation of 880 people. Also in the territory of the municipality of Veggiano, the Tesinella (which comes from the municipality of Grisignano di Zocco) overflowed, and numerous springs opened along the banks of other tributaries (Ceresone). For over a week, the water level exceeded one and a half meters, with peaks over 2 meters in the lowest areas. One of the most affected areas by the flood was the Bassa Padovana, where 22% of the territory was inundated. The embankment of the Frassine River suddenly gave way in the Prà di Botte area (a collapse of 150 meters of embankment), flooding the municipalities of Megliadino San Fidenzio, Saletto, Montagnana, Ospedaletto Euganeo, and Este; 23 million cubic meters of water poured into the area. A couple of hours after the disaster, another drainage, the Vampadore, overflowed, flooding Megliadino San Vitale and Casale di Scodosia. Subsequently, the municipalities of Carceri and Vighizzolo d'Este were also invaded by the waters of the Brancaglia canal (although to a much lesser extent). The landfill present in Este was immediately closed as water managed to enter the facilities. During the flood period, a vast lake could be observed from the Euganean Hills, stretching for dozens of kilometers. On November 17 and 18, there were new overflows, particularly of the Bacchiglione River, which flooded Bovolenta in particular. The same happened on December 25, also in Bovolenta.

In the Verona area, the two municipalities most affected were Monteforte d'Alpone and Soave. The overflow from the Alpone stream led to the closure of the A4 motorway. On the morning of November 1, 2010, after the break of the embankment of the Alpone stream in San Bonifacio (where the Chiampo flows into the Alpone), the waters flooded the entire southern part of Monteforte d'Alpone, reaching nearly two meters in height on some streets. In Monteforte, 6 million cubic meters of water and mud poured in, causing damage to 759 private properties, 146 businesses, and 25 farms. On the morning of November 1, 2010, the water from the Tramigna stream, a tributary of the Alpone, broke the embankment and began to overflow in Soave. A part of the area within the medieval walls and the entire outer part up to the middle school were flooded with water, which flowed from the Alpone up the Tramigna. With this flooding in Soave, about 600 private properties, 120 businesses, and 22 farms suffered damage. Numerous landslides occurred in Malcesine on Lake Garda, where one particularly threatened the inhabited area.

The contribution of Civil Protection volunteers has been fundamental for the rapid overcoming of the emergency. About 6,801 volunteers registered in the regional register of Volunteer Organizations worked in their respective provinces. A significant contribution also came from mobile units from other Italian regions that intervened to assist Veneto, coordinated by the Department of Civil Protection.

Article_Name: Alluvione della Maremma grossetana del novembre 2012

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Maremma Grossetana in November 2012
Whole_Text.content: The flood of the Grosseto Maremma in November 2012 was a serious catastrophic event that affected the central-southern part of the province of Grosseto on November 12, 2012, resulting in the loss of 6 human lives, one due to the overflow of the Chiarone River, one due to the overflow of a canal near Lake Burano in the vicinity of Capalbio, and the other three due to the collapse of a bridge over the Albegna River near Marsiliana, in addition to two seriously injured individuals, one of whom died on December 30 of the same year. The overflow of various watercourses caused flooding and significant damage in the countryside between the basins of the Ombrone, Albegna, Fiora, Nestore, and Paglia rivers and in the town of Albinia in the municipality of Orbetello, a fraction that remained completely flooded with about 150 displaced persons due to the overflow of the Albegna River, out of a total of about 700 displaced persons throughout the province. Cultural heritage was also affected with the collapse of a Renaissance bastion and a section of the walls of Magliano in Tuscany. Numerous infrastructures were rendered unusable, including the State Road 1 Via Aurelia and the Tyrrhenian Railway (reopened in the afternoon of November 16, 2012) which were interrupted near Albinia, along with many local roads, due to the severe damage caused by the disastrous effects of the bad weather. In Grosseto, a record flood of the Ombrone was recorded, which remained in floodplain for three days, lasting longer than that of 1966 but without major damage in the city, despite the panic in the fraction of Istia d'Ombrone where the water reached some houses near the bridge; the fractions of Rispescia and Alberese, moreover, remained isolated for two days. At the provincial level, the event is comparable to the Grosseto flood of November 4, 1966, with the difference that the 2012 event hit the southern sector of the province harder, while the 1966 event caused the most damage along the Ombrone Valley, in the central-northern part of the provincial territory. Intense rainfall also affected the area of Mount Amiata, including the Sienese side, as well as a vast area of Lazio and Umbria straddling the Laziale Maremma, Tuscia, and Orvietano, where exceptional floods occurred, leading to overflows of some right tributaries of the Tiber, including the Nestore, with 1000 m³/sec. at Marsciano, submerged by the overflow with significant damage, and especially the Paglia, its main right tributary, which with an extraordinary flood of 1,500 m³/sec completely submerged the lower part of the municipality of Orvieto causing significant damage.

On the morning of November 11, 2012, the Regional Hydrological Service of Tuscany issued a maximum level critical alert valid until 24:00 on November 12, 2012, for various areas of central-southern Tuscany, including the Ombrone Valley, the Val d'Orcia, the valleys of the Bruna, Albegna, and Fiora rivers, areas later involved in the tragic flooding event, as well as other areas such as the islands of the Tuscan Archipelago, Valtiberina, Casentino, upper Valdarno, Valdichiana, the Cecina river valley, and Val di Cornia. Given the high level of the alert issued, which anticipated the risk of accumulations exceeding 250 mm in 24 hours in the affected areas, the Province of Grosseto requested the individual municipalities to adopt all preventive measures to address the situation and to adequately inform the population about the risks associated with the anticipated event.

Whole_Text.header: Genesis and evolution of the event
Whole_Text.content: On November 10, 2012, a complex system of low pressures and disturbances formed between the Atlantic Ocean and Spain rapidly moved towards the western Mediterranean, beginning to affect northwestern Italy and causing rather abundant rainfall in Liguria in the second part of the day. Meanwhile, an extensive high-pressure area was strengthening over the Balkans, acting as a block to the eastward movement of disturbances, thereby reinforcing the warm and humid sirocco wind drawn towards Italy by the low pressure present over the western Mediterranean. As a result, in the evening, the disturbance intensified, fueled by the sirocco, generating strong thunderstorms during the night between Versilia, Garfagnana, Lunigiana, and the Pisa coastline, reaching the city of Livorno, all areas where rainfall accumulations between 100 and 250 millimeters were recorded in just a few hours. Between the morning and early afternoon of Sunday, November 11, 2012, cooler and drier air arriving from the Atlantic managed to invade Tuscany for a few hours, bringing a temporary and relative improvement in the weather; however, the blocking action of the high pressure over the Balkans, opposing the now deep low pressure over the western Mediterranean, kept a strong and humid sirocco wind alive between the Strait of Sicily and the southern Tyrrhenian Sea. By late afternoon, the sirocco again reached southern Tuscany through a warm front that - due to the relative positions of low and high pressures near Italy, and the presence at high altitude of a jet stream extending in the same direction as the front - remained stationary in place for about 30 hours. Along the warm front, a very intense mesoscale convective system was generated, that is, a particularly extensive thunderstorm that brought heavy rains and downpours between the Grosseto Maremma, part of the province of Siena and the province of Viterbo, and the Tyrrhenian Umbria. The thunderstorm renewed its structure, continuously regenerating from 6 PM on Sunday, November 11, until 11 PM on Monday, November 12, 2012, when the bad weather rapidly eased. The improvement in the weather was favored by the formation of a new low pressure over Morocco, which again drew the humid air pushed by the sirocco not towards Tuscany but towards Sardinia (first) and the Balearic Islands (later).

At the precipitation level, numerous stations of the Regional Hydrological Service of Tuscany recorded record rainfall accumulations, never previously recorded during their respective historical series, even surpassing the highs of November 1966; at the same time, some rain gauge stations, including those of Orbetello-San Donato and Magliano in Toscana-Poggio Perotto, recorded precipitation accumulations in just 24 hours between the evening of November 11 and the evening of November 12, 2012, that were more than half of the total rainfall that typically falls in a year (part of the area most affected by the intense phenomena has historical annual rainfall averages between 500 and 600 mm). Below are some rainfall records recorded during the flood event by some stations of the Regional Hydrological Service of Tuscany: In addition to the aforementioned daily rainfall records, following the precipitation of November 12, 2012, various rain gauge stations in the affected area recorded a new monthly total precipitation record with 18 days still available to further increase the record: among them, the hydrological stations of Abbadia San Salvatore and Piancastagnaio in the province of Siena, on the slopes of Mount Amiata from which the valley of the Paglia River originates, in addition to the already mentioned rain gauge stations of Orbetello-San Donato, Scansano-Pomonte, and Roccalbegna-Usi, and the hydrological stations of Magliano in Toscana-Poggio Perotto, Manciano, Marsiliana, Manciano-Capanne, Pitigliano in the Tufo Area, and Santa Fiora on the Grosseto side of Amiata; other stations, however, recorded precipitation accumulations between November 1 and 12, 2012, close to the historical monthly record, which could be surpassed by the end of the month in case of further precipitation. We also report the data recorded in the immediate vicinity of the Grosseto borders, for example, the two meteorological stations related to Acquapendente (VT) managed by MeteoAquesio. The first, located at an altitude of 340 m a.s.l. (locality Fornace), recorded, in just under 40 hours, an accumulation of 256 mm. The second, located at an altitude of 734 m a.s.l. (located at the Monte Rufeno nature reserve), recorded, in just under 40 hours, a rainfall accumulation of 465 mm. This last station found itself for several hours right in the most active part of the trajectory of the self-reinforcing thunderstorm, recording a record accumulation accompanied by very high rain rate values.

The Public Prosecutor's Office at the Court of Grosseto has initiated investigations to clarify all criminal responsibilities, opening four separate files following the flooding event that affected a large part of the provincial territory.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Versilia was a serious flooding event that struck part of the historical region of Versilia in Tuscany on June 19, 1996, following a particularly violent storm phenomenon that occurred during the transition from spring to summer.

On the morning of June 19, 1996, the sky over Versilia was clear; however, that day a clash of cold air from Northern Italy with warm, humid air from the coast was taking place over the peaks of the Apuan Alps, causing a rapid meteorological evolution, thus favoring the formation of an apparently modest thunderstorm cell that was, however, 12 km high and about half as wide, heavily laden with precipitation (convective thunderstorm). Violent downpours unleashed from early morning on the Apuan Alps, affecting the entire upper basin of the Serra and Vezza streams (the latter merging into a single watercourse at Seravezza, the Versilia) on the western watershed, and the entire upper part of the Turrite di Gallicano stream basin on the eastern watershed. The precipitation also affected part of the Camaiore river basin. All this while only a few drops of rain fell on the plain of Versilia. In a short time, the extraordinary precipitation (with peaks of over 150 mm in one hour in the upper Vezza basin) caused various landslides, and the watercourses quickly swelled. Following a brief pause that occurred late in the morning, the rains resumed even more intensely throughout the day from noon until early afternoon, before the deluge broke out. Copious rains shook the mountains and valleys near the village of Cardoso, where various minor streams give rise, near the settlement, to the Vezza stream. Meanwhile, in the plain, no one could remotely predict what was happening: in the Pietrasanta area, near the short stretch of the Versilia river, only 5–10 mm of rain had fallen. The civil protection agency was activated, taking care, around 2:00 PM, to check the rainfall values on the Apuan Alps, discovering that one of the hydrometers near the Pomezzana center in the upper valley of the Vezza stream recorded a record cumulative precipitation value, with 440 mm in just 8 hours and a maximum peak of 157 mm in one hour. Fearing that some sudden flood wave could occur, the levels of the rivers were immediately checked, especially the Versilia, which at first glance appeared to be, after the large flood wave in the morning, deceptively decreasing.

Around 1:00 PM in the upper valley, the Vezza stream (upper section of the Versilia river) began its devastating run down towards the center of Cardoso: here, according to eyewitnesses, numerous booms were first heard coming from the mountains, after which repeated waves of water, mud, and debris up to 4-5 meters high arrived from the gullies of the tributary streams near the village, which was thus hit and almost completely destroyed. The speed and sudden violence of the event were justified by the fact that since the morning, the heavy rains, combined with the drought that had afflicted the area for months, had made the already unstable slopes of the Apuan Alps even more fragile, causing enormous landslides of earth, debris, and logs that had blocked, with temporary barriers, all the valleys of the watercourses upstream of Cardoso that give rise to the Vezza stream; thus, various ephemeral water basins had formed which, collapsing all together in the early afternoon under the incessant rainfall, led to a catastrophic flood wave. Among the people who lost their lives was little Alessio Ricci, after whom the elementary school on Via Pontenuovo in Pietrasanta has been named since 2020: he was only 8 years old when he was swallowed by the river's flood. After devastating Cardoso, the flood continued down the Vezza stream and first hit the center of Ponte Stazzemese (where it reached the second floor of the houses, partially collapsing an entire hotel) before reaching Ruosina, where it submerged the entire settlement, almost completely erasing the valley floor road. Additional water contributions arrived at the Vezza from every side valley, further fueling its flood. Around 3:00 PM, the flood arrived furiously at the town of Seravezza, which was largely submerged by 2-3 meters of water; in this stretch, the Vezza stream then received from the right the flood of its main tributary, the Serra stream, and changing its name from this confluence to "Versilia river," it continued impetuously and overflowing with debris downstream, literally causing a malfunction (when it marked a value of 4.50 m above the zero hydrometric level) of the only hydrometer present along its river stretch. Therefore, no other data regarding the maximum flood height is known except for the peak flow value, estimated after the event, at about 571 m³/s, an absolutely exceptional and uncontrollable value for a modest river like the Versilia. After Seravezza, the Versilia overflowed and destroyed all the bridges near the centers of Ripa, Corvaia, and Vallecchia, leaving its valley stretch and finding an outlet in the plain of Versilia: in this stretch, the river (channeled and diverted in the past centuries into an artificial bed that flows near Cinquale di Montignoso) literally overflowed near the locality of San Bartolomeo in Pietrasanta due to the overtopping and subsequent collapse of a large section of its left bank, thus creating a new course southward, following the ancient path of its old flow bed, causing an extensive flood of the entire western portion of the municipality of Pietrasanta up to the fraction of Marina di Pietrasanta, Forte dei Marmi, and part of the municipality of Montignoso. Meanwhile, the tragedy also struck the eastern slope of the Apuan Alps in Garfagnana: in the upper valley of the Turrite stream, the center of Fornovolasco was literally devastated by the flood of the watercourse. Further downstream, however, the damage was minimal thanks to the presence of an artificial lake on the watercourse that, completely empty for maintenance, was able to accommodate and slow down much of the flood, saving the center located further downstream in Gallicano. Around 6:00 PM, the rain gauges in Pomezzana and Retignano, in Alta Versilia, showed cumulative precipitation values of 478 and 401 mm respectively over 13 hours. That of Fornovolasco, in Garfagnana, was 408 mm. This tragedy, considered one of the worst floods to ever hit Tuscany after the Florence flood of 1966, also caused a high number of victims: by the end of the emergency, there would be 13 dead, almost all in Cardoso, and one missing.
The technician Marco Fornaciari (41 years old) died during an inspection of the areas affected by the flood.

Article_Name: Alluvione dello Spezzino e della Lunigiana del 25 ottobre 2011

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Spezzino and Lunigiana on October 25, 2011
Whole_Text.content: The flood of Spezzino and Lunigiana on October 25, 2011, occurred following heavy rainfall that dumped 542 mm of rain in six hours on the provinces of La Spezia and Massa and Carrara. This weather event caused the flooding of the Vara and Magra rivers and their tributary streams in the affected areas, with varying degrees of flooding throughout the Val di Vara and Val di Magra. The most affected centers were Borghetto di Vara, Brugnato, Bonassola, Levanto, Monterosso al Mare, Vernazza in the province of La Spezia, and Aulla in the province of Massa-Carrara. This event was followed a few days later by the flood in Genoa on November 4, 2011, also caused by extremely heavy rainfall (Mediterranean low Rolf) that recorded peaks exceeding 500 mm in a few hours in various areas of Genoa and its province, causing the overflow of the Bisagno and Fereggiano streams and the flooding of the Sturla, Scrivia, and Entella streams, resulting in 6 deaths.

In the early morning of October 25, 2011, a disturbance began to concentrate over the northern areas of the provinces of La Spezia and Massa and Carrara. Within a few hours, an enormous amount of rain fell. In no time, the tributaries of the main rivers became uncontrollable and overflowed, bringing all sorts of debris downstream. The flood wave effect spread to the major rivers, Vara and Magra, which overflowed into the plains around the villages of Borghetto di Vara, Brugnato, Ameglia, and Pontremoli, Villafranca in Lunigiana, and Aulla. The disaster also affected the nearby Cinque Terre in the province of La Spezia: the water carried huge amounts of mud and debris along the natural drainage in the villages of Vernazza and Monterosso, and the main roads turned into raging rivers, carrying everything they dragged out to sea. The flood deposit in the main street of Vernazza measured several meters in thickness. Communications became extremely difficult: there were also significant damages to road infrastructures with landslides and mudslides on various provincial roads (resulting in the isolation of some inland locations), closure of the A12 motorway section between the toll booths of Sestri Levante and Deiva Marina due to a landslide on the southbound lane, and disruptions on the Levantine railway line. On the A12, the landslide involved a truck, and rescuers managed to extract the driver, who was miraculously saved. The state road 1 Via Aurelia was interrupted by multiple landslides, and the railway was blocked by a mudslide in Vernazza. Dozens of small towns in the Val di Vara became unreachable, except by helicopter, and telecommunications were interrupted. Further south in the reference watershed, the effects of the flood were felt in the municipality of Ameglia, at the mouth of the Magra River: in three years, the fourth overflow was recorded, and this time the most affected (in addition to houses completely invaded by mud) was the Colombiera bridge, which collapsed for the second time: a yacht was dislodged by the river's fury and struck the central span of the bridge, destroying it. More than a week after the flooding event, in anticipation of a new and maximum weather alert across the region (classified as "Alert 2" by the meteorological and hydrological functional center of the Civil Protection of the Liguria Region, expected from 10 PM on November 3 to 6 PM on November 6 in the Ligurian maritime basins of Ponente, Centro, Levante, and Padani di Ponente), evacuation orders for the population were issued by the respective mayors of Vernazza and Borghetto di Vara as a precautionary measure. In Val di Vara, landslides continued for days, blocking road communications. On November 5, Camisano (Ameglia) and Pignone were evacuated, while Corvara and Bracelli (in the municipality of Beverino) were isolated, and new evacuations took place in Calice al Cornoviglio, where the roads were now opening into terrifying chasms. In ten days, 4 bridges collapsed, and 20 roads were closed between Montemarcello, Rocchetta di Vara, Brugnato, Calice, Pignone, Beverino, Corniglia, Monterosso, and Vernazza.
Main municipalities affected by the flood.
Other municipalities affected, albeit with lesser intensity, had to face landslides and flooding of watercourses.

One of the factors exacerbating the affected citizens is the recurrence of these events in the area: the flood of October 25, 2011 marks the peak of three catastrophic years, where every rainfall of above-average intensity results in incalculable disasters from floods and landslides. After the 1960s, the riverbanks were raised twice to reach a total height of 5 meters, through the application of two layers of unreinforced concrete that were not statically connected to each other. The foundations of the banks were affected by the insertion of a protective layer of rocks.

From the very beginning, the exceptional nature of the climatic variable is evident, but the disastrous effects raise many questions about the hydrogeological structure of the Spezia territory, which has already been heavily affected in previous years. The combined effect of global warming and recent changes in land use has led to a situation of increased flood risk, worsened by the growing likelihood of events of significant intensity. Recent cases of flooding in Liguria confirm that this circumstance occurs in Mediterranean environments, but not only, of the Italian peninsula.

The strong abandonment of crops, the neglect of underbrush, and the disease of non-native plants have been the causes of aggravating factors in the climatic situation, leading to a decrease in the geotechnical resistance of the soils, the formation of organic and inorganic detrital material, and blockages in water management systems.

The Magra River Basin Authority had anticipated everything, declaring flood levels in the Hydrogeological Arrangement Plan (PAI) or Basin Plan, approved in 2003; however, in the flooded areas, there were constructions erected from the 1950s onwards. In Monterosso al Mare and Vernazza, the controversial issue is the covering of the channels, which became pressurized with the fallen rain. Even in the Cinque Terre, cementification is not ruled out as a cause of the lack of water management: in Monterosso, the council granted permission for the construction of 30 villas by the Meschi family. In Brugnato, the Friday before the tragedy, the municipal council voted to approve the construction of a huge outlet that was supposed to be built right in the area devastated by the flood. The outlet was then regularly constructed and inaugurated in 2014. The method of cementification of the territory is also under discussion in Aulla, where a large part of the constructions of the last fifty years have been built within the natural riverbed of the Magra River. At the beginning of the flood wave that invaded the streets of the town, it seems there was a failure of the dam of the sedimentation basin to the north, near Villafranca in Lunigiana. In the days following October 25, the institutional authorities, who visited Aulla, were heavily contested by the local people: among them was the mayor of Pontremoli, Lucia Baracchini, and Minister Altero Matteoli.

The floods of the Vara and the tidal part of the Magra represent another controversy: public opinion points the finger at the lack of dredging of riverbeds, regulated by Law 183/1989, which classifies the extraction of inert materials along rivers as soil defense interventions, thus placing, in principle, the public interest in proper hydraulic maintenance as the only act that allows extraction activities in rivers. As a result, pending the adoption of Basin Plans, extraction activities have been suspended. Despite popular beliefs, rivers would be flooded with sediment material; however, there is a study commissioned by the interregional Basin Authority of the Magra River, developed by the Faculty of Civil Engineering at the University of Florence, which states that the valley sections of the rivers have not increased sediment levels, but rather are incised. Another important point seems to be the state of neglect of secondary watercourses and the tributaries of the Vara and Magra rivers. According to some testimonies, in the municipality of Follo, affected by the flood in the plain, it seems that the water did not come directly from the riverbed, but rather from the inability of the tributary streams to drain into it. This would have caused damage to the culverts (some literally exploded) and their overflow would have flooded the buildings present in an area classified by the PAI as floodable.

The causes of the flooding events have been the subject of legal proceedings: Subsequently, the construction of a multi-storey car park in Monterosso was suspended and the construction site was placed under seizure by the La Spezia prosecutor's office.

The case of the Brugnato outlet flared up in the weeks following the disaster, dividing public opinion between those in favor of the project, which would ensure the economic revival of the area, and those against it, due to the danger of the area and the failing economic model it would support. The Liguria region issued a resolution, known as "safeguard," which halts construction in areas affected by the flood, pending safety checks. This measure follows a similar one by the Tuscany Region. In fact, this decision freezes the outlet project. However, the outlet is not the only point of contention; in Monterosso, controversy erupted over the Mayor's decision to continue work on a multi-story parking lot. The outlet was then regularly built and inaugurated on April 10, 2014.

From the day of the disaster until November 9, 2011, 10 people were reported dead (7 in Borghetto di Vara, 2 in Aulla, and 1 in Monterosso) and 3 missing (in Vernazza): Sauro Picconcelli (50 years old), Pino Giannoni (70), and Giuseppina Carro (80). On November 10, the identity of a body found off the coast of Saint Tropez was confirmed to be Sauro Picconcelli. On November 11, a second body found off the coast of France was identified as Pino Giannoni: the toll is 12 victims and 1 missing. On December 16, DNA testing confirmed that the three bodies found in France were those of Pino Giannoni, Sauro Picconcelli, and Pina Carro: the final toll is 13 victims. The victim from Monterosso, Sandro Usai, was swept away by the mudslide while trying to save some people from the river's flood. In relation to his act, the President of the Republic, Giorgio Napolitano, will award the gold medal for civil valor posthumously to his widow.

Following the event, the A12 and the La Spezia-Genova railway were closed, and 43% of provincial roads were declared impassable. A total of 1,183 people were evacuated: 238 in Monterosso, 150 in Vernazza (all transferred to Levanto), 196 in Borghetto, 199 in Brugnato, 25 in Sesta Godano, 27 in Pignone, 152 in Beverino, 75 in Rocchetta Vara, 18 in Ameglia, plus 49 from Bocca di Magra, 34 in Arcola, and 22 in Calice al Cornoviglio. The economic damages were initially estimated at around 1.5 billion euros. On November 19, 2011, it was announced that 947 claims had been filed for a total reported damage amounting to 116,213,535 euros. These claims should be added to those received in the following days due to the extension until November 30 and those from agricultural businesses received by the Agricultural Inspectorate. For the most urgent sums, that is for the immediate interventions to be carried out, Vernazza has allocated 50.9 million, Monterosso 35 million, Brugnato 17.9 million, Borghetto 12.9 million, Sesta Godano 4.1 million, Beverino 6 million, Calice 4.1 million, and Ameglia 2.1 million. In total, twenty-five municipalities have sent reporting forms to the commissioner. The defense of the land and the road network of the Province has counted damages of 47.5 million. The companies in La Spezia that requested aid due to the damages caused by the flood, as of December 20, 2011, number 1,481, of which 269 are agricultural businesses, for a total compensation of 169 million euros; 203 requests came from Monterosso, 145 from Brugnato, 109 from Vernazza, and 80 from Borghetto. To address the damages caused by the flood, the Berlusconi government increased fuel taxes by 0.0089%. To cover the flood fund, the Liguria Region also decided to increase gasoline taxes (+0.5 cents), a choice mandated by the previous government, which, at the initiative of Minister Giulio Tremonti, requested Liguria and Tuscany to increase taxes to support the 40 million allocated for the damages.

Thousands of volunteers have mobilized to help the affected population. Many of them responded to calls made on social networks like Facebook: students, workers, spiritual heirs of those "mud angels" from Florence. A particular case was that of the "red bands," almost 400 volunteers from all over Italy (Como, Naples, Pavia, Trento, Parma, Rome, Livorno, etc.) who identify themselves with a red band on their arm. The idea reproduces an ancient custom of the Lunigiana labor movement, which, in a late 1800s photo, depicted labor teams from Pontremolese with red bands around their waists and arms. Special attention has been paid, from the beginning, to the nature of the aid, especially financial. An example is the case of Monterosso, where a fundraising campaign was launched by Repubblica and Sky for the "rescue" of the "Enrico Fermi" elementary school, but some testimonies revealed that the school building had not suffered significant damage that would prevent its use. The question arises as to what the school will be saved from. A year after that tragedy, the first assessments of the reconstruction and the safety of the Spezzino territory have begun. For example, according to some sources, the media and the highest authorities have portrayed the reconstruction of Vernazza as a virtuous example. However, some citizens have compiled a dossier indicating that the situation is far from virtuous. In general, the commitment to safeguarding the territory does not seem particularly significant, with urgent works being done, a lack of planning interventions, and continuous issuance of building permits for extremely invasive large projects. A shocking example is the collapse of a landslide on the Via dell'Amore in Riomaggiore, following just a few hours of rain.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Campi Bisenzio del 15 novembre 1991

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Campi Bisenzio on November 15, 1991
Whole_Text.content: The flood of November 15, 1991, in Campi Bisenzio, caused by the breaking of the banks of the Bisenzio River, was the third major flood to hit the Tuscan town in the 20th century, after those of 1926 and 1966. Unlike the previous ones, this flood did not affect the outskirts or peripheral neighborhoods but the main town and was not an unexpected event. The alarm had indeed been raised in the early hours of the afternoon of November 15, and the situation became serious around 8 PM, when the level of the Bisenzio became truly concerning, leading to the decision to close the historic bridge of the main town. Around 10 PM, the waters of the Bisenzio overflowed into the Santa Maria neighborhood, passing through the houses along the bank, but about twenty minutes later, the Bisenzio broke the bank-road on the opposite side, in the area of the Corti district, and the flooding of the main town began. The waters invaded a large part of the main town, particularly the districts of Corti and Case Nove and the area of the Central Post Office, reaching the areas of Maccione and via Palagetta. The only victim of the flood was an eighty-three-year-old woman, Dina Nistri, residing in the Corti area, close to the breach, who was swept away by the waters in her garden. The damages from the flood, which would later trigger a fierce controversy, were estimated at 144 billion lire of the time. Since that November 1991, hydraulic restoration and the care of the waterways in the area would become one of the top priorities of the various municipal administrations.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Campi Bisenzio del 22 novembre 1926

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Campi Bisenzio on November 22, 1926
Whole_Text.content: The flood of November 22, 1926, was the first of three major floods that struck the municipality of Campi Bisenzio in the 20th century and was caused by the breaking of the banks of the Bisenzio River, the Ombrone Pistoiese, and the Marinella stream. The flood of the Bisenzio arrived unexpectedly in the capital in the late evening of November 21, when the river level became alarming, and shortly after, the waters began to overflow into the city streets through the windows of the riverside houses. The fate of the municipal capital seemed sealed when the Bisenzio broke the bank at the bend of Via XXIV Maggio near the first houses of the San Martino district. The breach was about fifty meters long, and from it, the river's waters poured into San Martino itself, then reaching San Piero a Ponti and the plain of Sant'Angelo a Lecore, where the Ombrone Pistoiese had also broken its banks in the meantime. In some areas, the waters reached a level of two meters. At the same time, the Bisenzio and the Marinella stream also broke their banks near the Capalle district, and their waters reached the level of the first floor of the houses. The only victim of the flood was a forty-year-old farmer from San Piero a Ponti, Emilio Scuffi, who suffered a heart attack at the sight of the waters flooding his home. The rescue efforts were quite ineffective, although the now-dominant fascist regime did not allow protests or excessive demands, also due to the absolute unpreparedness of the municipal administration, which in previous years had even sold two barges, bought for potential emergencies, because they had never been used. The damage from the flood was significant, and there were no reimbursements, although the repair of the banks by the Civil Engineering was quick and effective. The collapsed pedestrian bridge of San Martino was permanently restored only in 1939. The poor organization of the rescue efforts was ultimately fatal for the last mayor, Emilio Cioppi, who was replaced in the following months by a government-appointed podestà.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Crotone on October 14, 1996, was a disaster caused by a flood of the Esaro stream, resulting in the inundation of a large area of the city of Crotone, especially near its industrial area, which caused the death of 6 people, thousands of displaced individuals, and damage to 358 businesses amounting to 126 billion lire in 1996.

On October 14, 1996, the city of Crotone, on the Ionian side of Calabria, suffered a violent flood following heavy rainfall that added to the significant rains that had already affected the province the previous week, saturating the land and causing floods and overflow of several watercourses in the area, including the Passovecchio stream and the Esaro river. In the morning, approximately 120 mm of rain fell particularly on the basin of the latter (which brought the total for the week to 330 mm), thus overloading all the tributaries of the Esaro coming from the Cutro area. In the locality of "Isola Capo Rizzuto station," an uncontrollable and violent flood of the same river formed (later calculated with a flow rate of over 1000 m³/s). The flood reached the "Gabelluccia" district in the western outskirts of Crotone around noon: a mass of water and mud submerged the ground floors of the houses in the same neighborhood, subsequently extending towards the industrial area, affecting both the buildings on the left bank, which had already been flooded previously due to the overflow of the Papaniciaro tributary, and those on the right bank, near the "Gesù" district, after which the water also reached the historic city center, channeling along via Nicoletta. The flood caused 6 fatalities (Paolo Pupa, Angela Trovato, Luca Buscema, Michela Cicchetto, Luca Tavano, and Bruno Comisso) and immense damage: numerous industrial prefabricated buildings were swept away by the water, and the commercial and industrial area of the city was heavily devastated. In some streets of the inhabited center, the water even reached four meters in height. The effects of the overflow were further aggravated by heavy illegal construction: the neighborhoods of Gabelluccia and Gesù, the latter built close to the Montecatini plant, had indeed emerged in the 1980s, in the floodplain expansion areas. Almost all the bridges were destroyed. 358 businesses were affected with damages amounting to 126 billion lire in 1996.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Genoa on October 7, 1970, which continued on October 8, occurred as a result of extremely heavy rainfall. This led to the overflow of the Bisagno, Fereggiano, and Leira streams and the flooding of the Sturla, Polcevera, Chiaravagna, and Cantarena streams. Very intense and localized rains, typical of the Ligurian coast and the autumn period, accumulated 948 mm of water in 24 hours. Genoa was the most affected, but severe damage also occurred in another 20 municipalities in the province, with Masone being the hardest hit. There were 43 victims, including 35 dead and 8 missing. More than 2000 people were displaced. On November 4, 2011, a similar event would hit essentially the same area, and on October 9 and 10, 2014, an even more violent one occurred. The neighborhoods of Quezzi, Foce, Molassana, San Fruttuoso, Marassi, Brignole, Sestri Ponente, and Voltri were heavily affected.

The events were mainly due to the heavy rainfall that occurred on October 7 and 8. On the evening of the first day in Voltri, there was a violent flooding of the Leira stream that resulted in 13 confirmed victims. The rainfall continued, leading to the violent flooding of the Bisagno and Fereggiano streams in the afternoon; especially the flooding of the former caused many and countless victims, affecting Marassi and Quezzi (an wing of one of the Biscione buildings also collapsed), primarily, but the neighborhoods of Foce and Brignole were also hit, with the floods amplified by concurrent storm surges, which prevented the waters from flowing out to sea. There were numerous evacuees and interruptions to gas, electricity, and water supplies.

Whole_Text.header: The collapse of the Sant'Agata Bridge
Whole_Text.content: Due to the destructive flood of the Bisagno, the ancient Sant'Agata Bridge, overlooking the Borgo Incrociati, partially collapsed, remaining with only the central arches, isolated from the two banks of the stream. Built in the Middle Ages, it had been used until then as a pedestrian passage.
The Genoese singer-songwriter Fabrizio De André dedicated one of his most famous songs, Dolcenera, to the event, which is included in his last album Anime salve from 1996.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Grosseto on November 4, 1966, was a disastrous event that affected the city of Grosseto, the surrounding plain, and part of the Ombrone Valley. The causes were the intense rains that occurred in the days leading up to it along the basin of the Ombrone River and its tributary, the Orcia. This was part of a widespread event of heavy rainfall that affected much of Italy during those days, leading to similar floods on the same day in Florence, Venice, Chioggia, Pisa, and other cities in central-northern Italy. The waters of the Ombrone broke the banks on the morning of November 4, 1966, overflowing and flooding the countryside, causing significant damage in the provincial capital, where in some areas the water reached three and a half meters in height. The flood was not a simple overflow but rather a collapse at four points of the Ombrone River's embankment; this was partly caused by the sirocco winds that hindered the outflow to the sea, as well as by the embankment of the bridge on the Aurelia state road, commonly known as the Mussolini bridge. There was only one death since November 4 was a holiday at the time, and therefore all major activities were halted. To understand the magnitude of the phenomenon, it is important to note that the average flow of the Ombrone River is 25 m³/s, and on that day it exceeded 4000 m³/s. At the Acquisti Farm, in the countryside of Braccagni north of the city, one victim was counted, the buttero Santi Quadalti, who was swept away by the flood while trying to save his herds, and he was awarded the gold medal.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Palermo in 1931 is the last major flood (with loss of human life) recorded that struck the city of Palermo.

In Palermo, five different floods are recorded between the 19th and 20th centuries. In fact, the floods of 1557, 1666, 1689, 1769, 1772, 1778, 1851, 1862, 1907, 1925, and finally, at its peak, the flood of 1931 are remembered. Since then, no further disasters of this magnitude have been reported.

Between February 20 and 24, 618 mm of rain fell on the city, of which 395 mm occurred in 50 hours of continuous rain between February 21 and 23. The configuration of Palermo, a basin located at the base of high mountains, facilitated the rise in water levels, which varied at different points in the city from 2 m on Via Roma to 6 m in Piazza Sant'Onofrio: in fact, the Conca d'oro is not homogeneous but characterized at several points by large depressions. Another factor that influenced this was the presence, above and below the city level, of four main water flows: the Canale Passo di Rigano, the Papireto, the Kemonia, and the Oreto River; some of these channels were artificially diverted below street level. In addition to the large volume of water, the city was hit by a strong north wind that destroyed several walls.

The flood caused the death of 10 people and injured another 21. Several homes and roads were destroyed, many historic buildings suffered severe damage, and the railway line was torn apart. There were also significant damages in the countryside, where rural homes were swept away. Furthermore, the crane used for the construction of the Post Office building was uprooted by the strong wind, collapsing onto an adjacent building.

Due to the high water level, rescue efforts were delayed; boats and temporary bridges were organized to transport to safety the people who had taken refuge on the upper floors of the houses. The wind also made it difficult to construct floating bridges.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Salerno on October 25-26, 1954, was a serious disaster caused by exceptionally heavy rainfall; the tragedy was sometimes worsened in the affected areas by reckless deforestation, which favored some extensive and destructive landslides.
The rain started to fall at 1:00 PM with 175mm of water, then in the evening it increased by 684 times. On October 26, however, it fell 450 times more, reaching 1309mm of water.

The most affected area was that in the Campania region, from the Amalfi Coast to the city of Salerno, specifically the locations of Vietri sul Mare, Cava de' Tirreni, Salerno, Maiori, Minori, and Tramonti. The devastation was immense: landslides, sinkholes, collapsed bridges, roads and railways destroyed in multiple places, houses swept away, and basements flooded. The damages were estimated to exceed 45 billion lire. The fury of the waters caused extensive landslides, one of which, detached from the slope of a recently deforested mountain, swept away the village of Molina and a nearby monumental aqueduct bridge, called "Ponte del Diavolo." The two streams Bonea and Cavaiola coming from Cava de' Tirreni carried down such a quantity of debris that it expanded and increased the current beach of Vietri sul Mare known as Marina. The entire Salerno coast changed its appearance, resulting in numerous points being more advanced due to the influx of debris. In Maiori, the high neighborhoods, a large part of the historic center, and some buildings along the Reginna stream were damaged, which, blocked by the trunks of trees carried down by the waters, eroded the foundations of the buildings along its course, causing their facades to collapse. Subsequently, the destroyed houses were replaced with modern buildings, which currently characterize the center of Maiori. In the Town Hall, there is a plaque that remembers and lists the names of the 37 victims of the flood in October 1954.

In total, there were 318 victims (including dead and missing), 250 injured, and about 5,500 homeless. In Salerno, the victims were around a hundred and about 100 injured; in Vietri sul Mare, the victims were over 100; in Cava de' Tirreni, 37; in Maiori, 37; in Tramonti, 35.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Sarno e Quindici del 1998

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Sarno and Quindici in 1998
Whole_Text.content: The Sarno and Quindici flood, or Sarno landslide, was a large-scale landslide that, between May 5 and 6, 1998, particularly affected the urban areas of Campania, including Sarno (SA), Quindici (AV), Siano (SA), Bracigliano (SA), and San Felice a Cancello (CE), resulting in the death of 161 people. Following these events, the Prefecture of Naples decided to activate an environmental monitoring network, created and installed by a company in the sector, to ensure the monitoring of rainfall and its effects on the evolution of the flood.

The area of the Sarno district, like all the heights surrounding the homonymous plain, is made up of two distinctly separated geological domains. The base substrate consists of limestone rocks, above which the various historical eruptions of Vesuvius have deposited successive layers of pyroclasts. These two domains are well differentiated and described by numerous geological surveys conducted in historical and recent times. They constitute two sets of different densities, with compact limestone, and the layers of pyroclasts being more loose and incoherent. These two layers were held together by natural vegetation, as well as by terraced cultivation practices. The abandonment of the latter has led to the slopes being invaded by ruderal vegetation, which has been burned multiple times, and which did not ensure the same continuity between limestone and pyroclasts.

In May 1998, the area of the Sarno district was hit by an exceptional rainfall event, with over 240/300 millimeters of rain falling within 72 hours. This event caused the dissolution of the continuity between limestone and pyroclasts, leading to the catastrophic sliding of the latter over the former. On May 5 at 3:00 PM, the first landslide detached from Mount Pizzo d'Alvano, grazing the underlying inhabited areas, while the rain fell incessantly on Sarno, Bracigliano, and Siano. The Salerno prefecture was notified of the occurrence of landslides only around 4:30 PM. At 5:00 PM, several landslides and debris flows began to slide down, overwhelming Sarno and nearby locations, destroying dozens of homes. Meanwhile, news of a landslide in Siano also arrived. The first rescue teams reached the valley after about an hour, just as a mud and debris avalanche struck Quindici, located on the opposite side of Mount Pizzo d'Alvano, burying the town and the Casamanzi fraction. Shortly after, the Episcopio fraction of Sarno was hit by a massive flow that destroyed the entire settlement. During the evening, while other landslides affected Sarno and Quindici, causing some blackouts, several dead and injured were extracted from the mud: the latter were transported to the largest hospital in the area, Villa Malta in Sarno. But the situation took on catastrophic proportions between 11:31 PM and midnight on May 6, when a massive landslide again overwhelmed Sarno, invading the Villa Malta hospital and burying two doctors, three nurses, the hospital porter, and five patients (including two children) under the mud. The first helicopters flew over the area only after 6:00 AM.

After days of digging through mud and rubble, the final toll reached 161 dead. Among the victims of the disaster was also a rescuer, firefighter Marco Mattiucci, who was awarded the gold medal for civil valor for his heroism during the rescue efforts.

According to some sources, only ten hours after the incident, the regional environmental assessor of Campania, Angelo Grillo, sent a fax to the mayors of the area predicting the possibility of catastrophic events: "It is reported that the orographic configuration and the geo-environmental characteristics of your municipal territory, in conjunction with particular ongoing rainy events, can lead to unpredictable situations of instability resulting in catastrophic landslides. This is communicated for the purpose of activating any necessary measures to ensure the safeguarding of public and private safety." Once the severity of the situation was confirmed, numerous detachments of law enforcement, firefighters, and volunteers from all over Italy rushed to the site to assist the affected populations. In addition to the high number of victims - including several children - many people were rescued from the mudslide; among them was the current deputy mayor Roberto Robustelli, then a little over twenty years old, who was pulled alive after more than three days from the under-stair area where he had been dragged by the force of the sludge. After the initial emergency phase was over, several criminal proceedings were opened against members of the municipal administration of Sarno, aimed at determining any responsibilities. On May 5, 2010, Mayor Gerardo Basile, initially found not guilty regarding the charge of multiple involuntary manslaughter in the first two levels of judgment, had his appeal sentence annulled by the Court of Cassation. This judgment - motivated by the fact that, according to the Court, the mayor's conduct was "passive" in managing the events - referred the case back to the Court of Appeal in Naples for a new trial. In December 2011, the Court of Appeal sentenced Basile to five years in prison, confirmed by the Cassation in 2013; the sentence was then reduced by three years due to the 2006 pardon, while the remaining two years were served under probation in community service.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Verona in 1882 was a flood of the Adige River that struck the city in September 1882. It was one of the most devastating floods of the river and caused numerous damages and casualties. Following this, Verona began, a few years later, the construction of high embankments as a barrier.

Verona has certainly benefited greatly from its position in the bend of the river, but it has also suffered significant destruction due to its floods. Paul the Deacon and Pope Gregory I recount the disastrous flood of October 17, 589, which submerged the city and destroyed part of the city walls. On the facade of the Church of Santo Stefano, there is a graffiti that commemorates the flood of 1195, and on a fresco at San Zeno, there is a remembrance of that of 1239. Later, other floods are noted in 1512 and 1568. In the 19th century, the Adige also overflowed in 1835 and 1868, culminating in the most devastating flood, that of 1882.

Already from the first days of September 1882, the water level of the Adige was increasingly rising due to the abundant rains. The warm winds blowing over the mountains also melted the early snowfalls that had occurred. The millers and residents of the houses by the river were therefore prepared to face the flood but not the magnitude it would have. Indeed, measures were taken to reinforce the moorings at San Lorenzo, at the Filippini, in Via Sottoriva, and in other more exposed areas; floodgates were also used to protect doors and windows on the ground floors. Among the causes of the violent flood were the changes to the river's course in Trentino, made during the construction of the Brenner railway, and the arrangement of many streams that increased the speed of the flood wave. There was also talk of agricultural works that had altered the river's hydrography upstream of the city. September 14 was the most terrifying day. Many mills broke the chains with which they had been previously secured and were swept away by the current. One crashed against the Ponte Nuovo, bringing it down. On September 17, over two-thirds of Verona were submerged by water; boats could not even pass under the arches of Porta Borsari. At Ponte Pietra, the water had reached a height of 4 meters and 50 above the warning signal, while the estimated speed of the current was 20 km/h. The mobilization of the army was immediate and essential, arriving with landing craft and military engineering units from Legnago and Peschiera del Garda. The city found itself enveloped in darkness, many people were isolated, and some houses collapsed. In the area of Piazza Isolo, 11 residents died in the collapse of their home. On September 27, the city was visited by King Umberto I, who came from Rome to assess the disaster and to bring comfort to the Veronese.

The damage assessment was extremely heavy. The most noticeable can thus be summarized. The printing house of the newspaper l'Arena was also flooded and had to suspend publications for a few days. The city, after the waters receded, was covered in mud and other sediments up to human height. Work immediately began to restore normalcy. Despite the belief that it would take years of work or even doubts about the city's ultimate survival, a remedy was found in relatively short time. These city restoration works will culminate in the securing of the Adige River through the burial of the Canale dell'Acqua Morta and the construction of embankments as a riverbank.

Whole_Text.content: During the flooding of the Meuse in 1993, large parts of Dutch Limburg were flooded. In Belgium and France, small rivers also overflowed their banks. Six people died. High water levels occurred in the Meuse basin after a period of persistent rain. On December 20, 1993, the Meuse overflowed its banks for the first time, and on December 22, this happened in several places in the province of Limburg. The areas around Roermond and Venlo, specifically the villages of Gennep, Itteren, and Borgharen, located on the eastern bank, were affected. On the western bank, Neer was the hardest hit. About 8% (18,000 ha) of the area of the province of Limburg was underwater. Several municipalities in Brabant along the Meuse also experienced water damage. Approximately 12,000 people were evacuated. The total damage amounted to 254 million guilders. Never before had such a high discharge been measured: 3,120 m3/s. In Borgharen, the Meuse reached a record height of 45.90 meters above sea level. Just over a year later, in January 1995, the areas along the Meuse were again hit by large-scale flooding.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in 1845 was one of the largest floods in the territory of Bohemia and Moravia in modern times. It was surpassed (though not everywhere) only after more than 150 years by the flood in 2002. The maximum water flow in Prague during the flood in 1845 is estimated at 4500 m³/s.

The flood had an impact on the construction of railways: because most of the lines were built relatively shortly after it, the lines were designed to avoid being affected. Therefore, the lines were largely operational even during later floods. In Moravia, a large part of Břeclav was flooded during these floods due to poorly designed railway embankments. This was also reflected in later transportation construction projects.
Drought in the Czech Republic 2015–2020

The Oder flood of 2010 was one of the largest floods of the Oder since the beginning of water level recordings. Since all three riparian states had made huge efforts for flood protection after the devastating Oder flood in 1997, the damages remained far below those of the summer of 1997. At the same time, and due to the same precipitation event, the Vistula basin was also hit by a catastrophic flood with huge damages and loss of life.

Already in the upper Oder catchment area, the flood developed into the second largest since the end of the war. From May 15 to May 20, 2010, 350 to 370 mm of rain fell in the Czech catchment area of the Oder. This quickly led to the formation of an extreme flood. At the Czech-Polish border, on May 17, a flow of about 2100 cubic meters per second was recorded, the second largest since records began. In 1997, over 2800 cubic meters per second flowed here. The third largest flood is considered to be that of August 1985 with 1155 cubic meters per second. The flood retention basin Buków (Oder-km 29–32.5), completed in 2002, was opened on the night of May 17 to 18 and relieved the Oder by about 300 cubic meters per second, reducing the flow in the Oder from 74% to now 63% of the peak flow of 1997. At the downstream Oder gauge Miedonia, the peak level on May 18 was accordingly 1.6 m below the peak value of 1997, making it still the second highest water level recorded there since 1947.

The Brandenburg State Environment Agency compiled and published the highest water levels in 2012. The threshold values for the highest alert level were reached and exceeded in the upper German section of the Oder from Ratzdorf to Frankfurt (Oder). Alert level IV was declared on May 26 and 28 for these river sections and remained in effect until the end of May. Alert level III applied to the entire downstream section of the Oder. It was not until June 23, 2010, that the entire German/Polish section of the Oder was free of alert levels.

Whole_Text.content: The Magdalene flood of 1480 was a devastating flood disaster that struck the area around the Aare and Rhine rivers, as well as other rivers in the Swiss central region and Upper Rhine area, in July 1480.

As with other extreme flooding events, such as the Magdalene flood of 1342, the Oder flood of 1997, the Elbe flood of 2002, or the flooding in Central Europe in 2013, the flood was likely triggered by a Vb weather situation. After the water levels of the rivers had already been very high due to prolonged rain in May and June, hot days in early summer caused intense snowmelt. In mid-July, continuous rain set in (according to the Bernese Chronicle of Diebold Schilling, it rained in torrents for three days without interruption in Ströme), which led to the flooding.

The beginning of the flood is set for July 21 in the Bernese Oberland and Fribourg in Üechtland. In Bern, the Aare overflowed its banks in the Matte district and in Marzili on July 22 – during the night of July 23 – flooding the streets, gardens, and apartments. In Basel, the peak of the flood was on July 24.
According to the chronicles, all bridges over the Aare and Rhine between Bern and Strasbourg were completely or partially destroyed.

The Magdalene flood of 1480 was rated as the greatest flood disaster in Switzerland. According to researchers, the water levels were up to 90 centimeters higher than during the great Alpine flood of 2005.
