The flood of the Tarn in 1930 is a centennial flood of the Tarn, its tributaries the Agout and the Aveyron, its sub-tributaries the Thoré and the Arnette, and also of the Garonne. It caused a devastating flood from March 1 to 4, 1930, in several departments of the Southwest of France.

Thousands of houses, dozens of bridges, and kilometers of roads and railways are damaged or destroyed; hundreds of deaths are reported. In Montauban, the capital of Tarn-et-Garonne, Arthur Poncelet, Adolphe Poult, his friend René Bousquet, and Marcel Lefranc save dozens of people from drowning. In the same department, the city of Moissac is the most affected by these devastating floods. The departments of Aude, Lot-et-Garonne (including Agen) and Tarn are also particularly impacted. These catastrophic events led to a national day of mourning on March 9, 1930 — for the first time in France in the 20th century — after the then President of the Republic, Gaston Doumergue, himself from the South of France, visited the site, accompanied by André Tardieu. The French government allocates significant financial aid to rebuild the devastated areas, supported by national and international solidarity (Yugoslavia, Netherlands, Morocco), particularly in Moissac, the most affected municipality by these exceptional floods described as the "flood of the century." François Coty participates in the efforts by constructing four model farms designed by architects to withstand future floods, offering them in full ownership to deserving families. Pope Pius XI sends a check to the bishop of Montauban for the care of the victims. The number of deaths due to these floods is now estimated at around 700.

Article_Name: Inondation de Vaison-la-Romaine en septembre 1992 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Vaison-la-Romaine in September 1992 is a submersion phenomenon caused by heavy rainfall and significant impermeability of the land. This disaster occurred on Monday, September 21, and Tuesday, September 22, 1992, in Vaison-la-Romaine, in the French department of Vaucluse in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region. It resulted in 37 deaths and 4 disappearances, in four municipalities.

The floods in Vaison-la-Romaine are due to a large-scale meteorological phenomenon in the southeast region of France, affecting several departments: on September 21, 1992, heavy rains fell on the departments of Hérault, Gard, Lozère, and Ardèche, particularly on the Cévennes mountains. The municipality of Caylar received 448 mm of precipitation in 24 hours, which was a record for the Hérault department until September 16, 2023, when Roqueredonde received 550 mm in 24 hours. These rains followed a weather pattern above the norms for the region, with average temperatures being higher than normal, combined with a low-pressure area in the Bay of Biscay. The next day, the rains continued in Gard, especially in the morning, where the regions of Sommières and Nîmes were swept by a brief and violent storm accompanied by strong gusts of wind, as well as part of Ardèche, then the rain front crossed the Rhône, affecting the departments of Vaucluse and Drôme. The showers on September 22 were the result of a thunderstorm front of west/east flow blocked on the western flank of Mont Ventoux from the afternoon. With this thunderstorm system remaining stationary over part of the Ouvèze watershed, the municipality of Orange, northwest of the Vaucluse department, received 51 mm of cumulative rainfall, while Carpentras, south of the Dentelles de Montmirail, received 212 mm.

The first alert bulletin from Météo-France to the Ministry of the Interior, and then to local authorities, dates back to September 21, 1992. That same evening, the prefect of Vaucluse relayed this state of alert for the implementation of security and protection services. On September 22, 1992, two other messages from Météo France to Marignane, late at night and early in the morning, confirmed the alert by announcing storms of rare violence. Despite everything, the rain, which was heavy in Vaison-la-Romaine in the middle of the morning, stopped around noon. The city's rescue services faced several difficulties: the events took place on a Tuesday, the day of the weekly market, and there was an increased influx; the evacuation requests made to clients and tourists (who were numerous at the end of the summer season) at the municipal campsite, located upstream of the Roman bridge, had little effect. The first moderate shower (17.8 mm) fell between 10 a.m. and noon. It was followed, in the early afternoon, by a much more violent second shower (182.7 mm) that lasted until 3:15 p.m. The teachers at the Jules Ferry school, then located near the course of the Ouvèze, secured the students on the first floor of the building farthest from the river. The total rainfall in Entrechaux was 300 mm (300 liters of water per square meter) in six hours (perhaps a little more locally). For comparison, the annual average precipitation in Paris is 637 mm. During this meteorological event, nearly 1,320 km² received more than 100 mm of precipitation. The storm, of unprecedented violence, stagnated on the slopes of Mont Ventoux for several hours. It dumped 215 mm of water in Malaucène, 179 mm in Vaison, and 143 mm in Buis-les-Baronnies. The heavy rains upstream of Vaison-la-Romaine were such that a mudslide, about 50 cm deep, invaded and completely covered the municipal campsite around 3 p.m. A water height of 10 cm already covered the streets of the lower town. The first news arrived, there were deaths at the Moulin de César campsite. The area reserved for the associative camping À cœur joie — 450 pitches — was swept away. It was learned that there were many victims in the Théos neighborhood subdivision, located on the right bank, which was submerged by the floodwaters. At the same time, a torrent of mud swept through the municipal campsite, carrying everything in its path: caravans, vehicles, and campers. In the minutes that followed, at the Roman bridge, whose deck is located less than twenty meters from the river's normal level, the water reached 17 meters, which is 15 meters above its normal course. Images of caravans crashing against the Roman bridge are etched in memory. The fire station, located near the bed of the Ouvèze, was then flooded, along with the building and rescue equipment. The ORSEC Plan was triggered at 5 p.m. The water level only began to recede after 10 p.m. Of the three bridges on the Ouvèze, only the ancient Roman bridge withstood, despite some damage to the parapet.

Later, we will learn that the same phenomenon has already occurred, at least once, in Vaison. In the municipal archives of the city, a deliberation dated August 1616 indicates that "the city council had to repair the parapet of the Roman bridge destroyed by a flood that also swept away several houses." There is no mention of any victims. In the 17th century, the people of Vaison lived in the upper town, and around the cathedral, covering the ruins of ancient Vasio, there were only gardens. The risk was known but neglected. Before the tragedy, following the disaster of October 3, 1988, in Nîmes, engineer Ponton mentioned in his April 1989 report, 62 cities, including Vaison-la-Romaine, likely to be victims of flooding due to rain runoff. Jean-Pierre Mazeillier had described the Land Use Plan (POS) of Vaison as "completely crazy" when he took over the technical services of the town hall and could not find any trace of Ponton's report. The Deferre decentralization law had transferred urban planning authority from the prefect to the mayors in 1982. On October 14, 1983, the mayor at the time, André Thès, revised the POS and declared the right bank of the Ouvèze buildable for more than a kilometer. The area had not even been classified as a "low flood zone." The price of land had multiplied by a factor greater than 10. Scientific studies have been conducted on the centennial flood of 1992. They provide reasons for the extent of the damage. In the area of the Salette torrent, a tributary of the Brégoux, which is itself a tributary of the Ouvèze, in the heart of the Dentelles de Montmirail, 200.5 millimeters of rain fell in the span of five hours. The figures are known thanks to the Bernardins station in Beaumes-de-Venise. This represented a volume of 4.2 million cubic meters of water that fell in the watershed of this torrent, which has an area of only 28 km². The report of the inquiry commission on "the causes of the floods and the means to remedy them" also mentions other reasons such as a geological impermeability specific to this Ouvèze valley but also aggravating anthropogenic modifications: "an impermeabilization of the soils leading to urban rain runoff and finally the presence of constructions in the riverbed itself." The Ouvèze is a 123 km river, originating in Montauban-sur-l'Ouvèze, in the Drôme department, and flowing into the Rhône at Sorgues, after watering 28 municipalities. Many watercourses are tributaries of the Ouvèze, notably the Toulourenc, between Mollans-sur-Ouvèze and Entrechaux. Of the 820 km² of the Ouvèze watershed, 580 km² is located upstream of Vaison-la-Romaine.

This tragedy of September 22 caused the death of more than 40 people, swept away by the Ouvèze or its tributaries. The most commonly reported number of victims is 46 dead, plus one in Beaumes-de-Venise, which is often forgotten in the statistics. Thirty-eight people lost their lives that day in the Haut-Vaucluse, including 34 in Vaison-la-Romaine. Among them were fifteen residents of the Theos housing estate and at least eleven campers from the Moulin de César campsite. This unprecedented flood struck many villages downstream from Vaison, also causing deaths: three in Séguret; an old farmer who went to look for his cow in Gigondas, which was found alive; four campers swept away by the waters of the Brégoux in Aubignan; a pedestrian who tried to cross the bridge swept away by the flood of the Salette in Beaumes-de-Venise, as well as four missing persons, including a six-month-old baby. Nine months later, in 1993, a body was found in the municipality of Roaix by a firefighter dog handler from Vaison. Without the courage of a firefighter who saved 36 people with a borrowed boat, the death toll would have been much higher. As the water receded on the morning of September 23, bulldozers and trucks were able to work in the streets to remove the wrecks of vehicles covered with river silt and all the debris it had carried. To prevent looting, the flooded area was cordoned off by the army, with soldiers monitoring the entrances to the city and the main affected villages and patrolling in front of the houses. During the first five years following the disaster, the investigation stalled. Only the prefect of Vaucluse, who was in office in 1965, was implicated in 1995. The judge closed the investigation at the beginning of 1998, after ordering new investigations into the studies conducted for building permits. These studies "clearly implicated the systematic concreting of at-risk areas, particularly natural floodplain basins." Two years after the disaster, building permit applications were submitted to construct in the flood-prone areas of the city. Some survivors in Vaison were able to relocate to the clos d'Ariston, a plot purchased and serviced by the municipality. Few of them left the city, as the insurance companies reimbursed them well, while others were able to buy older properties.

The material damage was estimated at 500 million francs (a little over 76 million euros). Despite spontaneous solidarity, subsidies, and insurance reimbursements, the municipality became heavily indebted. More than 19,000 F per inhabitant (about 2,890 €). In the five years following the disaster, 115 million francs worth of work was carried out, amounting to 17.5 million euros. Furthermore, this renovation had a revised higher cost. The final bill amounted to nearly 460 million euros in damages, including 20 million just for Vaison. Ultimately, for this single municipality, the works totaled about 26 million euros, of which nearly 8 were borne by Vaison and its 6,000 inhabitants. While everything was done to prevent a new disaster, it came at the cost of heavy indebtedness.

It is true that Vaison, being a tourist town, needed to quickly restore an image that aligned with its objectives. The first measure taken was to make the areas along the Ouvèze river unbuildable. Seventy homes, including an entire housing development, were demolished. The riverbed was widened and the banks reinforced. Upstream, the municipal campsite was relocated and elevated. Where the Théos housing development once stood, huge stone blocks reinforced the bank, and a natural space was created. Further along, a health trail covers the former neighborhood of the Jardins de l'Ouvèze, and the Eminées and Magnans housing developments have become green spaces. The school was rebuilt. It is protected, like the lower town, by a long wall serving as a levee. Evacuation drills take place every year in all classes. If intervention is needed, the firefighters of Vaison, thanks to alert systems, are notified of a flood two hours in advance. Two non-negotiable hours, but enough to evacuate everyone. The alert is given through the installation of weather radars in Bollène and in the Gard. In 1992, according to the mayor at the time, there were none, but there was one in Nîmes named Mélody, which had been struck by lightning the night before...

If on the left bank of the Ouvèze, the industrial zone has healed its wounds, it has not moved. Many have reopened their businesses on site. For an economic reason: moving would involve both buying land and rebuilding, and the insurance companies did not follow. However, a new activity zone has been created higher up, but it has only attracted two companies. Moreover, "local media regularly echo the local urban planning plans (PLU) that are challenged and most often annulled a few months later by the courts. The reasons are almost systematically, in addition to formal irregularities, the transformation of agricultural land, often located in flood-prone areas or adjacent to them, into building land." The primary cause is that land prices have reached new heights throughout the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region. For reasons of quality of life and sunshine, it is the region of France with the fastest-growing population due to the arrival of retirees as well as working families. Thus, for some, the temptation is great to want to multiply the value of agricultural land by twenty or thirty simply by classifying it as building land. In the event of a flood, even less severe than that of September 22, everyone knows that the damage would be considerable, including in terms of human lives.

Whole_Text.header: The floods in Vaucluse, Ardèche, and Drôme
Whole_Text.content: Sixty-three municipalities were affected in Vaucluse, the most impacted, besides Vaison, Séguret, Gigondas, Beaumes-de-Venise, and Aubignan, being Violès, Bédarrides, Jonquières, and Sarrians. The next day, the extent of the damage was discovered: roads washed away, vineyards gone, bridges destroyed like those in Roaix and Beaumes-de-Venise. A desolation that intensified in the municipalities of Vaucluse affected by the flood, with 2,300 houses or businesses counted as damaged in the department, including 320 in Vaison that were either demolished or needed repairs. But Vaucluse was not the only affected department. On September 22, there was a centennial flood of the Ardèche that caused five deaths in the south of that department, between Pont-de-Labeaume and Aubenas. The Drôme department was also severely affected, with water rising more than 2 meters in some villages along the Ouvèze. The municipality of Sainte-Jalle was particularly hard hit.

The flood in Genoa - Sestri Ponente on October 4, 2010, occurred due to a maritime thunderstorm, self-regenerating in nature, very violent and persistent, which struck with extreme violence a relatively small area of the western part of the city and Varazze. It caused the overflow of the streams Chiaravagna, Cantarena, and Molinassi, one victim, and significant material damage.

The storm cell that formed in the early morning of October 4 initially lingered for several hours (between 4:00 and 8:00) in the area of Varazze, dropping almost 300 mm of rain and causing the major streams to overflow and several landslides in the hills of the area. It then moved east, stopping in the western neighborhoods of the city between Pegli, Sestri Ponente, and the Polcevera valley, where it unleashed its full power, causing a true flash flood. In about five hours, between 8:00 and 13:00, over 400 mm of rain fell on the heights of Sestri Ponente, 380 mm on those of Pegli, and about 300 mm in the lower Polcevera valley between Pontedecimo and the mouth of the stream. A few dozen more millimeters of rain could have caused the Polcevera and many other secondary streams to overflow, resulting in significant damage.

Following the intense rainfall, in the early afternoon, the streams Chiaravagna, Cantarena, and Molinassi overflowed, while the Marotto stream and the buried streams Zanino and Monferrato broke through the asphalt of the roads beneath which they flowed. Almost the entire lower part of Sestri Ponente and Multedo was flooded: shops, garages, basements, squares, and streets suffered damage, from which the flow of water carried away parked cars. A worker from the nearby quarries of Monte Gazzo fell along with an embankment swallowed by the fury of the waters of the Chiaravagna stream and was found a few days later in the sea off Sestri Ponente: he was the only victim of the flooding event. The Molinassi stream, which flows covered by the Fincantieri warehouses in the last 440 meters, broke the right bank, an old stone wall, at the height of Piazza Clavarino, flooding the western part of Sestri Ponente and merging its waters with those that overflowed from the Cantarena stream in via Leoncavallo, under which it flows in the last 300 meters of its course. In the eastern part of the delegation, it was the Chiaravagna stream that overflowed at the dam created by the building at via Giotto 15, built right above its bed and then demolished in March 2013. The most western part was also flooded by the Marotto stream and the streams Zanino and Monferrato, which violently overflowed from the network of tunnels in which they had been channeled during the first half of the 20th century under the abandoned industrial warehouses of the former Multedo foundry and those that today house the Coop and other productive activities, and were discharged into the sea beyond the Genoa-Ventimiglia railway line, not far from the oil port docks. Other floods, fortunately without serious consequences, occurred in other low areas of the west such as the Multedo railway underpass, the one near Piazza Brin in Certosa, and throughout the Fiumara area in Sampierdarena.

Whole_Text.content: The floods in Bauska that occurred in 1928 were among the most devastating floods in the history of Bauska. The rise in the level of the Mēmele River caused by heavy summer rains on June 20 swept along logs carried by the river, flooded the streets of the old town of Bauska closest to the river, and destroyed part of the Mēmele Bridge. The rainy summer of 1928 caused floods in many places in Latvia and southern Estonia. During these years, there was active floating of logs cut down in the forest down the rivers to sawmills in Bauska, Jelgava, and Riga. By the beginning of June, a dangerously large accumulation of logs had formed near the Mēmele Bridge. However, the major floods began a couple of weeks later when the pressure of the Mēmele waters broke through log blockages about four kilometers before Bauska, and the logs carried by the current jammed at the Mēmele Bridge. Due to the rains, the water volume in the Mēmele doubled on June 20 and 21. The enormous log dam blocked the river and raised the water level by 6 meters above normal, flooding many city streets. The overflowing river swept away poorly secured log rafts, which jammed at the Mēmele Bridge, creating a wooden dam. Buildings and streets along the river were flooded. On Friday, June 22, at 4:00 AM, the logs carried by the current broke a section of the bridge about 10 meters long. The water and logs partially destroyed several buildings. The river water carved its way along the riverbank on the old town side, washing away and partially destroying riverside sheds, the Jewish synagogue, and several other buildings. The most affected by the floods were the Lower Mill owned by the German Stēbens, which suffered losses amounting to 8 million rubles, while the brewery of Teodors Lodiņš incurred losses of 300,000 rubles.

Starting from the evening of June 23, the water level has dropped by 3 meters, leaving behind logs. The Bauska municipality began organizing the removal of the logs, involving 350 workers for this task. Under the leadership of Mrs. Jura Varenā, the head of the Bauska branch of the Latvian Red Cross, the city ladies formed a relief committee that used funds provided by the Red Cross to distribute food—soup, bread, butter, meat, fish, sugar, etc.—to those affected by the floods for a couple of weeks. In the first few days, 300 people received assistance, with each person receiving help amounting to 64 santims per day. The destroyed bridge meant that Bauska no longer had land transport with 16 of the 20 parishes in the district. Trade in the market stopped, and industrial output decreased. Just a few weeks later, a raft bridge was opened for horse traffic, and a wooden walkway was built for pedestrians.

Article_Name: Aluvião na ilha da Madeira em 1803 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: The flood of 1803 was the most severe natural disaster recorded to strike the island of Madeira since its settlement. This natural disaster, which occurred on October 9, 1803, resulted in the death of hundreds of people, mainly in the municipalities of Funchal, Machico, Ribeira Brava, Santa Cruz, and Calheta. Its destructive capacity would only be matched 206 years later, on February 20, 2010, by the storm on the island of Madeira. Due to its tragic circumstances, it remains in the collective memory of the Madeiran people and is still commemorated today on the municipal holiday of Machico, on October 9.

October 9, 1803, was one of the most fateful days in the history of Madeira Island, but the series of events that led to it began ten to twelve days earlier, during which the island experienced intense, albeit intermittent, rainfall. On the morning of October 9, around eight o'clock, a period of precipitation began, although not very heavy, which would last for 12 hours, until around 8 PM. Shortly after 8 PM, the weather conditions worsened, the levels of precipitation increased significantly, and a stronger wind began to blow. Around 8:30 PM, the situation escalated, and the flow of the streams increased noticeably until, finally, it violently overflowed its banks. The conditions were set for one of the worst natural disasters to ever strike Madeira Island. The origin of such a great tragedy was an atmospheric situation characterized by the presence of southwest winds, thunderstorms, and heavy rainfall. The baldness of the mountains overlooking Funchal, clearly visible in the engravings of the time, and the lack of drainage for the streams within urban areas contributed to the worsening of the disaster. Faced with the seriousness of the situation, many inhabitants, caught by surprise, were unable to escape the danger, ultimately perishing. Some were caught in their escape by the strong currents that had overflowed the banks of the streams, many did not even attempt to flee, dying when their own houses collapsed or being crushed by the falling walls.

The municipality of Funchal was one of the most affected by this catastrophe and suffered the most in terms of the number of victims. One of the particularly affected areas was the neighborhood of Santa Maria Maior. The walls of the Ribeira de João Gomes, whose flow had already increased due to the intense rainfall of the previous days, burst in three locations. The water that overflows the banks at these three points forms such violent currents that it destroys almost everything in its path and is responsible for the deaths of many dozens of people. According to reports from the time, entire streets and numerous buildings were swept out to sea. The very Parish Church of Our Lady of Calhau, located on the left bank of the river, succumbs to the violence of the waters. In one house in this area, 21 inhabitants die. In another building in Pelourinho, an English subject and 15 family members die. The estimated number of victims in this neighborhood is shocking; it is estimated that, in this area alone, the flood claimed the lives of about 200 people. The rivers of Santa Luzia and Bom Jesus are also unable to withstand the high flow of water, which ends up overflowing the banks and causing great destruction. The street of Ferreiros suffers considerable damage, with several residential and commercial houses destroyed. The description is similar for Rua dos Tanoeiros and Rua Direita, where the scene of destruction repeats itself.

In the village of Machico, it can be read in the Parish Archive that the river wall was destroyed, as well as the existing bridge, and that the water descended upon the village with such intensity that it reached a height of three cubits in the Church and in all the streets. The same archive describes as "prodigious" the fact that only 14 people perished (swept away by the intensity of the currents or buried in their own homes), given the intensity of the catastrophe. The historic Chapel of the Lord of Miracles (at the time referred to as the Chapel of Christ), one of the oldest on the Island of Madeira, was also affected, having been almost completely destroyed by the currents. From the original chapel, only the ogival door and the crosses of the frontispiece remained. The image of the crucified Christ was swept out to sea and considered lost; however, it would eventually be recovered, almost intact, by an American galley that delivered it to the Cathedral of Funchal. This event, considered miraculous by the inhabitants of the region, would lead to the renaming of the chapel to the Chapel of the Lord of Miracles, as well as to a pilgrimage (one of the largest on the island) that takes place every year on October 9, in honor of the Lord of Miracles. In addition to the Chapel of the Lord of Miracles, several churches, as well as the archives of Foros, chapels, and brotherhoods, were also damaged.

The number of deaths resulting from this tragedy is not consensual. Some sources point to a number very close to 1000 fatalities. According to Cabral Nascimento, in a lengthy study on these events published in the Historical Archive of Madeira (Volumes 1 and 5), this flood caused more than 700 fatalities, and besides the city, there were also many damages in the other parishes in the South of the Island, namely in Campanário, Calheta, Tabua, Ribeira Brava, Santa Cruz, and especially in Machico, where fourteen people died. The governor and captain general D. José Manuel da Câmara, given the gravity of the events, published an edict adopting the necessary measures to mitigate the effects of the disaster. One of the first measures adopted was, naturally, to seek shelter for the many people who had been left homeless. Temporary accommodation was provided in various public buildings, state service offices, churches, chapels, fortresses, as well as many private houses. Another urgent measure was the prohibition of price increases for consumer goods under penalty of severe punishments for transgressors. Not remaining insensitive to the suffering of the Madeirans, the government of the metropolis, in February 1804, sent to Madeira Brigadier Reinaldo Oudinot with the task of directing the much-needed recovery works. On February 19, 1804, Brigadier Reinaldo Oudinot, a reputed engineering specialist, arrived in Madeira with the mission to oversee the recovery work from the damage caused by the great flood and to guide the construction of the lateral walls of the streams. He demonstrated, from the beginning, high competence in performing his duties. In a short period, he managed to pipe the three streams that cross Funchal. He is also responsible for one of the major planning moments of the city of Funchal, outlining a plan for its reconstruction, which refers to the expansion of the city to the north, east, and west. Also outside of Funchal, he developed laborious activities promoting the widening and strengthening of the walls of the banks of the Machico stream. He promoted the rapid reconstruction of many of the damaged structures in various parts of the island, relying on the free labor of many Madeirans who only received essential goods and exemption from certain taxes, all in accordance with the old "Ordenações," which had been in effect since the beginning of the settlement, to occur in exceptional events. Reinaldo Oudinot would die in the city of Funchal on February 11, 1807, but his services were not forgotten by the inhabitants of this city who named the street on the left bank of the João Gomes stream after him, between Campo da Barca and Praça dos Lavradores.

The flood in Carrara on September 23, 2003, was a violent downpour that struck the city of Carrara and the district of Avenza, causing the death of 2 people and significant damage to property. The disaster also involved 70 people who went to the emergency room, 30 displaced individuals, and another 15 who refused to leave their homes. Shops were inundated with 1 meter of water, and businesses were also paralyzed (sawmills closed and quarries unreachable), leading to much agitation among the people. There were also problems in the areas of Colonnata with the temporary suspension of gas in homes, Forno, and Torano. The maximum rainfall recorded was 140 millimeters over the course of an hour and a half, which was not predicted by weather reports.

On the evening of September 23, 2003, a violent downpour hit Carrara, causing only one victim. During the evening, a very intense thunderstorm developed, striking all of Massa and particularly the Apuan Alps, dumping 200 mm of rain in just two and a half hours. In a short time, the entire Carrione basin became saturated, overflowing at various points along its main course. The historic center of Carrara was fully affected by the flooding, which inundated the streets with nearly 2 meters of water, sweeping away cars and resulting in the death of a woman. Subsequently, the waters also invaded the district of Avenza.

Northern Italy was affected by a humid southwesterly flow, moving along the ascending branch of a vast trough extending from Scandinavia to all of Central Europe. The associated disturbance caused downpours and thunderstorms to pass through Northern Italy, affecting the southern area, including the Central Regions, Tuscany included. The influx of very warm and humid air from the Mediterranean, the strong southwesterly flow, and the orography of high Tuscany, which is very exposed to such flow, were among the triggering causes of the propagation of the violent thunderstorm.

Whole_Text.header: Procedures to follow after the flood

Whole_Text.content: The Municipality of Carrara implemented a plan on November 22, 2010, for collecting applications for compensation for damages suffered in 2003 in the former districts of Bonascola, Avenza, and Marina di Carrara.
On January 14, 2010, legal proceedings were initiated for the flood disaster in Carrara in 2003, in which 24 people were investigated, including two former mayors for manslaughter and flooding.

September 2003 already became part of history due to at least 4 sad episodes, from Val Canale to Taranto, from Syracuse to Carrara. A truly worrying frequency that affected geographically distant areas, and also orographically different.

Article_Name: Powódź w Polsce (2001) – Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia

Whole_Text.content: Poland flood July 2001 The flood in Poland (2001) – a flood that struck the Vistula River basin in July 2001. Its cause was heavy rainfall and storms. In southern Poland, high water levels persisted for 2-3 days, which led to seepage and breaches of the levees on the Vistula. There were also failures of hydraulic structures (including the breach of the dam of the under-construction Wióry reservoir on the Świślin, resulting in flooding of the southern part of Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski). The losses from the flood were estimated at 4 billion zlotys. In Gdańsk, the flood occurred on July 9, 2001. As a result, significant areas of the city were affected, including those along the Radunia Canal in the Orunia-Św. Wojciech-Lipce and Downtown districts, as well as areas along the Strzyża stream in the Wrzeszcz Górny and Wrzeszcz Dolny districts. The intense rainfall also affected, among others, Maków Podhalański, where on July 24, 94.6 mm of rain fell, and on July 25, as much as 190.8 mm. This caused an increase in water levels in rivers and streams, resulting in the destruction of the market, damage to municipal infrastructure, disruption of railway tracks, and damage to numerous homes. According to estimates, the losses related to public property exceeded 20 million zlotys.

Whole_Text.content: The Lech flood of 1910 was the strongest known flood of the Lech. It caused significant damage along the entire Lech. The city of Augsburg was hit hardest by the disaster.

The Alpine river Lech, the second largest tributary of the Bavarian Danube by water flow after the Inn, has experienced severe flooding since time immemorial. Its riverbed was originally mostly flat, kilometers wide, and intertwined. Almost every year, it swelled to multiple times its normal width and repeatedly sought a new bed in its gravel. Corrections to its riverbed from the late Middle Ages to the 19th century were primarily intended to make it navigable, increasing its flow speed, which deepened its bed even more. From Augsburg to its confluence with the Danube, the Lech had been flowing in an artificially regulated bed since the 1850s, but upstream it was still largely in its natural state. In June 1910, there was still a lot of snow in the Tyrolean mountains, which melted rapidly due to heavy rain on June 14. With the influx of both rainfall and meltwater, the Lech swelled into a raging river. In the Tyrolean Lechtal, it swept away seven bridges, and numerous timber rafting structures and barriers fell victim to it. At Steeg, it carried almost 300 cubic meters of water per second—compared to an average of only 12 cubic meters per second. At that time, the Forggensee did not yet exist to absorb the flood peaks. On the evening of June 15, the Lech reached a flow rate of over 1000 cubic meters per second at Landsberg, according to measurements at the time, and over 1400 cubic meters per second by today's estimates, destroying the Karolinenwehr there. In the lowlands of the Lechfeld, it flowed up to four kilometers wide. It reached almost to the edge of the settlement of Mering on the right and into the village of Haunstetten on the left. In Rain, five kilometers before the confluence with the Danube, the entire area north of the old town was flooded, causing significant damage in the so-called suburb (area of Donauwörther Straße). In Oberndorf am Lech, all local streets were underwater. The peak flow at the Lech confluence on June 16, 1910, was measured at 1250 cubic meters per second (average flow 116 cubic meters). Other rivers, such as the Iller, also experienced severe flooding at the same time, causing significant damage.

Whole_Text.header: The destruction of the high spillway.
Whole_Text.content: At the Augsburg Hochablass, the yellow-brown flood initially tore away a section of the weir, which was built of wood but fundamentally flood-resistant, at the two gravel passages, and then due to the gap created, further parts of the weir up to the log jam. Subsequently, the water destroyed the main lock of the city stream, the historic main lock building from 1798, and the restoration building. With great efforts, the military and the fire department managed to protect the well structure at the Hochablass, a construction on which Augsburg's drinking water supply completely depended, from destruction by reinforcing the bank with riprap, gravel-filled boxes, sandbags, and other natural materials. To reduce the risk of further damage, the entire Hochablass weir was blown up except for a small remaining stump on the eastern bank. The river tore away extensive stretches of the bank below the weir, where its bed was deeply incised, and destroyed seven properties on the Hochzoller bank. Parts of Hochzoll, Lechhausen, and the Jakobervorstadt were flooded. The tracks of line I of the Augsburg local railway were undermined and damaged. The 52-meter-high church tower of St. Pankratius in Lechhausen was severely damaged. The railway weir broke, putting the railway bridge at Hochzoll in great danger, as its middle pillar was threatened to be undermined. In Gersthofen, a large piece of the railway bridge, which was only seven years old, was torn away.

The damage amount from the Lech flood of 1910 for the city of Augsburg is estimated at around 5 million marks. Following the flood disaster, Augsburg faced great hardship due to a lack of water, as the break of the high discharge weir caused the capital stream, which was fed by it, and the Lech canals supplying Augsburg to run dry. All hydropower plants on these canals were shut down. Large companies switched to coal-powered steam engines, while many small businesses completely ceased operations. Since all the city's wastewater also flowed through these canals, their drying up also endangered the health of the population. However, a short-term reconstruction of the high discharge weir was out of the question. Therefore, a new temporary Lech diversion was established further upstream to supply the capital stream with water again.

In February 1911, work began on the construction of a new spillway, which was built for the first time in reinforced concrete and according to the latest state of technology. It was erected about 200 meters away from the old location, and the construction costs amounted to 1.5 million marks. On July 28, 1912, the official water inflow took place. In 1914, King Ludwig III visited the completed new spillway with the royal family, which is still commemorated today by a monument on the left bank of the weir.

Article_Name: 明治十八年の淀川洪水

Whole_Text.header: The Yodogawa Flood of the 18th year of Meiji.
Whole_Text.content: The Yodogawa flood of the 18th year of Meiji (Meiji 18) refers to the flood of the Yodogawa River that occurred from mid-June to July 1885. It is also known as the Great Meiji Flood. It caused damage second only to the Yodogawa flood that occurred in the 2nd year of Kyōwa (1802).

In June 1885 (Meiji 18), continuous rain fell from the beginning of the month due to the influence of two low-pressure systems, and heavy rain finally began on the night of the 15th, causing the Yodo River to rise rapidly. On the 16th, the tributaries of the Yodo River on the right bank, including the Hino River (Takatsuki City), the Akuta River (Takatsuki City), the Aii River (Ibaraki City), and the Ibaraki River (Ibaraki City), flooded. On the 17th, the embankment of the Amano River in Okashinmachi, Hirakata City, on the left bank of the Yodo River, collapsed, and later that night, the embankment of the main Yodo River in Ikaga, Hirakata City, collapsed over a stretch of 30 ken (about 182m), leading to the "Ikaga Break," which eventually expanded to 60 ken (about 364m) and overflowed to the south side of the Yodo River. The embankments on the left bank of the Yodo River collapsed in various places, and in addition, the waters from the tributaries and irrigation channels of the Yodo River overflowed, flooding the entire northern area of the Kawachi Plain. The water reached the embankment of the Neyagawa River and stopped there, with no damage occurring south of the Neyagawa River. Nevertheless, on the 20th, the Onchi River flooded in Nakakawachi County. The flooded areas extended over a wide range, including the current Osaka City districts of Miyakojima, Asahi, Joto, Tsurumi, as well as Moriguchi City, Kadoma City, Neyagawa City, Hirakata City, Settsu City, Ibaraki City, and Takatsuki City. With the momentum of the flood temporarily halted, Governor Kenno Sato of Osaka Prefecture decided to intentionally breach the embankment of the Okawa River to drain the vast amount of water, employing a method known as "waza to kiru," which had been used repeatedly since the Edo period. From the 20th to the 23rd, he cut 26 ken of the left bank embankment of the Okawa River behind Daichoji Temple (now Fujita Tei Ato Park) located at the confluence of the Okawa and Neyagawa rivers in the southwestern corner of the flooded area. Restoration of the embankment began on the 25th in Ikaga, Hirakata City, and on the 28th, Minister of Finance Matsukata Masayoshi inspected the construction work.

On the night of the 27th, when the drainage of the flooded areas had not yet been completed, a thunderstorm began, and on the 28th, heavy rain fell due to the influence of a typhoon. The wind intensified on the 29th, and on July 1st, a storm occurred, causing the embankment in Ikaga, which was under repair, to collapse again, leading to the waters of the Yodo River overflowing to the south once more. Furthermore, the embankment in Sakuramiya, in the current Miyakojima Ward, also collapsed in three places, and water from the Okawa River entered from the embankment behind Daichoji, which had been intentionally cut. This flood did not stop there; the embankment of the Neyagawa River, which had prevented greater damage during the previous flood, collapsed at Tokuan in the current Tsurumi Ward, and as a result, other rivers flowing into the Neyagawa also overflowed, causing the flood to expand south of the Neyagawa. By early July, a large lake, which should have disappeared due to land reclamation in the Edo period, appeared on the surface, including Shinjo Pond and Fukano Pond, which were once part of the Kawachi Lake. Additionally, the high tide contributed to the water from Osaka Bay flowing up the Anjigawa River, flooding the current Kita Ward and Nishi Ward areas, but the area around Osaka Tenmangu Shrine was spared from flooding due to its slightly elevated terrain. The July flood caused the flooded areas from June to be inundated again, and new areas including the current Kita Ward, Fukushima Ward, Konohana Ward, Nishi Ward, Minato Ward, Higashinari Ward, Ikuno Ward, Higashi-Osaka City, Daito City, and Shijonawate City were also flooded. The area affected by flooding was approximately 15,269 cho (15,142 ha), with about 20% of the total households in Osaka Prefecture at that time, or 72,509 households, being flooded by up to about 4 meters. Additionally, 1,749 houses were lost, about 15,000 were damaged, 512 bridges were washed away, 224 embankments collapsed, and there were 81 dead or missing, with 304,199 people affected, resulting in significant damage. The loss of houses was 739 in Ibaraki County and 836 in Higashinari County, accounting for 90% of the total, while the dead and missing numbered 49 in Ibaraki County and 13 in Higashinari County, making up 77% of the total, causing substantial damage. However, in terms of the number of flooded houses, Nishi Ward had 23,116, Naniwa County had 14,253, and Kita Ward had 8,691, surpassing Ibaraki County's 6,996 and Higashinari County's 4,421, mainly due to the storm surge caused by the typhoon. Ultimately, excluding the area north of the Yodo River, which suffered less damage, most low-lying areas, including around Osaka Tenmangu Shrine, the area between Osaka Castle and Tennoji on the Uemachi Plateau, and around Senba, were affected by flooding, while the southern part of Osaka City was also inundated. In addition to Kawasaki Bridge upstream of the Okawa, the three major bridges of Naniwa, namely Tenmabashi, Tenjinbashi, and the southern half of Namba Bridge (the northern half is a railway bridge), as well as Yodoyabashi, were also washed away. The Aji River Bridge, which was the latest movable iron bridge, showed signs of being blocked by debris, prompting the army to quickly blow it up. Thus, more than 30 of the main bridges in Osaka, known as the "Yao Yao Hashi," were washed away one after another, cutting off almost all transportation in the city. On the 7th, the army installed a boat bridge south of Namba Bridge. Once the storm subsided, the flood finally ceased its movement. As the water level of the Yodo River gradually decreased, the water that had accumulated in the flooded areas was drained from the repaired embankments, particularly from the embankment behind Daichoji, although it took a long time. After this flood, the nearby counties initiated a movement to petition the Osaka Prefecture and the national government for the improvement of the Yodo River, and eventually, the Osaka Prefectural Assembly submitted a proposal to the national government. These movements, led by Obashi Bontaro, bore fruit, and finally, in 1896 (Meiji 29), after the First Sino-Japanese War, a public river law bill that included the improvement of the Yodo River was enacted, and the budget for the Yodo River improvement was established, leading to the commencement of improvement works from that year. The Daichoji Temple, which had been washed away and whose grounds had become desolate, was sold around 1887 (Meiji 20) to Fujita Densaburo, and the temple was relocated and restored. On the site where Daichoji once stood, Densaburo built a residence called Anjima Goten, which is now the Fujita Museum, Fujita Residence Ruins Park, Taikoen, and Osaka City Public Hall. Near Sakuranomiya Park, a monument related to this flood has been erected.

Article_Name: Inundaciones en San Juan de 2014, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The floods in San Juan in 2014 were an extreme weather event that affected the south and east of the province of San Juan (Argentina) for several days in February 2014. It intensely affected the departments of Pocito, 25 de Mayo, and Valle Fértil. It also affected Caucete and 9 de Julio, Santa Lucía, Rawson, Angaco, Chimbas, Zonda, 9 de Julio, Ullum, San Martín, and Sarmiento. During the event, the amount of precipitation set a historical record for the province (where the annual average is 100 mm) recording 137.6 mm, exceeding the annual average. According to the Ministry of Human Development of the Government of the Province of San Juan, the number of evacuated people was 3,000.

One of the most affected areas was Pocito, where there were evacuated people and collapsed houses; another affected area was 25 de Mayo, in the localities of Casuarinas, Tupelí, and La Chimbera. Likewise, in Valle Fértil, it caused the overflow of a series of temporary rivers such as Las Tumanas and Del Valle, obstructing traffic on provincial route Nº 510, where the localities of Usno, Astica, La Majadita, and Los Valencianos were greatly affected. Other affected areas included Caucete, where 350 people were evacuated; in Rawson, where there were 310 affected people; in Santa Lucía, with 200 affected people; in Angaco, with 150 affected; and Chimbas, with 17 flooded. Other affected departments were: Zonda, where 60 were evacuated; 9 de Julio, where it reached 56; Ullum, where 50 were evacuated; San Martín, where it reached 25; and Sarmiento, where 20 evacuations were recorded.

Whole_Text.header: The flood in the Sandvik river system 1987
Whole_Text.content: The flood in the Sandvik river system in 1987 was a 100-year flood due to both heavy rain and storm surge in October 1987. Both were caused by a strong low-pressure system that led to enormous damage in Western Europe (the Great Storm in Western Europe 1987). The Sandvik river overflowed the Tangen bridge, which has since been raised by one meter. On October 16, 1987, 145 m³ per second of water flowed past Bjørnegårdsvingen. Storm surge in the Oslofjord flooded Kadettangen.

The Flood of Deucalion is the ancient Greek version of the flood mentioned in the traditions of many ancient cultures. According to the myth, during the time when Deucalion ruled in Phthia in Thessaly, Zeus decided to destroy all of humanity, which was corrupt, except for the righteous king and his wife Pyrrha. Therefore, Deucalion, after advice from his father, built a ship, gathered the necessary supplies for their survival, and boarded the vessel with his wife. Meanwhile, Zeus opened the floodgates of Heaven, and the land of Greece was filled with water, and people perished. For nine days and nine nights, the royal couple drifted on the waters in the vessel. 

On the tenth day, however, they landed on Mount Othrys, or according to another version, on Parnassus or Athos. There, when the rains stopped and the waters receded, Deucalion and Pyrrha descended to dry land, and the first thing they did was to make a sacrifice to Zeus the Protector of Refugees. The god whom the pious Deucalion invoked sent Hermes to convey to them the promise that Zeus would grant their first wish. And the first wish of Deucalion and Pyrrha was none other than for Zeus to give life again to the human race. According to another version, which comes from Phocis, Deucalion and Pyrrha went to Delphi and to the sanctuary of Themis to express the same desire. The goddess listened to them and responded with an oracle, telling them that if they wanted to bring new people to life, they should cover their faces and throw the bones of their mother behind their backs. They understood the interpretation of the oracle, and after doing what the oracle told them, they began to throw stones behind their backs, as these came from the womb of Mother Earth. The stones that Deucalion threw transformed into men, and those that Pyrrha threw transformed into women. From the first stone that Deucalion threw, the Greek, the ancestor of the Greeks, came forth. 

There are other variations of the flood of Deucalion, such as that it occurred when Ogyges was king in Boeotia, the first king of the land of the Boeotians, or according to the Megarians, only Megara was saved from the flood, who took refuge at the top of the Gerania mountains. Nevertheless, the version of Deucalion and Pyrrha is the one that spread widely and prevailed over all others, and during the time of Plutarch, it was enriched with other elements and details that come from Asian traditions, reminding in many ways of the version told in the Bible.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Genova del 9 e 10 ottobre 2014

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Genoa on October 9 and 10, 2014
Whole_Text.content: The flood in Genoa on October 9 and 10, 2014, occurred following heavy rainfall, which caused about 395 mm in 24 hours. In the city of Genoa, the rivers Bisagno, Sturla, Fereggiano, Noce, and Torbella overflowed; in the metropolitan city of Genoa, the Scrivia, Stura, Entella, and the Carpi stream were affected. The weather event impacted many of the most populated areas of Genoa, including the neighborhoods of the middle and lower Bisagno valley of Molassana, Staglieno, Marassi, Quezzi, San Fruttuoso, and many areas of the city center, including the Genoa Brignole station, the Borgo Incrociati area, the Foce neighborhood, and many points in the historic center. Neighborhoods in the eastern part of the city were also heavily affected, including Nervi, Apparizione, and Sturla, as well as in the western part, such as Bolzaneto, Rivarolo, Sampierdarena, Cornigliano, Sestri Ponente, Multedo, Pegli, and Voltri. In total, 43 municipalities in the province of Genoa were affected, including Montoggio, Rossiglione, Masone, Campo Ligure, and Bogliasco.

In the afternoon of October 9 in Chiavari, the Entella river overflows at its mouth, in a safe area without damage. At 9 PM in Montoggio, a municipality in the province of Genoa, the Carpi stream and the Scrivia overflow, causing significant damage. Due to the flooding, there is a power outage, and the water reaches the first floor of houses, dragging some cars with people trapped inside by the pressure of the water on the doors, and three people are rescued. In the municipality of Genoa, intense rainfall occurs in the morning. In the afternoon, the rainfall stops, only to resume late in the evening and with greater intensity during the night. At around 11:30 PM, the Bisagno river overflows. The water invades the streets and drags parked cars. Until three in the morning, due to the flooding, part of the city remains without power. In some areas, the outage lasts for one to two days. The Fereggiano stream, already responsible for the flood of 2011, also overflows and floods the area of via Fereggiano and corso Sardegna. The waters of the Bisagno river reach almost two meters in height outside its banks, dragging many cars and trapping them near the pedestrian and road tunnels next to the Brignole station.

Shortly after midnight, the Sturla stream overflows, flooding numerous streets and dragging parked cars away. Around 00:30, the Brignole area is completely flooded, as in the 2011 flood and various previous ones, with water also invading the second part towards the valley of via XX Settembre. Shortly after, at 00:45, firefighters recover the body of a man, who drowned, in the flooded tunnel between via Canevari and the Brignole station, who will be identified two hours later. At around 01:00, firefighters rescue a person trapped in a car, a few meters outside the tunnel between via Canevari and the Brignole station, stuck among others dragged by the Bisagno. The A12 motorway is closed between the junction for the A7 and Genoa Nervi due to the flooding of Corso Europa towards Genoa at 02:00.

In the early hours of October 11, a heavy rainstorm hits the western part of Genoa, particularly Cornigliano, Coronata, Sestri Ponente, Multedo, Pegli, and Voltri, causing flooding. In Cornigliano, the Polcevera river, in Pegli the Varenna, and in Voltri the Leira exceed the warning levels. The inland areas of Genoa are also affected by intense rains between Campo Ligure, where the Ponzema stream, a tributary of the Stura, overflows, Masone, and Rossiglione. Around 3:00 AM, another heavy rainstorm, with strong gusts of wind and intense and violent rains, strikes the center of Genoa, particularly in the middle eastern neighborhoods and in the Bisagno valley. New overflows of the Bisagno and Fereggiano rivers are feared, but they remain within limits. At 3:30 AM, the Torbella river overflows in Rivarolo. At around 4:00 AM in San Fruttuoso, the Noce stream overflows again. As the hours pass, the storm increasingly affects the eastern part, first limiting itself to the city of Genoa, in the neighborhoods of Foce, Sturla, and Nervi, then extending to the Gulf of Paradise, the Gulf of Tigullio, and their inland areas. At 12:00 PM, the Civil Protection declares a state of "Alert 2" (maximum level) until 12:00 AM on Monday, October 13, 2014, for all Ligurian provinces except for Imperia.

The flooding of the Bisagno stream caused one victim: a 57-year-old man, found drowned by the Fire Brigade in the tunnel between via Canevari and the Brignole station at 01:06 on October 10. The Municipality of Genoa declared a day of mourning for October 16, 2014, the day of the man's funeral. The estimated damages amounted to 250 million euros, 25 of which were just for the city of Genoa. The other flooded municipalities were 43, in the province of Genoa. Four municipalities were in the province of La Spezia. Montoggio was the most affected municipality after Genoa. Resources for the flooded businesses amounted to 40 million. With the stabilization of weather conditions in the flood-affected areas, the city witnessed a strong reaction of spontaneous social solidarity, with participation from the population, including many young people and kids, who took part in helping and assisting those affected and restoring normalcy. In the following days, many volunteers, referred to as "mud angels" (a term historically used by Italian media to describe volunteers who intervene in flooded areas), including people of all ages, Genoese citizens, flood victims, immigrants, people who came from other parts of Italy, civil protection workers, firefighters, and municipal employees, cleaned the streets and most of the affected structures.

The event was triggered by heavy rainfall, 395 mm in 24 hours, occurring in a restricted area between October 9 and October 10 and in various areas of Genoa and its province, causing the subsequent flooding of the Bisagno stream and other affected watercourses. A weather event of large proportions, aggravated by the strong self-regenerating thunderstorm. The meeting of the two flows, that of warm air with that of cold air, is the cause of the V-shape thunderstorm, so named in English for its V shape, and also referred to as self-regenerating. From the examination of wind data, the southwesterlies at altitudes above 700 hPa and the southerlies at 850 hPa in the lower layers (925 and 1000 hPa), it can be understood how the meeting between the cold northern currents of the Tramontana wind from the Po Valley and the warm humid southern currents of the Scirocco wind from the Tyrrhenian Sea led to the occurrence of a stationary microfront, that is, a stall due to the airflow caused by the convective motion of the currents. The currents remained blocked over the area, consequently the thunderstorm precipitation self-fed and fell back on the same area.

Starting from the second half of the 1920s, the area was affected by the city's expansion. There was also the covering of streams over which buildings and structures were constructed. The city's expansion and the intervention of the covering of the Bisagno in the 1930s constituted a factor of increased criticality.

The flood of 2014 that hit the Borgo Incrociati neighborhood is described in the events of the novel "Forty Nights and Then Tomorrow" by Sergio Grea. The event is mentioned in the song "The Red Thread," a famous song by the Genoese singer-songwriter Alfa.

Whole_Text.header: The great flood of the 43rd year of the Meiji era.
Whole_Text.content: The Great Flood of Meiji 43 (1910) was a major disaster that struck 1 prefecture and 15 prefectures in eastern Japan in August 1910. Due to the combination of the rainy season front and two typhoons, heavy rain caused rivers to overflow, resulting in 769 deaths, 78 missing persons, and approximately 5,000 houses completely destroyed or washed away in the Kanto region alone, with about 1.5 million people affected in Tokyo Prefecture. As of August 8, it was reported that "heavy rain in the Tokai, Kanto, and Tohoku regions turned the Kanto area into a quagmire, with record-breaking concentrated heavy rain following prolonged rain leading to river flooding and landslides, resulting in 1,357 dead or missing, 2,765 houses completely destroyed, and 3,832 houses washed away."

The current flat areas of the Tokyo metropolitan area were originally tidal flats and low wetlands, which were converted into habitable land through land reclamation and flood control projects after Tokugawa Ieyasu's entry into the city. Tokyo (Edo) is essentially vulnerable to flooding, and there are regions, such as the former Katori Sea area, which became the lower reaches of the Tone River due to the Tone River diversion project aimed at flood control, that have come to be struck by floods as a consequence. Prior flood control measures, as seen in the Nakajo levee, were based on the premise of flooding and only protected key points, and although the area had frequently been hit by floods, starting with the Edo flood in 1742, it was not seen as a problem. However, after the Meiji Restoration, as modern infrastructure development progressed and the damage amounts increased, further burdens were placed on areas suffering from flooding, making it difficult to gain understanding for flood control based on the premise of flooding.

From around August 5, 1910 (Meiji 43), heavy rain caused by the rainy season front continued, and on the 11th, a typhoon approached the Japanese archipelago, grazed the Boso Peninsula, and moved out over the Pacific Ocean. Another typhoon made landfall near Numazu on the 14th, passing through Kofu and western Gunma Prefecture, resulting in concentrated heavy rainfall across various regions of Kanto. Rivers across a wide area, including the Tone, Arakawa, and Tamagawa river systems, flooded, and levees broke in various places. The damage in the Kanto region included 769 dead, 78 missing, 2,121 houses completely destroyed, and 2,796 houses washed away. In Gunma Prefecture, which suffered the most damage, there were 283 dead, 27 missing, and 1,249 houses completely destroyed or washed away. In addition to the left bank of the Tone River and downstream areas, the Nakajo levee, a key flood control structure on the right bank, which had been reinforced after the major eruption of Mount Asama in 1783, also broke, causing floodwaters to traverse Saitama Prefecture and reach Tokyo, completely inundating the Kanto Plain. In Tokyo, the downtown area was submerged for a while, and there are records of a relief station (now Asakusa Temple Hospital) being established at Senso-ji Temple.

In Saitama Prefecture, a dispute arose regarding the repair of the Nakajo Dam, which was breached due to this flood. One side, including the northern Katsushika district and the southern and northern Saitama districts, advocated for reinforced restoration, while the other side, the Kamigō area, demanded the conventional maintenance of the Nakajo Dam along with the construction of levees on the upper Tone River. This led to great chaos in the prefectural assembly, and local residents, dissatisfied with the mediation proposal presented by the governor, clashed violently with police forces, resulting in repeated conflicts in the prefectural assembly. Ultimately, however, consideration was given to the demands of the Kamigō area, which had been suffering from water damage, and the height of the Nakajo Dam was maintained as before. In response to the claims from the Shimogō area for reinforcement, it was decided to widen the levee, and the narrow sections at Sakamaki and Setoi were to be expanded, with the restoration based on a continuous levee system. This necessitated a revision of the ongoing Tone River improvement project, leading to significant changes such as a review of the planned flood flow and an increase in the diversion flow to the Edogawa River. Additionally, this major flood caused significant damage in Tokyo, affecting 1.5 million victims, and the Tokyo Prefecture, which had not previously borne the costs of flood control for the Tone River, began to share the local burden of flood control costs like other prefectures in the basin. For the Arakawa River, a large-scale improvement plan was formulated, and the following year, the Arakawa River diversion project was initiated, which involved the excavation of a discharge channel 500 meters wide and 22 kilometers long from Iwabuchi to the mouth of the Nakagawa River. The project faced significant challenges due to the recession caused by World War I and the Great Kanto Earthquake, but utilizing steam excavators and dredging boats, a total of 3.1 million personnel were mobilized, and it was completed in Showa 5 (1930).

Article_Name: Aiguats de la conca del Segre de 1982 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.header: Floods of the Segre basin in 1982
Whole_Text.content: The floods in the Segre basin of 1982 were a flood that took place between November 7 and 8, 1982, due to the rain that fell that night and culminated in the overflow of the Segre River and the Valira River. The affected areas were Andorra and the regions through which the Segre River flows, from Lleida to Cerdanya, and it also caused damage in the basins of the Noguera and the Llobregat. It was particularly tragic in Alt Urgell and Baixa Cerdanya. The floods left 14 fatalities, cut-off roads, and collapsed bridges. Additionally, they resulted in a significant economic crisis. The observatory in La Molina reported figures of 600 liters per m², while in Seu d'Urgell it was 102 liters per m². In Alt Urgell, there were forty isolated villages and thirty collapsed bridges. Neither the newspapers in Barcelona nor the television reflected the magnitude of the disaster, as they were focused on covering the trip of Pope John Paul II. The airport in Seu d'Urgell became the link between the city, the region, and Andorra with the outside world. The airport recorded up to 146 flights between planes and helicopters. In Baixa Cerdanya, the flood swept away the road from La Molina as it passed through Alp. In Martinet, it destroyed five or six houses. In Alt Urgell, the flood left the city of Seu d'Urgell cut off, and the bridges crossing the Valira and the Palanca bridge collapsed. The village that suffered the most damage was Pont de Bar, built in a narrow area close to the Segre, which was completely submerged by the floods, forcing its reconstruction far from the old village. Half of the village was buried by a landslide from a mountain, and the water also destroyed several houses; it also swept away the remains of the millennial bridge of Sant Ermengol, which gives its name to the village. Years later, the river was channeled as it passed through the Segre River. In 2007, 25 years later, a plaque was placed in memory of the victims at the entrance of the Olympic Park of the Segre, at the steps of the tannery. The plaque reads "Such a great flood of water came...".

The river's rise began on November 7, at three in the afternoon the firefighters were already on alert and started evacuating people living near the river. An hour later, news came from the entire region about the abnormal rise of all springs and wells, even speaking of "water volcanoes." Three hours later, the water had already unleashed. At the Pont de Bar (now Pont de Bar Vell), they boarded up the doors of the power station, and at night the water level suddenly rose by two meters and swept away the workers' house, which was unoccupied at that moment. In the evening, given the magnitude of the rise, the Emergency Board was established, coordinated by the City Council of La Seu d'Urgell and other organizations. On November 8, in the early morning, the Adrall bridge on the Cantó road collapsed, and at a quarter to two, it was reported that the Oliana reservoir was full. Between La Seu d'Urgell and Alàs, the usual width of the Segre is 30 meters; that day it was 400 meters and exceeded its normal level by five meters, and in Organyà by fourteen. Five people had been isolated since Sunday (the 7th) in a farm in Montferrer and had to climb onto the roof as the river was eroding the house. The Civil Guard helicopter that was supposed to come from Zaragoza did not arrive, but they were eventually rescued, along with one person in Salit, by a second French helicopter mobilized through efforts by the Mitra in Andorra. A fire department boat rescued a girl stuck in a tree in Ponts, and the French helicopter went to La Massana due to reports of gas explosions and that some cars had fallen into the Valira while fleeing danger. During Monday, information was gathered about the closed roads, the isolated towns, and the provision of essential services to the cut-off villages. In the evening, false rumors began to circulate about the collapse of a dam in France, and in Oliana, the evacuation of the lower part of the town was ordered. On the 9th, efforts were made to secure raw materials, and an air bridge was established between the La Seu d'Urgell airport and Barcelona. Among other things, there was the evacuation of the sick and the arrival of medicines and food. A total of 10 helicopters were operational, with three soldiers with radio telephones in each telephonically isolated village. To reach Andorra, alternative routes through the high mountains had to be used, and SAR helicopters evacuated tourists. In Alt Urgell, it was ensured that the milk from the isolated villages could reach the tanker trucks. Some of the procedures were deemed picturesque, such as the hose from Taús, to lower the milk down the ravine. On Wednesday, rumors circulated about a landslide at the Pont de Bar, saying that if the landslide occurred, it would create a dam that would multiply the effects of the previous floods. As a consequence, the mountain was studied day and night by geologists. On the 11th, Os de Civís, Taús, Tuixent, and Ossera were still cut off. In Os, a group of forty soldiers cleared a path with picks and shovels. Complaints about the lack of television and political coverage were significant, although that same day, Jordi Pujol, then president of the Generalitat of Catalonia, visited La Seu d'Urgell. On Friday, a decree was published denying the information from TVE about the danger of a landslide at the Pont de Bar. The rumors had caused alarm downstream and even reached Lleida. In Balaguer, scenes of panic were experienced, and an evacuation order was given. The area was declared a disaster zone by means of a decree law 21/1982. Ultimately, the total number of victims was twelve people, although it had been said that there were about fifty in Andorra.

The heavy rains affected all the parishes of the country. The Valira River, both from the East and the North, rose throughout the night swallowing cars, buses, bridges, streetlights, buildings, and people. About 12 people were reported missing and 7 dead. Tourists who had come to visit the country were trapped in hotels, while the Andorra Fire Service's switchboard was overwhelmed with calls. People climbed onto the roofs of supermarkets (such as Hiper Andorra) and citizens had to be rescued with the help of tractors. Santa Coloma (a parish of Andorra la Vella) was flooded. It was decided to close the road to Arinsal (a parish of La Massana) because the Andorgaz gas station had just exploded. An evacuation order was immediately issued for all buildings within 500 meters of the gas station. The country took a week to return to normal. Days after the events, there were still 1800 tourists trapped in hotels awaiting rescue. The disaster caused the population to flock to insurance companies after the floods. Policies multiplied, and so did the insurance claims. The first government of the country, which was in the midst of transitioning to a Constitution, had to improvise. The head of government, Òscar Ribas, was caught off guard by the tragedy. While it was pouring rain in Andorra, he was in Geneva on an official trip. He was immediately informed of the chaos. It was the first time Andorra had a government and faced such disasters. Poor planning in previous years regarding construction was one of the causes of the floods' severity. The municipal headquarters (common house) were used as "control and coordination centers." The water swept away the headquarters of the Encamp Commune. However, there were citizens who blamed the government and the communes for poor management. After all, 4 days later, Arinsal (La Massana) was still cut off. The situation created solidarity among the population. Everyone, to varying degrees, tried to help each other. Antoni Aleix, the director of the police force at the time, recalls that "looting in stores was minimal." It was a situation like never seen before. The head of government stayed in contact with ministers and the police until two in the morning. The Swiss Red Cross managed a flight to Barcelona so that the head of government could return to the country. Once in Barcelona, he took a helicopter. Four days after the flood, the helicopter link service between Andorra and La Seu d'Urgell was suspended, and a forest track was opened as a precarious communication route. Some shopping centers offered products that had suffered from the water damage at reduced prices for a long time. The situation generated by the floods raised alarms for thefts. There were people who took advantage of the situation, and at one point, bottles of water were sold for more than double the normal price. Central Park (Andorra la Vella) was flooded. The situation was one of hysteria and anguish, as confirmed by Jaume Bartumeu (former head of government). According to estimates from the government at the time, the reconstruction of the damages and destruction cost more than 1000 million pesetas. Andorran schools, especially the Liceu Comte de Foix, took a long time to return to normal. The country observed several days of mourning.

Whole_Text.content: The Kae-tsu Flood refers to the flood that occurred on July 17, 1966, in the Kae-tsu region of Niigata Prefecture. It is also known as the 7.17 Flood in the affected areas.

From July 16 to 18, concentrated heavy rain occurred in the Shimoekawa region, causing breaches in the banks of the Kaji River, Tainai River, and Arakawa, resulting in major flooding. The damage was particularly concentrated on the left bank of the Kaji River. The flooding from the Kaji River combined with the overflow from Fukushima Lagoon, leading to prolonged inundation of the nearby low-lying areas. The drainage at the Arai-gō River pumping station could not keep up, so the levee of the Agano River was breached for drainage, and on August 4, drainage was completed after 19 days. The flooding on the right bank of the Kaji River flowed towards the Otogawa River and caused inundation at the site of the Shiunji Lagoon. The following year, on August 28, 1967, the Uetsu Flood (8/28 Flood, Uetsu Heavy Rain) occurred in the Shimoekawa region and Yamagata Prefecture. The Shimoekawa region was hit by flooding for two consecutive years.
