Article_Name: Inundación en Santa Fe de 2007, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Santa Fe in 2007 was a meteorological event that occurred in March of that year, affecting the city of Santa Fe and nearby towns due to heavy rainfall in the Argentine coastal area. In total, 437 millimeters of rain fell from March 26 to April 4, resulting in 26,000 evacuees.

The city of Santa Fe is located in an interfluvial area with the Salado River to the west and the Paraná River system to the east, and it features a set of streams, creeks, lagoons, and wetlands that represent 70% of the municipal district framed in a floodable valley. The rise of these has caused floods such as the one in 1983 from the Paraná and the one in 2003 from the Salado. On the other hand, the climate in Santa Fe is temperate without a dry season, according to the Köppen climate classification, with annual precipitation between 800 and 1100 mm, of which approximately half occurs between the months of February and May. These land and climate characteristics, along with the occupation of floodable soils, result in the continuous risk and water vulnerability that the city suffers.

In light of the problems faced with the water situation, the government has built a series of defenses to prevent floods and inundations. The first and most primitive of these is the defense embankment or lateral dike, which is an artificial barrier of earth located on the banks, separating rivers from flood-prone areas. To prevent water accumulation, as it cannot flow back into the rivers due to the embankments, a set of river defense structures was established, consisting of storm drains, pipes, and rainwater drains. This system directs water to reservoirs, areas adjacent to the embankments, which are depressed zones whose main function is to temporarily store water to later be emptied into nearby natural water flows. This emptying occurs in two ways, namely by gravity and by pumping. The gravity method occurs through gates in the embankments that connect the reservoirs at their lowest point with a part at the height of a water flow. On the other hand, the pumping system operates through plants equipped with motor pumps capable of expelling water outside the defenses. By 2007, there were four pumping stations, known as pump houses, in operation, with two more lacking electrical connections. Pump house No. 1 was operating at 65% of its capacity, with two of the five pumps not working; No. 3 operated at 65% and No. 4 at 80%. In pump house No. 2, an explosion occurred on March 14 in one of the two pumps, which had not yet been repaired at the time the flooding began. By then, 27 of the 45 available pumps were not functioning, representing 60% of the pumping system.

On April 20, 2005, the Justicialist mayor Martín Balbarrey, elected in 2003, presented the Contingency Plan for the city, which detailed all the mechanisms to prevent crisis situations like the 2003 flood, with the aim of ensuring that each neighbor knew how to act in an emergency. The plan was prepared by official agencies and NGOs, along with community groups and specialists in the field, and was led by Venezuelan Pedro Zuccarini, a disaster specialist who had been helping in the city since the 2003 flood, on behalf of the German Red Cross. The plan established the action protocols to be carried out by organizations and institutions, the dissemination of necessary knowledge to the population so they would know how to react, and the creation of the Risk Action Office, prepared to act before, during, and after the disaster. A year later, on March 20, 2006, Balbarrey ordered the creation of the Undersecretariat for Risk Management, dependent on the Secretariat of Water Resources, which he placed Pedro Zuccarini in charge of. In June 2006, Proyecto Santa Fe, a study center led by then-national deputy radical Hugo Storero, conducted a survey of 360 people and 56 institutions from twelve neighborhoods in the west, the area most affected by the 2003 flood. Given the results, it turned out that most did not know what to do in the event of a new flood, being unaware of the new Contingency Plan and the location of evacuation centers, although Zuccarini later denied the survey, claiming that "two out of five Santa Fe residents" knew the plan and were prepared. Another finding from the survey was that a majority of institutions did not believe another flood was possible. Zuccarini traveled to his home country, Venezuela, in December 2006, first for personal reasons, and then, according to Balbarrey, to present the projects established in Santa Fe in other parts of the world. On February 1, 2007, he continued to be absent, resulting in him being unpaid, and he was ultimately removed from his position on February 21. The team of nine people from the undersecretariat continued working, divided into two groups, one responsible for fieldwork and the other for logistics. This occurred in the context of the rise of the Paraná River in February 2007, which affected the residents of Vuelta del Paraguayo.

Between March 26 and April 4, the Santa Fe departments of Belgrano, Caseros, Castellanos, Constitución, Garay, Iriondo, La Capital, las Colonias, Rosario, San Jerónimo, San Lorenzo, and San Martín; and the Entre Ríos departments of Islas del Ibicuy, Gualeguay, Gualeguaychú, and Paraná. During those days, the total rainfall was 437 mm. On March 30, 15,000 residents from the western neighborhoods of San Pantaleón, Barranquitas, Villa del Parque, San Lorenzo, Chalet, and Santa Rosa de Lima left their homes for temporary shelter centers, following the declaration of a red alert and preventive evacuation of the area by Mayor Balbarrey, as it was the most affected. Although the rain had decreased, the connection between the water reservoirs caused an increase in other areas of the city. The Santa Fe-Rosario highway and Route 11 were impassable. The Army, Gendarmerie, and Coast Guard were in the city to provide assistance regarding food supplies, relief, and security.

According to Mayor Balbarrey, the causes were the large amount of rain, which exceeded all previous precautions; and the lack of maintenance and looting of the extraction pumps installed in the western area. The proliferation of settlements in flood-prone areas, the lack of maintenance of the reservoirs and the pump system.

Whole_Text.content: The Great Flood of 1860, also known as the "ofsen," was an extreme flood that occurred in Eastern Norway, peaking between June 15 and June 18, 1860. The flood was not as devastating as the Great Flood of 1789, but water levels were higher or close to that in many places. According to the Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate (NVE), the flood had a volume 3-4 times that of the Great Flood in parts of the Glomma river. At least twelve people are reported to have lost their lives. The flood may have been at the level of a 500-year flood. It was caused by an unusually high amount of snow in the mountains during the winter of 1859/1860. When the snowmelt was at its worst, large amounts of rain also fell, leading to extreme flooding and significant inundation in many areas of Eastern Norway. In this way, it resembled the Lesser Flood of 1995, while the Great Flood was more of a rain flood. Buskerud was particularly hard hit, resulting in loss of life, along with livestock and bridges. Parts of Sweden also experienced significant flooding. The Faluån river destroyed a large part of the buildings along its banks, and the water level in Siljan rose to 3 meters above normal.

The Munich flood of 1899, referred to as the "century flood," is one of the largest natural disasters that struck the city of Munich. A flood wave of the Isar triggered by heavy rainfall destroyed riverbank facilities in the urban area as well as two large Isar bridges in September 1899, leading to a reorganization of the inner-city river area with significant riverbank reinforcement works and the construction of six new bridges.

Starting from September 8, 1899, there were heavy rainfalls in Southern Bavaria. The rain originated from a large low-pressure area that extended from North Africa to the Baltic Sea and from the Western Alps to the Black Sea. The transport of moist air from the north and from the entire Mediterranean region produced precipitation peaking over 500 mm over an area of more than 10,000 square kilometers. In the Isar region up to the mouth of the Loisach, the rainfall from September 9 to 14 averaged 400 mm, resulting in 990 million cubic meters of runoff from the 2736 square kilometer area. Due to a relatively dry summer and a snow-poor winter of 1898/99, the underground reservoirs had a low water level, allowing parts of the rainwater to be naturally captured. Otherwise, the subsequent flooding would have been even more massive. Nevertheless, the rainfalls led to flooding, especially in the Isar and Inn regions, by September 14. Other areas in the foothills of the Alps were similarly affected, such as along the Danube and the Traun. Unlike the floods of 1954 and 2002, there was no double wave (resulting from separately fallen blocks of precipitation) in 1899, but only a continuous, single wave. The water levels reached in 1899 were the highest ever recorded in the Isar and Inn regions.

The flood-prone Isar caused significant damage in the Munich city area starting from September 12. The riverbank reinforcements and weirs were particularly affected, such as the Neumüller and Montgelas dams. The young Maximiliansanlagen were also severely damaged. Here, as in the Isar meadows, constructed ponds and lakes were destroyed. The hydropower plant Maximilianswerk, built only in 1895, was also affected. All Isar bridges were damaged, with two collapsing. In addition to three wooden bridges, there were eight stone and two iron bridges in the city area before the flood. On September 13, the Max-Joseph Bridge (also known as the Bogenhauser Bridge), a bridge built in 1876 in iron framework architecture, collapsed. The date is notable as it was also on a September 13 during the flood of 1813 that the Munich Swan Bridge (now: Ludwigsbrücke) collapsed at the current Museum Island, drowning 100 people. After days of the flood undermining the pillars of the Luitpold Bridge (also known as the Prinzregenten Bridge) and washing away significant amounts of soil at the abutments as well as parts of the bank protections, it too collapsed into the Isar the following day. This steel bridge, built in segmental arch construction, had only been erected eight years earlier. Approximately at its location, the riverbed of the Isar widened during the flood due to bank erosion from 45 to 65 meters. No fatalities from the flood are known.

After the normalization of the water levels, military units from Munich and Ingolstadt immediately constructed a pontoon emergency bridge. The destroyed Max-Joseph Bridge was replaced by a temporary bridge after the onset of winter. As a result of the destruction, the city administration decided on an extensive construction and renovation program, which from 1900 to 1905 included a fundamental river regulation in the urban area, the construction of extensive riverbanks and quay walls, as well as the renewal (profile expansion for greater water flow) or new construction of six bridges. In March 1901, the city magistrate decided to announce a limited competition for the expansion and new construction of the bridges. The generous new construction program included the creation of six new Isar bridges in stone and (partially) concrete construction (Luitpold Bridge – 1901, Max-Joseph Bridge – 1902, Cornelius Bridge – 1903, Reichenbach Bridge – 1903, Wittelsbacher Bridge – 1904, and Outer Maximilian Bridge – 1905) and a reorganization of the Isar area (almost continuously over a length of about 6 kilometers from the Thalkirchen weirs to the Praterwehr) with regulation by encasing the river with quay walls and dikes. For cost reasons, the new bridges were constructed with a standard teaching framework and made of solid shell limestone (from quarries in Lower Franconia), which is why they look similar in shape with their wide-spanning arches and are the same in material. The bridges were built by the construction company Sager & Woerner, and the designs were by architects Friedrich von Thiersch and Theodor Fischer. The previously regularly flooded coal island (now: Museum Island) was also reinforced so that it was now flood-proof.

Article_Name: Aiguat de Sant Miquel - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Sant Miquel flood took place from September 28 to 29, 1913, and affected almost all of Catalonia, causing the overflow of numerous rivers and streams in the northeast sector of the country. The most affected areas were Baix Llobregat, Empordà, and Penedès. The highest precipitation levels occurred on the 28th in Baix Llobregat with 262.0 mm in St. Feliu del Llobregat and 153.8 mm in Esplugues de Llobregat, and in Alt Penedès with 105.5 mm at the Foix Reservoir. On the 29th, the maximum values were recorded in Baix Empordà with 192.3 mm in Lladó, 181.0 mm in Peralada, and 150.6 mm in Empúries. Throughout the meteorological episode, the 262.0 mm in St. Feliu de Llobregat and the 202.6 mm in Lladó stand out. During those days, there was a marked surface flow between east and southeast, driven by a deep depression located over Galicia, which had a secondary core off the coast of Algeria. Additionally, at altitude, there was significant wind shear: southwest at 500 hPa, south at 850 hPa, and southeast at the surface. In general, this configuration tends to be potentially very unstable and leads to the advection of warm and very humid air to Catalonia, favoring the development of significant storms with heavy rains along the coast and pre-coast, as occurred between September 28 and 29, 1913. Due to the large amount of precipitation, the Foix, Anoia, Cardener, Llobregat, Ripoll, Congost, Besòs, Muga, Manol, Llobregat d'Empordà, and numerous streams in Penedès, Garraf, Baix Llobregat, Barcelonès, and Empordà overflowed, causing significant damage in many places. Regarding the damage, it is worth highlighting the violent overflow of the Riera de la Salut in St. Feliu de Llobregat, which broke the walls of the municipal cemetery, dragging many coffins into the Llobregat River. In Vendrell, the Torrent del Lluc swept away the railway bridge, and in Cubelles, the Foix destroyed another bridge. Finally, in Empordà, all the bridges on the road from Roses to Vilajuïga collapsed due to the significant overflow of the various streams crossing that road. The consequences of this flood were very visible for a long time, leaving a significant mark in the memory of the inhabitants of all the affected regions.

Article_Name: Aiguat de Santa Tecla - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The flood or disaster of Santa Tecla was a flood that occurred on the night of September 22 to 23, 1874, and primarily affected the regions of Camp de Tarragona, Conca de Barberà, Priorat, Urgell, and Garrigues. The heavy rains that fell that night caused rivers and streams to overflow, and it is estimated that about 570 people died and more than 700 houses were destroyed. The name of this flood has remained in the popular memory of the most affected regions as the flood of Santa Tecla, since September 23 coincides with this festivity.

Whole_Text.header: In the Camp de Tarragona and the Conca de Barberà
Whole_Text.content: The area most affected by this flood was the course of the Francolí River. In Vimbodí, the flood swept away the railway bridge, and in l'Espluga de Francolí, 24 fatalities were recorded. In Montblanc, 8 people drowned, and the force of the water carried away eleven houses, several mills, and the railway bridge. In Vilaverd, the current also took away the railway bridge. At the narrow of la Riba, where the courses of the Brugent and Francolí rivers meet, the flood demolished numerous houses and paper mills and caused fatalities. The streams flowing near the city of Valls also experienced rises, causing the collapse of walls and some houses. Two people were reported missing. In the Valls area, the rise of the Francolí respected the Goi bridge, a construction from the medieval period. In the following days, in the areas of Rourell, Morell, Pobla de Mafumet, and Puigdelfí, numerous corpses were collected that the water had dragged away. In Tarragona, it was the eve of the Santa Tecla Major Festival. It rained torrentially from one to six in the morning. Around two-thirty in the night, the Francolí River overflowed, flooding the nearby fields and collapsing an old wooden bridge and the iron bridges of the two railway lines (the one from Reus and Lleida, and the one from Tortosa and Valencia). The water entered the city and flooded the lower neighborhoods, causing severe damage. In the following days, numerous corpses were found that the flood had dragged to the beaches and the gardens by the Francolí. The Gaià River also experienced a strong rise. In the upper course, the flood demolished numerous houses in Pontils and those in the lower part of Santa Perpètua. The rise caused considerable damage along its entire course, provoking a severe flood in the area of Altafulla where it collapsed the railway bridge. In Baix Camp, the streams also overflowed, demolishing buildings in towns like Reus, Riudoms, Cambrils, and Mont-roig. On the beaches between Hospitalet de l'Infant and Cambrils, seventeen corpses were collected, and forty more between Cambrils and Salou.

In addition to the Camp de Tarragona, the heavy rain was also strongly felt in Urgell, especially in the city of Tàrrega where the rise of the Ondara river swept away the entire neighborhood of Sant Agustí, causing 150 fatalities and the collapse of 250 houses. The flooding occurred in the early morning, surprising people inside their homes. Inside the town, the water rose in the streets until it reached the square of Sant Antoni. In the rest of Urgell, the Corb river also experienced a strong rise, causing devastation as it passed through Guimerà (35 deaths). In Tarròs, the water demolished almost all the houses, causing 8 deaths. In Vilagrassa, there were 13 fatalities and in Claravalls, 11. The heavy rain also swept away a section of the railway line between Tàrrega and Bellpuig and the bridge over the Vilagrassa stream. Between Bellpuig and Belianes, a small settlement, the Eixaders, also disappeared. Near Agramunt, the Sió river carried away the aqueduct bridge, built in 1857, over which the Urgell canal crossed elevated above the river. The waters, which swept away all kinds of objects, blocked the arches, causing the river level to exceed 9 meters, the water passed over the bridge and formed a great waterfall until the structure gave way. In Garrigues, the most affected locality was La Floresta, where the flooding inundated several houses and caused the death of 10 people. Other affected towns included Vinaixa, les Borges Blanques, and Juneda.

In Priorat, the Montsant and Siurana rivers and their tributaries also experienced significant floods. In Cornudella, the town was flooded, and some houses and half of a bridge collapsed. In Porrera, the water uprooted the vineyards and trees near the ravines. In La Vilella Baixa, the flood destroyed 14 houses and caused the death of one resident. The flow of the Ebre River also increased, although not as much as on other occasions. In Ginestar, the Sant Isidre ravine flooded some houses, drowning three people. In Móra d'Ebre, two sentinels of the castle died from the impact of a lightning strike.

The only population for which meteorological data from that day's downpour is available is Barcelona. Very strong winds from the NE and N were recorded, and 63 mm of precipitation fell by two in the afternoon on the 23rd. In this city, the downpour caused a wall to collapse at the confluence of Riera Alta and Ronda de Sant Antoni, resulting in the death of a girl. The Anoia River also experienced a significant rise, affecting numerous factories in Igualada. In Vilanova i la Geltrú, the torrent of Pastera and the ditch of Miquelet overflowed, flooding houses, factories, and pens, but without causing any fatalities.

Article_Name: Aiguat del 10 d'octubre de 1994 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The downpour of October 10, 1994, or the Downpour of Saint Thomas, was an episode of torrential rains that particularly affected the regions of Camp de Tarragona, causing considerable flooding and damage to road infrastructure. It began on the night of Sunday, October 9, and at a quarter to 6 in the morning on Monday, October 10, 1994. At 8 in the morning, the delegate of the Government of the Generalitat, Josep Maldonado, established the crisis coordination center with the heads of the affected departments of the autonomous and state administrations. By 10 in the morning, there was a maximum alert, and many municipalities were already suffering from severe flooding.

The irregularity of the Mediterranean climate causes streams and ravines to go from having no water to carrying a significant amount, and at certain times of the year, especially in autumn, favorable weather conditions for intense downpours occur, leading to the feared floods. Meteorologists agree on the confluence of various situations for these to happen: They have orographic causes and characteristics similar to those of monsoon rain: they last a long time and occur at any hour of the day or night.

Alforja was the town that recorded the highest rainfall, 403 liters/m2 in 24 hours. In the early morning, the most affected regions were Priorat, Baix and Alt Camp, and Tarragonès. In the afternoon, the heavy rains intensified in the regions of Montsià and Baix Ebre, in the south of the province. The heavy rains and the increase in river flow put the entire province on Alert G - very heavy rains. The most affected areas were the banks of the Francolí River, from its source in Espluga de Francolí to its mouth, next to the fishing district of Tarragona - the Serrallo. In some places, the river reached heights of up to three meters, surpassing the height of some of the bridges crossing it and causing the collapse of five, for example, in the town of La Riba, the confluence of the Francolí and Brugent rivers caused a flood that destroyed the access bridge to the town. The PLASEQTA - Safety Plan for the chemical industry of Tarragona - was also activated due to the collapse of the bridge that provided access to the refinery and the municipalities of Pobla de Mafumet and Morell via the Valls road. The force of the river caused the breakage of two conduits of the rack that transports various chemical substances, resulting in these toxic products spilling into the sea. In Reus, the PEM - Municipal Emergency Plan - was activated early in the morning, as most communication routes were cut off. Some flooding occurred - at the Casal de Sant Josep Obrer and Hall 4 of the Fair - students from the Bon Soleil School (currently Collège Français de Reus) were evacuated, and two houses collapsed, but no personal injuries were reported. The water flowed with great force through all the streams, torrents, and ravines of many towns in Tarragona, however, the water flowing through the streams of Alforja and Maspujols caused the majority of the damage in Baix Camp. In Priorat, the need to open the sluices of the Siurana reservoir increased the river flow and caused severe flooding in Porrera, which had to be partially evacuated. Power supply interruptions occurred - eight high-voltage towers fell in various municipalities - as well as telephone, gas, train, and road lines. The most significant evacuations took place in the fishing district of the city of Tarragona - the Serrallo - and in Porrera and Poboleda - in the Priorat region. Other municipalities were cut off due to the floods. Throughout the day, according to information from the delegate of the Government of the Generalitat, Josep Maldonado, and the civil governor, Ramón Sánchez, a total of 850 civil guards, 200 national police, 12 civil protection members, 80 mossos d'esquadra, 160 firefighters, as well as 4 firefighting helicopters were deployed to assist in evacuation tasks, along with local police forces from the affected municipalities and road personnel. The damage caused by the flood to the roads and bridges of the Generalitat was estimated at 5 billion pesetas, to which the autonomous administration added 2 billion in damages to hydraulic works. The MOPTMA estimated the losses in roads and bridges under its jurisdiction at 1.598 billion, mostly in the province of Tarragona, along with the loss of construction machinery from the Tarragona park, valued at 325 million. The Tarragona Provincial Council, for its part, estimated the damages recorded on the local road network at 1 billion pesetas.

Article_Name: Aiguats de novembre de 1983 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The November floods of 1983 occurred on November 7, 1983, in the Llobregat basin with catastrophic consequences. These floods happened just one year after the episode of torrential rains from November 6-8, 1982, which affected the entire country, but mainly the headwaters of the Llobregat and Segre basins with very serious overflows. The most affected areas in 1983 were the regions of Baix Llobregat, Barcelonès, and the eastern and western Vallesos, although in parts of Cerdanya, Garrotxa, and Osona, the total precipitation for the entire episode was also significant.

The most intense precipitation fell during the early morning of November 7, especially from 03 to 07 UTC, with amounts exceeding 150 mm recorded in parts of Barcelonès, Vallesos, and Baix Llobregat (220.0 mm in Terrassa-Placeta de la Creu, 217.3 mm in Hospitalet de Llobregat, and 188.0 mm in Terrassa-Casa Barba). The spatial distribution of the rain that morning was very irregular; for example, 217.3 mm fell in Hospitalet, 56 mm in Cornellà, and only 16 mm at the mouth of the Besòs. Precipitation continued to fall more moderately for the rest of the day on the 7th and much of the 8th. The last showers, of a more local nature, extended until midday on November 9. The maximum precipitation values in 24 hours occurred on the 7th, exceeding 200 mm in parts of Vallès Occidental and Barcelonès. In Terrassa, 313.0 mm fell, and in Hospitalet de Llobregat, 249.1 mm over about 28 hours (from 03 UTC on 07/11/1983 to 07 UTC on 08/11/1983). Among the accumulated values during the episode (from 07 UTC on 06/11/1983 to 07 UTC on 09/11/1983), notable amounts include 333.0 mm in Terrassa, 254.8 mm in La Molina, and 252.8 mm in Hospitalet de Llobregat. The meteorological situation during the episode was characterized by a strong surface storm from the southeast, caused by the passage of a deep disturbance present at all levels of the troposphere. This depression moved from the Gulf of Cádiz on the morning of November 6 to Sardinia on the morning of the 8th, crossing the Balearic Islands from the south during the day on the 7th. This storm caused a marked flow of warm, humid wind from the southeast at lower levels and from the south at higher levels, advecting a potentially very unstable air mass at all levels, producing the significant downpours on November 7 and 8.

The heavy rains on the 7th caused numerous tributaries on the left bank of the Llobregat River to overflow violently, which also temporarily flooded its lower course, inundating many fields. Notable overflows occurred in the Riera Blanca in Hospitalet de Llobregat, the Riera de la Païssa in Sant Joan Despí, the Riera de la Salut in Sant Feliu de Llobregat, the Riera de Vallvidrera in Molins de Rei, and the Riera de les Arenes in Terrassa and Rubí. It is also worth noting that many streets in the city of Barcelona turned into torrents of water due to the heavy intensity of the precipitation, flooding basements and garages. This episode of torrential rains had a significant social impact, especially in the riverside towns of Baix Llobregat, occurring just a year after the major floods caused by the rains from November 6 to 8, 1982, the damages of which had recently been repaired, but with many improvement works still pending. All of this created a notable feeling of helplessness among the entire population.

Article_Name: Rierada de Cambrils del 1994 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Cambrils in 1994 was an overflow of the Alforja stream as it passed through Cambrils on October 10, 1994, during heavy rains that particularly affected the Camp de Tarragona. The bridge crossing the mouth was cut off on both sides, as the water swept away a piece of asphalt and caused the subsidence of part of the land. The flood resulted in one fatality, Pere Torres Esteller.

From a quarter to 10 to a quarter to 12, the Alforja stream reached its maximum hydraulic flow, and consequently, the side roads were flooded. The water began to overflow the pedestrian walkways, which collapsed, and it also reached the level of various bridges, which were left without railings. The old town of Cambrils and some streets near the stream were flooded, such as Carrer Immolats del Setge, Carrer Hospital, and Carrer Sant Plàcid. The Eixample area was also partially flooded, especially the streets Santa Joaquima de Vedruna and Àngel Guimerà. In the port area, Rambla Jaume I and all the streets leading to the port up to Plaza Aragó were also flooded. At half past eleven in the morning, the water level began to drop. Firefighters assisted several people who had been trapped in the currents of the water.

There were also floods of houses and commercial premises in the affected streets, and several parking lots were completely covered with water and mud, burying the vehicles that were parked there. The streets were filled with rubble and mud; specifically, Santa Joaquima de Vedruna street was heavily affected in the initial stretch near the stream, which was rendered unusable for several days, and the underground parking located there was filled to the ceiling with water and mud. A lot of rubble was floating in the sea, both inside and outside the port. The amount of sediment carried by the flood formed a small delta at its mouth. Likewise, the stream's bed suffered numerous damages: two collapsed bridges, burst walls, rows of trees swallowed, and sunken sidewalks. The Maspujols stream also widened and caused a partial collapse at the bridge on the road leading to Salou and the destruction of part of the facilities at the Cambrils-beach campsite. In the afternoon, the city council convened an extraordinary meeting in which various alert measures were established in case another eventuality occurred, and it was decided, among other measures, to request the designation of a disaster area for Cambrils. The initial assessment of the damages was estimated at 500 million pesetas, as in addition to the destruction of part of the stream's channel and the bridges crossing it, there were damages to the road network, electrical installations, drinking water conduits, and sewage systems. The stream's channel had to be completely rebuilt, and it was taken as an opportunity to improve the foundation of the retaining walls of the last stretch and to cement the last stretch of the bed to prevent erosion.

Article_Name: Plena d'en Gelat - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Flood of Gelat is the popular name given to an extraordinary flood of s'Albufera in Mallorca and sa Pobla, which took place in November 1852. As a result, a new outlet of the lagoon was opened, known since then as s'Oberta, which led to the project for the drainage of s'Albufera, after decades of proposals, finally being carried out. At the time, it was estimated that 100 million m³ of water accumulated over s'Albufera, and at the Son Amer estate, the water level reached 20 spans (4 meters) above the ground, 6 above sea level. The characteristics of the episode correspond to a combination of torrential floods from the headwaters, extreme rains over the affected area, and marine phenomena, similar to those caused by a cyclonic swell, all exacerbated by an insufficient outlet of s'Albufera.

The rain began on November 30, St. Andrew's Day, and persisted the next day, and it must have had a general character across the island, as the streams were full, the Torrent de Búger overflowed flooding sa Pobla along the main street. Around the village, near the Muro road, there was up to a meter of water (up to the belly of the livestock, according to witnesses). Simultaneously, there was a strong storm at sea from the east or southeast and the sea was very high, which prevented the accumulated water and the water flowing from the torrents of Sant Miquel and Muro from flowing out through the natural outlet of s'Albufera, at the Bridges. Eventually, the enormous amount of water, trapped between s'Albufera and sa Pobla, opened a breach in the dune bar 200 paces long and 5 fathoms deep (~260×~4 m.), at the same place where the Canal Gran currently flows into more than three kilometers from the previous point, which allowed the accumulated water to drain. The flooding did not cause human casualties, but a lot of livestock, especially bulls and mares, died. The effects were felt as far as Ciutadella, where the red water (aigua roja) from the great flood arrived. The irrigation ditches, which often served as boundaries between properties, were filled with mud, and it was not possible to identify the limits of rural properties until several days later.

The popular name that the flood took, a designation that indicates the filling of the s'Albufera basin more than the overflow of the watercourse, is due to Bartomeu Company Serra, nicknamed Gelat. Gelat and his cousin Pere Serra, alias Garrut, both professional fishermen, were sent at midnight on the thirtieth to retrieve the mares that were grazing in s'Albufera, by their owners. When they returned, at the marsh of Son Fornari, the flood did not allow them to continue, and to save themselves, they climbed onto a raft made of 1200 bundles of reeds that they found in the Garden of the Walnut Trees. Up there, they spent 30 hours, much of it standing, with the water up to their chests and tied to each other with the halters they had for the animals, until the water receded. The raft was not moved by the runoff because it was supported on the buttress of a canal and secured by ropes tied to large perforated stones that weighed it down. Surviving under such extreme conditions, when everyone thought they were dead, fixed the episode in the collective memory of the locals, which is integrated into the local collective imagination.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Sochi was a natural disaster that occurred in the city of Sochi and throughout the Sochi and Adler districts of Russia in June 2015, when nearly two months' worth of rainfall fell in a single day. As a result of the downpour, the maximum water level in local rivers exceeded by more than 1.2 meters. The railway station and airport were flooded, and their operations were suspended. The most common version of the catastrophic scale of the flood is considered to be the malfunctioning of the storm drainage system, which was "redesigned" in preparation for the Winter Olympics — the redesign was mostly done on paper, and the money was embezzled. The editor-in-chief of "BlogSochi," Alexander Valov, claims that during the construction of Olympic facilities, many natural drainage systems were destroyed, which could have channeled water during heavy rains. In addition, one of the reasons for the catastrophic flood he cites is that the pumps meant to drain rainwater stopped due to power outages. Sochi began to flood in September 2013 — during the construction of Olympic facilities, and in July 2014.

Whole_Text.content: The Alpine high water of 2000 is a natural disaster that occurred in October 2000 in the Central Alps. The damage event primarily affected the Italian region of Piedmont and the Swiss cantons of Ticino and Valais.

The large-scale weather situation in mid-October 2000, with the stable low-pressure area Josefine over the British Isles, caused a continuous flow of mild, humid warm air from North Africa over the Mediterranean to the southern edge of the Alps from October 10 to 16. The air was forced to rise at the mountains, which led to prolonged widespread heavy rainfall since October 11. Initially, the Piedmont region was particularly affected, but as the wind direction turned to the northwest on October 13 at the southern Alpine edge, the rain also reached areas above the main Alpine ridge in the Valais. The heaviest rainfall occurred on October 13 and 14 in the region of Domodossola and at the Simplon Pass, and then from October 14 to 15 in some southern side valleys of the Valais. A maximum rainfall of 580 mm was recorded on October 14 at Lago Paione. On October 16, the cold front moved eastward, and the precipitation decreased.

The rainfall caused one of the most severe flooding events in recent history in Piedmont. It rained heavily and continuously in all the major Alpine valleys of Piedmont, from the Susa Valley to the Aosta Valley, the Lanzo Valley, and the Canavese, down to the Sesia Valley and the Esca Valley, leading to widespread flooding throughout the Po basin. In addition to immense property damage, there were 23 fatalities, 128 injuries, 11 missing persons, and around 40 homeless individuals. The upper reaches of the Po were particularly affected by flooding in the Pellice Valley, and neighborhoods near the Po in Moncalieri and Turin were flooded, with the river in Turin temporarily carrying 2,300 cubic meters of water per second, significantly exceeding the severe flood of 1994. It was the largest flood in Turin since 1839. In Noasca and Bardonetto, bridges over the Orco collapsed during the flood, in Robassomero those over the Stura, in Ivrea (Settimo Vittone) a railway bridge, and in the Canavese, the water destroyed additional road bridges. In the Po plain below Turin, the side levees of the Po broke in several places, and numerous towns were flooded; the flood zone also extended downstream into an area in Lombardy and Emilia-Romagna.

The level of Lake Maggiore reached its highest point since 1867. The lake's high water was due to the strong inflow of the Toce in Italy, where a rain center was located in its catchment area. In contrast, the Maggia and the Ticino did not bring any unusual floods to the lake. On October 14, the lake overflowed its banks and slowly flooded the old town of Locarno. By October 17, the water continued to rise and eventually reached a record level that had never been measured in the 20th century. The flooding of Lake Maggiore affected residential and commercial areas, as well as sports facilities, public buildings, wastewater treatment plants, and clinics in the municipalities of Ascona, Brissago, Gordola, Minusio, Muralto, Tenero-Contra, and Gambarogno, in addition to Locarno. It was not until October 25 that the water had drained from Sesto Calende into the Ticino River towards the Po, allowing the lake to retreat back into its normal basin.

In the canton of Valais, the weather event affected the entire Rhône catchment area above Lake Geneva. The rain led to the worst flooding in Valais in the 20th century. On October 14 and 15, numerous streams and rivers in the canton overflowed, vast areas were flooded, debris flows destroyed numerous houses and buried villages and transportation facilities. Sixteen people lost their lives in Valais due to the event. In Stalden-Neubrück, a debris flow destroyed five buildings and interrupted the cantonal road and the Brig-Visp-Zermatt railway line, while the backed-up Vispa flooded the Stalden wastewater treatment plant. Below Zermatt, a lake formed due to a debris flow, submerging several buildings. The BVZ railway line between Brig and Zermatt was interrupted at several points and could only be put back into operation after 24 days. Debris flows destroyed houses and interrupted transportation routes in Mörel, in the Binntal, in Naters, and in Baltschieder. There, the Baltschiederbach flooded a settlement area of 733,000 square meters and left debris deposits of up to four meters high in the upper part of the village, destroying the water and electricity supply as well as telephone lines. Between Brig-Glis and Visp, the Gamsa flowed onto the construction site of the A9 motorway and over the railway lines of the SBB and BVZ. As a secondary consequence of the heavy rain in Upper Valais, there was severe flooding in Lower Valais. In Sion, the Vissingen Canal overflowed and flooded a commercial area. In Chamoson, the right bank of the Rhône dam broke, exposing the gas pipeline of the Gazoduc du Rhône, which lay unprotected above ground. Water flowed through the breach in the dam into the Rhône plain, washing debris and mud onto agricultural crops. A dam on the canal from Sion to Riddes also broke, and water overflowed from the canal from Leytron to Fully. The commercial area of Saillon, with several wineries, was flooded. In total, 1,027 hectares were finally underwater in the Rhône plain during the event.

The most severe single disaster affected the village of Gondo. A landslide above the village caused a protective wall to collapse on October 14, and the large mass of rock, soil, and debris from the wall struck several buildings below and slid further down into the gorge of the Doveria, which was experiencing flooding due to the rain. Ten houses were destroyed and 13 people lost their lives. The three-hundred-year-old Stockalperturm was damaged. Additionally, the flooding at the Doveria and the river Grosses Wasser in the Zwischbergental destroyed protective structures and bank reinforcements.
After the severe Rhône flood of 2000, detailed planning for the third Rhône correction in Valais began.

On October 14 and 15, numerous streams and rivers in the canton overflowed, vast areas were flooded, debris flows destroyed numerous houses and buried villages and transport facilities. Sixteen people lost their lives in Valais due to the event. In Stalden-Neubrück, a debris flow destroyed five buildings and interrupted the cantonal road and the Brig-Visp-Zermatt railway line, while the dammed-up Vispa flooded the Stalden wastewater treatment plant. Below Zermatt, a lake formed due to a debris flow, submerging several buildings. The BVZ railway line between Brig and Zermatt was interrupted at several points and could only be put back into operation after 24 days. Debris flows destroyed houses and interrupted transport routes in Mörel, in the Binntal, in Naters, and in Baltschieder. There, the Baltschiederbach flooded a settlement area of 733,000 square meters and left debris deposits of up to four meters high in the upper part of the village, destroying the water and electricity supply as well as telephone lines. Between Brig-Glis and Visp, the Gamsa flowed onto the construction site of the A9 motorway and over the railway lines of the SBB and BVZ. As a secondary consequence of the heavy rain in Upper Valais, there was severe flooding in Lower Valais. In Sion, the Vissingen Canal overflowed and flooded a commercial area. In Chamoson, the right bank of the Rhône dam broke, exposing the gas pipeline of the Gazoduc du Rhône, which lay unprotected above the ground. Water flowed through the breach in the dam into the Rhône plain, washing away debris and mud onto agricultural crops. A dam on the canal from Sion to Riddes also broke, and water overflowed from the canal from Leytron to Fully. The commercial area of Saillon, with several wineries, was flooded. In total, 1,027 hectares were finally underwater during the event in the Rhône plain.

The most severe single disaster affected the village of Gondo. A landslide above the village caused a protective wall to collapse on October 14, and the large mass of rock, soil, and debris from the wall struck several buildings below and slid further down into the gorge of the Doveria, which was experiencing flooding due to the rain. Ten houses were destroyed and 13 people lost their lives. The three-hundred-year-old Stockalperturm was damaged. Additionally, the flooding at the Doveria and the river Grosses Wasser in the Zwischbergental destroyed protective structures and bank reinforcements.
After the severe Rhône flood of 2000, detailed planning for the third Rhône correction in Valais began.

Floods in Serbia occurred after heavy rainfall and a strong cyclone that affected the central part of the Balkan Peninsula in the second half of May 2014. The rainfall covered the entire area of Serbia, and over 100 liters of rain per square meter were recorded in 24 hours. Absolute rainfall maxima were recorded on May 15 in Belgrade (107.9), Loznica (110), and Valjevo (108.2). As a result of swollen rivers, landslides, and flooding, more than 30 people lost their lives. A state of emergency was declared on May 15.

Cyclone Tamara (also known as Donat in Croatia or Ivet in Central Europe) affected the area of Central and Southeastern Europe on May 13, 2014. It spread over a large horizontal area, with vertical thickness of several kilometers throughout the troposphere. A low-pressure area formed over the Adriatic when cold and moist polar air penetrated the Mediterranean region. This polar front collided with a moist subtropical front, leading to the formation of very low pressure. On May 14, the cyclonic field moved towards the Balkans and "settled" over the area of Serbia, Croatia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The saturation of the air mass was around 100%, and humidity increased due to warm air from the south and east. The physical-geographical specificity of the Balkan Peninsula also favored the development of such a low-pressure area. The center of the cyclonic field was over Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, where between May 13 and 15, a large amount of precipitation was recorded, the highest ever recorded since meteorological observations began. The weakening and disappearance of the cyclone began on May 16 and ended on May 18.

Heavy rain caused by a cyclone over the Balkan Peninsula fell almost continuously between May 13 and 16 in Serbia and neighboring countries. Over 100 liters per square meter were recorded within 24 hours, and a total of over 200 liters of precipitation fell over three days - the most in Valjevo, Belgrade, Loznica, and Novi Sad. The large amount of rainfall led to the emergence of flash floods, flooding, and the triggering of numerous landslides. This was also the rainiest May month in history. The multi-year average for this time of year is around 70 millimeters of precipitation; however, in 2014, as much as 214 liters per square meter fell (Belgrade).
The tables provide an overview of municipalities by districts that have been partially or completely flooded.

On May 14, a severe storm caused flash floods and rivers to overflow their banks. This led to the declaration of a state of emergency in 16 municipalities in Serbia. The Kolubara River overflowed along with its tributaries Ljig and Kacer, followed by the Bolečka River, Skrapež, Jadar, and West Morava. Low-lying areas near the rivers in Valjevo, Lajkovac, Ub, as well as in the municipality of Ljig and Gornji Milanovac, Kosjerić, Loznica, the vicinity of Novi Sad (Petrovaradin, Futog), as well as in Mala Moštanica and Mislođin were flooded. Rescue teams evacuated several dozen citizens from areas affected by heavy rainfall.

During the night between May 14 and 15, rescue services evacuated over 500 people from affected areas. A state of emergency was declared across the entire territory of Serbia. In Topola, a firefighter lost their life during the rescue operation. Heavy rainfall led to the flooding of the Kolubara River near the coal mining basin, resulting in a suspension of operations. Over 85,000 people across the country were left without electricity, and a large number of houses and homes were flooded. Due to the large amount of water and landslides, certain parts of the municipality of Loznica were cut off. Due to the critical situation in the country, representatives from several European countries offered humanitarian aid, with Russia and Slovenia being among the first.

The situation significantly worsened on May 16 when several cities and towns were left without electricity - including Lazarevac, Paraćin, Smederevska Palanka, as well as parts of Šabac and Obrenovac. During the day, a large amount of water overflowed from the Kolubara River and flooded Obrenovac and the surrounding area. The evacuation of the entire city and neighboring settlements began, involving numerous rescue services and units (military, gendarmerie, firefighters, etc.). Obrenovac was covered by water several meters high. Due to heavy rainfall, the water level of the Sava River was rising in the areas of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia. After a public call, a large number of volunteers from all over Serbia gathered and were sent to Šabac and Sremska Mitrovica to build dams and levees along the banks. In most areas where electricity supply was interrupted, the water was not drinkable. By the end of the day, 15,200 people had been evacuated from the affected areas, with the majority coming from Obrenovac. The critical situation was in Svijlanac, Paraćin, Krupanj, and many other places, where most settlements were flooded or cut off due to landslides and mudslides.

On the night between May 16 and 17, over 10,000 volunteers participated in building sandbag barriers in Šabac and Sremska Mitrovica. People near the embankment were evacuated as a precaution. The situation was severe in Krupanj, where around 200 houses were destroyed due to landslides, and communications were hindered. Ljig was without electricity and water. A large number of landslides occurred in all affected areas. Water partially receded from Gornji Milanovac, Trstenik, Kocelev, and Svilajnac. The Great Morava River overflowed near Varvarin and close to Ćićevac. Water penetrated the surface mines of the Kolubara coal basin - Veliki Crljen and Tamnava-West Field. By the end of the day, a total of 16,300 people had been evacuated, mostly from Obrenovac and Barič.

On May 18, the cyclone that affected heavy rainfall in Serbia and the region moved towards the southern part of the Mediterranean. In the municipality of Požarevac, the river Mlava overflowed. The water threatened the Kostolac thermal power plant and the Drmno coal mine. The water level in Obrenovac decreased, but evacuation continued. For health and safety reasons, entry into Obrenovac was prohibited without special permission.

A total of about 25,000 people were evacuated from the flooded areas. People were evacuated from the surroundings of Sremska Mitrovica and Šabac, as well as from the Šid villages of Morović and Višnjićevo. Volunteers and special services reinforced the embankments on the Sava, Mlava, and Kolubara rivers. In Belgrade, preventive embankments were set up in the municipalities of Savski Venac, Stari Grad, Čukarica, Novi Beograd, and Palilula. Due to the rising water levels of the Sava in the village of Zabrežje, a complete evacuation of Obrenovac was initiated.

On May 20, the water levels of the Sava and Danube rivers were rising. A total of over 30,000 people were evacuated. In Obrenovac, entry was prohibited to everyone except teams engaged in cleaning and sanitation of the area. The protective embankments in Kostolac were reinforced to preserve the coal mines and thermal power plant. The reservoir at Đerdap was emptied to prepare for the upcoming wave of water. Due to the rising water levels of the Danube, the population in the floodplain of the Smederevo municipality was evacuated. The Government of the Republic of Serbia declared May 21, 22, and 23 as days of mourning.

The Sava River level has dropped by about 10 centimeters. The Danube River level was rising, so a regular flood defense was declared in Novi Sad and Golubac. Villages around Obrenovac (Mislodjin, Drazevac, etc.) received water for technical use. In Smederevo, an emergency flood defense was declared, and the city port was submerged. Volunteers and services continued to strengthen existing embankments, raise new ones, and repair those that had given way. Evacuations in Obrenovac continued. A total of 2,260 structures were flooded in Serbia by May 21.

On May 22, a partial return of the population to the flooded areas began. Residents of Barič were allowed to return to their homes, and a portion of the residents of Obrenovac (men) came to their city to help with damage repair and cleaning. The water level of the Danube rose near Bačka Palanka, Novi Sad, Slankamen, Pančevo, and Zemun, while the level of the Tisa increased near Titel. After seven days, electricity was restored in Obrenovac, and coal mining from the Kolubara basin for the needs of TENT was resumed. Gendarmerie units and special sanitation teams continued to clean the flooded areas of mud, bulky waste, and animal carcasses.

The water level of the Bosut and its tributary Studva rose by 10 millimeters every hour in the territory of Serbia, due to the large amount of water flowing from Croatia. During the night between May 22 and 23, the Mlava River breached the embankment near Kostolac. In Rakovica, a landslide caused by a landslide covered the road near the Strazevica tunnel, but it was quickly removed. Smederevska Palanka received water from the water supply after eight days. A total of about 38,000 residents were evacuated, of which 25,000 from the Obrenovac area. The state of emergency in Serbia was lifted, but it remained in two cities and 17 municipalities that were still affected by the floods (Sremska Mitrovica, Sabac, then Obrenovac, Ljig, Krupanj, Ub, Lajkovac, Smederevska Palanka, Osjecina, Paracin, Mionica, Svilajnac, Kosjeric, Bajina Basta, Mali Zvornik, Koceljeva, and Vladimirci).

The state of emergency has been lifted in Trstenik and the population has begun to return to their homes. The Sava and Danube were stagnant, and a state of emergency for flood protection was declared in Zemun. Sanitation and cleaning in Obrenovac continued, and due to numerous landslides on the Loznica-Ljubovija road near Mali Zvornik, the construction of an alternative road 11 km long has begun.

The levels of the Danube and Sava rivers were declining. After ten days, electricity production was initiated at the Nikola Tesla A thermal power plant. Classes in primary and secondary schools in Ćuprija were resumed. In Krupanj, the dam at the antimony mine "Stolice" burst, leading to the spillage of toxic tailings and a potential environmental problem.

Due to heavy rainfall between May 25 and 26, several houses in the municipality of Grocka were flooded. The Gročica River and the Begaljica Stream overflowed in Zaklopča. Heavy rains also flooded the center of Pančevo. In Smederevska Palanka and Loznica, the state of emergency was lifted due to the improvement of the overall situation in those municipalities. In Kragujevac, over 50 liters of rain fell, leading to the flooding of several industrial facilities and residential houses, especially in the neighborhoods of Beloševac and Lekina Bara. Due to the situation, a state of emergency was declared in the city. In the settlement of Bresnica, the Bresnica Stream overflowed, and in the Zastava Arms factory, part of the production facility was flooded.

As a result of heavy rains and floods, numerous landslides were triggered across Serbia, a large number of residential and commercial buildings were submerged, over 1,000 were damaged or threatened, and more than 30,000 residents were evacuated from affected areas. The preliminary estimated damage amounted to around 1,000,000,000 euros. The table above shows the rivers and streams according to hydrological basins (Sava, Morava, Danube) that overflowed between May 14 and May 21, 2014. More than 60 watercourses overflowed their banks in areas affected by floods.

Due to heavy rainfall, hundreds of landslides have been triggered across Serbia. In Mali Zvornik, a landslide covered the main road. In Bajina Bašta, landslides have destroyed and threatened around 300 houses. In Kosjerić, over 600 landslides have been registered, and in Gornji Milanovac, about 300. In Krupanj, land movements combined with flash floods caused significant damage and affected over 500 homes. Landslides have also been activated in the areas of the municipalities of Požega, Čačak (100), Kraljevo (60), and Valjevo (100). In Belgrade, a strip along the Sava and Danube rivers from Barič to Karaburma and further to Ritoplek is at risk. Landslides have also occurred in the municipality of Ljig, where 50 houses were destroyed in the village of Ba. Besides the most affected areas, landslides have also been triggered around Niš (Gabrovac, Gornji Matejevac), near Bojnik, Medveđa, and Lebane, as well as in parts of the Pčinja district.

Floods and landslides have damaged and destroyed about 4,500 km of roads and 250 bridges. 2,260 buildings (houses, structures, commercial facilities, etc.) have been submerged, and about 1,800 are at risk. Agriculture has suffered significant damage, reflected in about 80,000 hectares of flooded arable land, which is about 2% of the total arable land in Serbia. In the Kolubara coal basin, a dam broke, and the Kolubara River overflowed, completely flooding two basins, Veliki Crljen and Tamnava-West Field. A total of over 150 million cubic meters of water flowed into both mines, reaching a depth of 50–60 m. Half of Serbia's total electricity production comes from the Kolubara basins. Rail traffic was interrupted on most routes due to damage to the tracks. The tracks were damaged on the Belgrade-Bar line near Lajkovac and on the Belgrade-Niš line near Jagodina and Bagrdan, and between Paraćin and Ćićevac, where the flood washed away 150 m of track. On the Prahovo-Zaječar route, the track was buried by a landslide, as well as part near Kraljevo in the settlement of Vitanovac.

Over 31,000 people have been evacuated from the affected areas. They have been placed in reception centers across Serbia, mostly in Belgrade. The largest number of evacuees is from Obrenovac (about 24,000), which was the most endangered. The rescue efforts involved the police, gendarmerie, special police units, firefighters, the army, volunteers, and rescuers from several countries in Europe and the surrounding region. The largest reception centers for the displaced were: Belgrade Fair (over 500), Belgrade Arena, Pioneer Hall (about 250), Old and New DIF, as well as the Šumice sports center, numerous primary schools, other sports centers, hotels, student dormitories, and others.

A large amount of water and mud that lingered for several days in flooded areas led to the development of potential sanitary problems. The warm weather and water favored the development of mosquitoes, then rodents, and various other pests. Contaminated water was a source of infectious diseases, such as dysentery and leptospirosis. The flood also destroyed and contaminated numerous crops and plants, and it killed a significant number of livestock and other domestic animals (dogs, cats), creating conditions for other diseases. Special teams removed over 200 tons of dead animals from the affected areas.

During and after the floods, a large number of individuals, organizations, associations, and states sent humanitarian aid to the affected areas and population. The aid consisted of food and water, as well as clothing, hygiene products, blankets, and mattresses. In addition, financial assistance was deposited into designated accounts of the Government of the Republic of Serbia.

The rescue of the population involved dozens of members of special teams from several European countries (Russia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Austria, France, Hungary, Macedonia, Denmark, Slovakia, Romania, Montenegro, EULEX). The teams were engaged in evacuating residents from endangered areas, pumping water, transporting people, delivering aid (food, water), etc. Humanitarian aid was sent by Russia, the United Nations, the European Union, as well as Azerbaijan, Belarus, Slovenia, Montenegro, Macedonia, the Jewish Foundation, Croatia, Romania, and others. It consisted of basic human necessities, as well as rescue helicopters, boats, special pumps for water removal, and dehumidifiers. In addition to government representatives, assistance also came from numerous organizations — the Association of Serbs from Vienna, the Serbian-Russian Humanitarian Center, and others.

The renewal and construction of areas affected by floods began with the cleaning and sanitation of the terrain. More than 200 young people and volunteers are participating in the cleaning and other necessary tasks in Paraćin, Svilajnac, Kostolac, and Krupanj.
