Article_Name: Inundaciones del río Murray en 1956, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods of the Murray River in 1956

Whole_Text.content: Most of Australia has a very dry climate, and the central and southwestern part of the island-continent constitutes the Great Australian Desert, one of the largest in the world (about 2.5 million km²). Only the northern part of the island-continent, which is already in the intertropical zone, as well as the southeastern mountains (Australian Alps), have a somewhat rainier climate. The Murray River, in turn, has an irregular flow regime and relatively low flow, which is due to its long course through arid climate regions. Thus, although the Murray River with its tributaries (Darling, Murrumbidgee, and others) constitutes the largest river system in Australia, covering more than one million km², its economic benefits for agriculture, industry, and drinking water supply are not well developed, and there are possibilities to increase them through comprehensive basin planning. The Murray is a river that experiences strong floods and long periods of low water, so more multipurpose dams (hydroelectric, irrigation, flood control, and others) need to be built, infrastructure works must be carried out to prevent damage in the populations located mainly on the right bank of the river from the confluence with the Darling to the mouth, and areas of insufficient drainage must be channeled (which in Australia are called billabong and correspond in Spanish to the terms of abandoned meanders, horseshoe lakes, swamps, or sporadically flooded areas, etc.).

Whole_Text.header: Asymmetry of the Murray River basin
Whole_Text.content: When talking about the floods in the Australian Murray River basin, it should be noted that, as it is located in the southern hemisphere, any moving body like the water of a river tends to deviate to the right, that is, the opposite of what happens in the northern hemisphere. However, this deviation is not real but apparent, as it is not that the river water deviates to the right, but rather that the Earth's surface rotates from right to left (from east to west), that is, counterclockwise. This means that, in a moving body with a constant direction (like the Foucault pendulum), the apparent deviation would be from left to right, or in other words, clockwise, for the simple reason that the base of the pendulum, that is, the Earth's surface, rotates in the opposite direction (counterclockwise). This is why practically all the cities affected by the floods in the Murray basin in 1956 were located on the right bank of the river. Among the flooded cities at that time, we can mention, including their location on Google Maps: Colignan, Iraak, which no longer exists and was replaced by a lake that is now almost dried up, Mannum, Murray Bridge, Mildura, Nangiloc, whose name is spelled backward from Colignan, Red Cliffs, Renmark, Wentworth, and others. All the indicated populations are located on the right bank of the Murray River (except for a couple of cases, where the population is divided in two by the river itself, as happens in Murray Bridge, although it is an exception that confirms the rule because the force of the flood affected the part of the city on the right bank. The case of Iraak, which is somewhat separated from the Murray River and is now practically uninhabited, is due to the fact that it was originally a military camp during World War II (it also had prisoners) and during the floods of 1956 it was flooded, creating a lake that still exists: on one hand, the location was a precarious and risky area and was only justified by temporary use as a military zone. On the other hand, the floods of that year highlighted the risk of that location and worsened the initial problem: it was probably easier to dismantle the camp and move than to carry out infrastructure works aimed at minimizing or eliminating the risks of that location. The Google Earth program is very useful for assessing the flood risk situation of any location in Australia (or anywhere) since by moving the cursor over the satellite image we automatically have the height in meters above sea level of any point, and this can indicate how frequent a situation is where the natural levees of a river are at a higher elevation than the surrounding plain, which is precisely why it is called a floodplain. In the specific case of Wentworth, which is located on the right bank of the Darling River at the confluence of this river with the Murray, the main reason for the flooding was not directly due to the rise of this river, but rather that this rise backed up the waters of the Darling upstream of the confluence, overflowing to the north of the population, which was almost completely flooded for some time. In a desert or semi-desert climate, most rivers are allochthonous and can have enormous floods due to the irregularity of the rains, which can be very scarce for years but can also be very intense and disastrous on some sporadic occasions, exacerbated by the fact that the large amount of sediment carried by the river waters (due to the sparse vegetation cover in a dry climate) tends to raise the riverbed and the natural levees, especially the left one, in the case of the Murray River because we are in the southern hemisphere. This is why most of the floods from the overflow of the river waters occurred on its right bank.

Whole_Text.header: The anomalous weather in the south and southeast of Australia in 1956
Whole_Text.content: Australia constitutes an isolated continent or, conversely, an island of continental scale. It is crossed by the Tropic of Capricorn in the northern part of the country, so this area already has an intertropical climate (savanna, jungle in some places, and especially dry subtropical climate). Most of the territory has a desert or semi-desert climate (the deserts of Australia cover more than 2 million km²) and oceanic influences are very powerful, giving rise to tropical and extratropical storms, often very intense: In the specific case of Australia, having a relatively dry climate makes it an irregular climate, with years and even decades of very scarce rainfall and brief periods (weeks or months) of extraordinarily intense rain. In 1956, a rainy period of just over 3 months was recorded, leading to a huge flood that peaked in Morgan, South Australia, at 12.3 m, and these floods were felt up to 100 km away from the riverbanks. In the specific case of Morgan, it is also located on the right bank of the river (just like the previously mentioned towns) with the aggravating factor of being in a 90° bend of the Murray River to the left, which concentrated the effects of the flood due to the natural right levee being lower than the left in the southern hemisphere, so the centrifugal force of the flow in the river bend acted towards the location of that town. This location can be seen on Google Maps: Morgan, South Australia.

Article_Name: Inundación de la Ciudad de México en 1629, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Mexico City in 1629 was an event that began on September 21 of that year, caused by heavy rain that lasted approximately 40 hours and resulted in the total flooding of the city. The water level reached just over two meters, and the city remained flooded for five years, from September 1629 to 1634. Of the 20,000 Spanish families that were in the city at that time, only 400 remained. The viceroy Rodrigo Pacheco y Osorio, III Marquis of Cerralbo, implemented several measures not only to alleviate the situation but also to prevent more people from leaving the city.

Tenochtitlan was founded in the lowest part of the Mexico basin, which has always been the main cause of its vulnerability due to its geographical location. Faced with recurrent flooding, the Mexicas developed systems to control the rise of the waters, such as containment walls and aqueducts. With the implemented systems, they were able not only to supply themselves with clean water for consumption but also to prevent flooding. The Spaniards, despite being aware of the existing soil subsidence problems in Tenochtitlan, decided to establish the capital of New Spain there for political reasons. In addition to the geographical location, there were other changes that resulted in the rise of water levels: environmental changes, deforestation, and the expansion of crops that led to soil erosion. All of this contributed to the city flooding on several occasions.

After these events, the construction of the Nochistongo Cut was approved to drain water from the city. The tunnel would have a length of 6,600 meters, a width of 3.50 meters, and a height of 4.50 meters.

When the rain started, Enrico Martínez advised the viceroy Rodrigo Pacheco y Osorio to close the outlet of the Huehuetoca drain, which was under construction, to prevent it from being destroyed. When the viceroy realized that this was only preventing the water from flowing out, he ordered the drain to be uncovered, but it was too late. The city was underwater, many houses collapsed, others were flooded, and their inhabitants could only stay on the second floor. The unsanitary conditions, scarcity, and disease that followed the flood caused the death of approximately 30,000 people in the following years. The flood also caused many people to emigrate from the city, most of whom settled in the city of Puebla. The viceroy wanted to prevent more people from leaving and took several measures to provide people with confidence and peace of mind that the situation would improve.

Whole_Text.header: Measures of the Marquis of Cerralbo
Whole_Text.content: The viceroy called a meeting to decide what measures would be taken. It was decided to request a loan of 6,000 pesos to be used for buying and distributing food daily in the most affected neighborhoods. Food would also be sold to people who could afford it but had no means of transportation. Wooden bridges were built to make it possible to cross from one building to another. Canoes were also used for transportation within the city. To prevent more houses from collapsing, it was ordered that each homeowner build a kind of wall attached to their wall to prevent the foundations from weakening. The measures taken to alleviate the situation were not sufficient; it was also necessary to drain the water from the city. To this end, the viceroy ordered the continuation of the construction of the Huehuetoca drainage system, which, after being opened, was damaged by the water.

There was a belief that the heavy rains were a punishment for the sins of the city. It was accepted that masses could be held on rooftops or balconies so that people could hear them from their homes. In an unprecedented event, on September 24, Archbishop Don Francisco Manso y Zúñiga allowed the image of the Virgin of Guadalupe to be taken by canoe from her Basilica to the city center. Given the situation and the lack of a short-term solution, the viceroy proposed to the city council the option of moving the capital to another city. But the city council responded that it would cost more money to change the capital than it would to rebuild it. It was decided that the only viable solution would be to find an effective drainage system. In 1634, the Carmelite friar and architect Andrés de San Miguel, at the request of the viceroy, corrected the drainage ditch of Mexico City, which had been built by Enrico Martínez, allowing the water to exit the city and enabling its reconstruction.

Article_Name: 平成27年9月関東・東北豪雨

Whole_Text.content: The heavy rain disaster in the Kanto and Tohoku regions from September 9 to 11, 2015 (Heisei 27), is known as the Heisei 27 September Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain.

Typhoon No. 18, which occurred on September 7, made landfall in the Tokai region on September 9 and became an extratropical low-pressure system over the Sea of Japan that night. Although the direct damage from this typhoon was not significant, moist warm air flowed in from the Pacific Ocean into the extratropical low-pressure system that had transformed from the typhoon moving northeast over the Sea of Japan, colliding with the moist winds blowing in from Typhoon No. 17, which was approaching the Japanese archipelago from the sea east of Japan. This resulted in the continuous formation of rain clouds (linear precipitation bands) extending north and south. Heavy rainfall exceeding 300 millimeters within 24 hours caused large-scale damage, particularly in the northern Kanto region and southern Tohoku region. On September 9, heavy rain centered in the northern Kanto region was recorded, with AMeDAS observations from midnight on September 7 to 5 PM on September 10 showing over 300 millimeters in various locations in Tochigi Prefecture, including 551.0 millimeters in Nikko City, Iroha, and 541.0 millimeters in Nikko City, Imaichi. Additionally, total precipitation was recorded at over 400 millimeters in various locations in Tochigi Prefecture, including 645.5 millimeters in Imaichi, 622.0 millimeters in Iroha, 561.5 millimeters in Torobe, and 523.0 millimeters in Kanuma. At 12:20 AM on September 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for all of Tochigi Prefecture, and at 7:45 AM, a special heavy rain warning was issued for almost all of Ibaraki Prefecture, urging maximum vigilance against river flooding, landslides, and flooding in low-lying areas, while also calling for strict vigilance in surrounding prefectures. The area of rain gradually moved to the Tohoku region, and at 3:20 AM on the 11th, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for Miyagi Prefecture. The special heavy rain warnings issued for each prefecture were lifted in Tochigi Prefecture at 6 AM on the 11th, in Ibaraki Prefecture at 8:15 AM on the same day, and in Miyagi Prefecture at 7:30 PM. On September 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency named the heavy rain and the resulting disasters that struck the Kanto and Tohoku regions "The September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain." The Geospatial Information Authority of Japan established a special page on its official website for "The September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain," providing information on the disaster using topographic maps and aerial photographs. On October 6, the government decided in a cabinet meeting to designate the areas of Minamiaizu Town in Minamiaizu District and Showa Village in Onuma District as "Localized Severe Disaster" under the law concerning special financial assistance for dealing with severe disasters related to agricultural damage, which was announced and enacted on the 7th. This resulted in the national government increasing the cost-sharing ratio for municipalities conducting restoration work on farmland and agricultural facilities to as much as 90%. The heavy rain in Tochigi Prefecture and flooding in Ibaraki Prefecture have been compared to Typhoon No. 4 in 1998. While Typhoon No. 4 recorded intense rain with over 1000 mm of precipitation, the Kanto-Tohoku heavy rain had a total precipitation of about 600 mm, with hourly rainfall of about 50 to 70 mm (no record of extreme short-duration heavy rain was announced during the period).

The total precipitation observed from September 7 to September 11 was 647.5 mm in Imaichi, Nikko City, Tochigi Prefecture, and 536.0 mm in Funabiki, Marumori Town, Miyagi Prefecture, exceeding 600 mm in the Kanto region and 500 mm in the Tohoku region, resulting in heavy rainfall that was more than double the average monthly precipitation for September.

According to a summary of damage as of October 18, 2017, by the Fire and Disaster Management Agency (including damage from Typhoon No. 18), there have been 20 confirmed deaths: 15 in Ibaraki Prefecture, 3 in Tochigi Prefecture, and 2 in Miyagi Prefecture. Additionally, there are 82 injured nationwide, 81 completely destroyed houses, 7,090 partially destroyed houses, 384 houses with some damage, 2,523 houses with flooding above the floor, 13,259 houses with flooding below the floor, and 1,722 non-residential buildings affected. It has also been confirmed that breaches, overflow, leaks, flooding, and collapses of embankments occurred in 5 rivers managed by the national government and 80 rivers managed by prefectural governments. According to a tally published at 5 PM on September 13, evacuation orders were issued for approximately 240,000 people across 1 metropolis and 19 prefectures from Iwate Prefecture to Kagawa Prefecture since the 8th, and evacuation advisories were issued for about 3.15 million people. Even a year after the breach of the Kinugawa River embankment, 197 people from 79 households in Joso City continue to live in temporary housing provided by the prefecture and city.

In Joso City, Ibaraki Prefecture, from early morning on September 10, flooding and leakage from levees occurred at several locations along the Kinugawa River, and at 12:50 PM, one levee in Misaka Town of the same city collapsed. As a result, a wide area between the Kinugawa and Kobai Rivers in Joso City was submerged, leading to direct casualties of 2 deaths, 12 disaster-related deaths, and over 40 injuries, in addition to significant damage including flooding of the newly completed Joso City Hall, which was built in 2014 incorporating lessons from the Great East Japan Earthquake, and more than 5,000 houses being completely or partially destroyed. In response to this incident, Joso City established a verification committee to compile a report. Additionally, due to flooding of generators and damage to facilities at Tokyo Electric Power Company's Kinugawa Power Plant (Nikko City), Michigahara Power Plant (Shioya Town), and Akagawa Power Plant (Nasushiobara City), power generation was halted. Furthermore, due to landslides causing transmission towers to tilt and disconnect, power supply to the Yagan Railway Aizu Kinugawa Line was disrupted, leading to service suspension on that line. Additionally, at the Kinugawa Onsen in Nikko City, Tochigi Prefecture, an outdoor bath at a hotel facing the Kinugawa River collapsed. Tochigi City’s Heya Elementary School and Oyama City’s Hakawa Nishi Elementary School announced plans to resume classes by borrowing vacant classrooms from other schools, as their school buildings and gymnasiums were submerged due to flooding. The end-of-term ceremony for the second semester was held in hallways and music rooms since the gymnasium was under renovation. In March 2016, renovations of the gymnasium at Hakawa Nishi Elementary School were completed, and a restoration ceremony was held on March 9. The Oyama Driving School suffered damage with 14 out of 18 vehicles submerged and had to suspend operations, but resumed business on November 11, 2015.

On the 11th, the Mogami River flooded in Mogami Town, Mogami District, Yamagata Prefecture. In Osaki City, Miyagi Prefecture, the levee of the Shibuigawa River, part of the Naruse River system, collapsed, and in Kurokawa District, Tomiya Town, and Yamato Town, the Yoshida River and its tributaries, Zen River and Takebayashi River, flooded. In Iitate Village, Soma District, Fukushima Prefecture, 395 bags containing decontamination waste from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant accident, which had been accumulated in the village, were washed away due to river flooding caused by the typhoon. At least 167 of the discovered bags were damaged, and it is believed that the soil and grass inside them were lost. Additionally, two bags that were washed away to the Haranomachi area of Minamisoma City also had their contents lost.

Tobu Railway suffered damage on various lines within Tochigi Prefecture. The Tobu Nikko Line was suspended between Shinkanamachi Station and Shimokamiyama Station due to landslide inflow at Shimokamiyama Station and embankment washout between Shinkanamachi Station and Kitakanuma Station. The Tobu Utsunomiya Line was suspended between Anzuka Station and Nishikawada Station due to the loss of the bridge pier and girder of the Sugigawa No. 2 floodway bridge. The Tobu Kinugawa Line was suspended between Shimokamiyama Station and Shinfujiwara Station due to embankment washout between Shintakutoku Station and Kosagoe Station, and track gravel washout between Kosagoe Station and Kinugawa Onsen Station. Bus services were provided for the suspended sections, and transfers to other companies' lines were also conducted. Some sections of Tobu Railway were restored by September 18, and the remaining sections were fully restored by October 7. The Kanto Railway Joso Line was flooded between Kogane Station and Sodo Station due to the collapse of the Kinugawa levee, and the operational base at Mito Kaido Vehicle Base was also damaged. As a result, the entire line between Toride Station and Shimodate Station was suspended. Train operations were resumed between Toride Station and Mito Kaido Station and between Shimotsuma Station and Shimodate Station by September 18, and on October 10, train operations were resumed on the remaining section between Mito Kaido Station and Shimotsuma Station, but this was a temporary restoration with significantly fewer trains than usual. Normal operations resumed on November 16, and rapid services were also restarted. The Kominato Railway Line was suspended between Kazusa-Okubo Station and Yoro Keikoku Station due to embankment washout, affecting the section between Kazusa-Ushiku Station and Kazusa-Nakano Station. Train operations were resumed between Kazusa-Ushiku Station and Tsukizaki Station by September 16, but the restoration of the embankment and the removal of landslides took time, and the resumption of operations between Tsukizaki Station and Kazusa-Nakano Station was on October 24 of the same year.

Whole_Text.content: The floods in Iraq in 2015 occurred in November 2015 in several Iraqi cities (such as Baghdad, Basra, and Kut) after heavy rainfall. The heavy rains caused the sewage systems to overflow, resulting in floods that submerged many areas in central and southern Iraq. These floods led to the deaths of more than 50 people due to electric shock from fallen power lines in the water, which electrocuted citizens through the water.

Whole_Text.content: The Santa Lucia flood was a flood that affected several European countries between December 13 and 14, 1287, and is named after the saint of the day, Lucia of Syracuse. As in other similar disasters in the area, such as the 1953 flood in the Netherlands, the phenomenon occurred due to the conjunction of a spring tide and a storm with low atmospheric pressure. The most severe consequences took place in Frisia, with about 50,000 direct deaths. The alteration of the land was such that a new sea, the Zuiderzee, was created, which had previously been a freshwater lake, the Flevo. The force of the tide collapsed the dunes that separated it from open waters, thus creating a new ocean entrance. Dozens of towns disappeared under the waves, new ports were created, and the need for more protection systems for coastal areas became evident, as the dike system installed in Western Frisia saved a large part of this region. The flood was also strongly felt in the British Isles, where the storm and waves buried entire hamlets. Some commercial ports, such as Dunwich, disappeared, causing significant economic losses. In the medium term, the flood contributed to waves of migration of people who did not feel safe in coastal areas and to new bogs generated or who had lost everything and sought ways to make a living in inland cities. It also affected the linguistic distribution of Frisian, which saw its area of influence reduced due to the death toll and population movements. Because of all this impact, the Santa Lucia flood is considered the fifth most important in recorded history, both for the high number of victims and for the consequences on relief, economy, language, and demographics over time.

Whole_Text.content: The Danube flood of 1830 in Vienna from February 26 to March 10, 1830, was an exceptionally strong flood of the Danube. It was the last major Danube flood in Vienna triggered by an ice jam.

The flood inundated Leopoldstadt in today's 2nd district and other settlements near the Danube such as Floridsdorf, Leopoldau, and Rossau, causing enormous damage. On February 28, 1830, drifting ice formed an ice jam at Stadlau, which then broke on the night of March 1. The masses of water made their way from Leopoldau through Breitenlee, Markgrafneusiedl, Großhofen, Glinzendorf, Rutzendorf, Kimmerleinsdorf, Breitstetten, Haringsee, Straudorf, and Wagram on the Danube, flowing over the Marchfeld and re-entering the riverbed of the Danube at Stopfenreuth. A total of 74 people lost their lives due to the flood wave. Kimmerleinsdorf was almost completely destroyed. The streams of the Vienna Woods and the Wien River could also no longer drain and overflowed their banks. Large parts of the urban area were underwater for days. However, the city was hit much worse by the subsequent cholera epidemic, which was triggered by the flooded cesspools and the contaminated groundwater. By December 1831, around 2,000 people had died from cholera.

After the flood and the subsequent cholera epidemic, all the important streams of the city were gradually covered and transformed into channelized waterways (see also History of the Vienna sewer system). This and the next major Danube flood in 1862 ultimately also provided the impetus for the regulation of the Danube in Vienna.

The Danube flood of February 1862 was an exceptionally strong flood of the Danube. It caused particularly great destruction in Vienna and Passau.

The flooding caused by persistent thawing weather inundated areas on both sides of the Danube in Vienna at the beginning of February, especially Leopoldstadt, Brigittenau, Zwischenbrücken, Rossau, Floridsdorf, Mühlschüttel, Stadlau, the area around the Great Danube Bridge, and Langenzersdorf. In Passau, the flood reached its peak on February 2 with a level of 11.6 m.
This and the previous major Danube flood in 1830 ultimately gave rise to the Vienna Danube Regulation in Vienna.

The flood in Skopje in 1962 occurred on November 16, 1962. Skopje, Ohrid, Struga, Titov Veles, Resen, Kicevo, Bitola, Novaci, Prilep, Tetovo, Krushevo, Bogomila, and a large number of villages and settlements in Western Macedonia were affected by the water disaster that day, which was the result of exceptionally heavy rains. The waters of the Sharplanina basin from Bistra and other mountains that gravitate towards Treska, foamy and muddy, poured into the bed of the muddy Vardar River. Four human casualties were reported.

Seven hundred and thirty cubic meters were flowing from the main discharge tunnel of the Matka hydroelectric power plant, while over 70 cubic meters of water per second were flooding the walls of the dam. The water continued to rise, and in just 15 minutes, a rise of 4 centimeters was recorded. The machine hall of the plant was flooded, the turbo generators were turned off, and the entire Matka lake was full of logs. The lake began to overflow exactly at 11:55, meaning it passed over the dam at that time. At 13:00, it overflowed into the machine room, carrying away the concrete and stone support in front of the plant as if it were a straw, the embankment melted away.

On November 16, 1962, throughout the entire day and the previous night, heavy rainfall occurred in the Skopje area, causing significant flooding in Skopje, Petrovac, and Gjorce Petrov. Four people drowned in Skopje, reported by 6 PM. The areas most affected in Skopje were the Municipality of Idadija, near the City Park, around "Ilindenska" Street, near the main post office, and the city square. Houses along "Cvetan Dimov" Street were endangered due to the overflow of the Serava River. Around 4 PM, all schools were dismissed. Those students who lived nearby were met by their parents at the school gate, but there were children who lived far away and could not go home due to the water. Work on the new concrete bridge was halted due to the heavy rains. However, the workers did not leave their posts and, together with experts, since three o'clock in the morning, they were removing large logs carried by the dangerous rapids of the Vardar River with long iron rods. This bridge was supposed to be put into use on November 29, 1962. The hydrometeorological service had installed a water gauge at this bridge. At 2:30 PM, a water level was recorded here that was eight centimeters higher compared to November 5, 1937, when the water level was 260 cm above normal, or 330 cm. The wooden pedestrian bridges were particularly endangered: near the National Theater and the bridge located between the new concrete bridge and the railway bridge. Due to their instability under the pressure of the rising waters, pedestrian traffic was prohibited on them on the morning of November 16. The railway bridge near the Military Hospital was closed to all trains, while movement on the railway bridge at Gjorce Petrov was allowed at five kilometers per hour. Only one bridge on the Vardar was safe — the Stone Bridge. The local headquarters for natural disasters immediately took measures to accommodate endangered families from the Idadija and Kisela Voda areas in the eight-year school "Kocho Racin," and endangered families from the Municipality of Kale and the Municipality of Saat Kula in the Health Center of these municipalities. In these two points in the city, all lost children were also accommodated. The Vardar overflowed on "Ilindenska," in "Marshal Tito" square, in the City Park, near the stadium, and everywhere the protective embankments were lowest. Many basements were flooded, and occasionally parts of the city were left without electricity. The water flooded the narrow and deep spaces of the "St. Andrew" monastery, and everything in the restaurant by Lake Matka was underwater. The villages around Gjorce Petrov were also affected. The dam of the new accumulation basin near the village of Bojane was breached. Due to the high water level of Treska, the lake at HEC "Matka" was overflowing, and therefore, the water was gradually released to prevent danger to the dam itself. In Saraj, the areas for camping houses were flooded.

In Ohrid, 400 houses were found underwater, Kičevo was cut off from traffic connections, and in Pelagonia, many areas were flooded, causing significant material damage in all flooded regions. Several thousand citizens were evacuated in Ohrid, and over 500 houses were flooded. All villages in Resen were underwater. Parts of Titov Veles and Kičevo were seriously threatened. Bogomila was cut off from other towns. The situation was similar in Debar. Tetovo was left without PTT connections. Kruševo was completely isolated from the world. For two days and two nights, the people of Struga fought against the massive water disaster of the lake. Around Lake Ohrid: scattered boats, filled with mud and various household items. In Struga, the lake overflowed and flooded the entire tourist settlement. The Sateska River flooded a large part of the Struga Field. The Jablanica River overflowed and flooded and destroyed the road in several places. Due to the prolonged heavy rains, the Vidobiska and Koselska Rivers overflowed to widths of 3 and 2 kilometers, respectively, along their entire course. These two rivers also flooded part of Ohrid. In addition to these two rivers, the Daljan River overflowed, reaching a width of about 2 kilometers. Due to the rising waters in Ohrid, about ten houses collapsed. Since the water rose more than one meter, access to the flooded houses was only possible by boat. About 350 families were evacuated and accommodated in the eight-year school "Brotherhood - Unity," in the hotel of Jugohrom and the hotel of PTT. The water disaster caused several houses to collapse in Resen, Carev Dvor, Drmeni, Upper and Lower Bela Crkva, and others. All citizens aged 15 to 55 were mobilized. The village of Ezerene, south of Resen, was cut off from other settlements. Bitola and Pelagonia were underwater. After the heavy rains, the Crna River rose, followed by Šemnica, Dragor in Bitola, and Kurderes, as well as all their tributaries and village streams. In the morning, Dragor overflowed its banks near the slaughterhouse, and at the same moment, Kurderes did too, causing the waters to merge and flood a vast area right next to Bitola, in front of the railway line. Near the village of Novaci, the Crna River flooded 3,000 hectares of arable land. The waters of the Crna River also destroyed both large bridges near the village of Brod. The fish farm Vukri was also damaged. Near Titov Veles, the Vardar and Topolka rivers rose 4.5 meters above normal. The entire street "Vasil Levski," on the left side of the Vardar, was flooded. The building of the "Trajko Andrejev" and "Blagoj Kirkov" schools were underwater up to the first floor. At the city market, the water reached a height of one meter. Five families were evacuated on the first day after the flood. Two bridges on Topolka were swept away. 6,000 chickens and chicks from the "Stochar" company were destroyed. Babuna overflowed its banks. Bogomila was completely isolated from the railway station because it was impossible to cross the bridge over Babuna. The water disaster uprooted trees along the riverbank and flooded the football field. In Bogomila and Tetovo, several houses were flooded, and according to initial estimates, about 70 hectares of planted areas were affected. Tetovo district: road and PTT traffic were interrupted. The swollen Pena, which rose more than one meter, collapsed the riverbanks at several points and flooded the streets: "Leninova," "Mirče Acev," and "Jeni Malo." The cellars of some institutions, as well as the Veterinary Station, were flooded. In Prilep: the Oreovec River overflowed and swept away two wooden bridges in the Tabana area. In this area, a private house was also threatened due to landslides on the left riverbank. The river carried away trees and several heads of livestock. Large areas of the Prilep Field were found underwater.

In Skopje, 1,050 houses were destroyed, 157 buildings were underwater, and 4,445 citizens were left homeless; in Petrovec, nearly 4,000 hectares of fertile land were flooded. The water disaster destroyed three bridges in Skopje and three in Gjorce Petrov. In Ohrid, 36 houses were destroyed by the flood, 57 were damaged, and access to 56 houses was impossible because they were filled with mud and water two days after the flood. A general mobilization of the population, members of the JNA, and the People's Militia was carried out in many cities, and all possible means of transportation were engaged. The trading house "Skopje" reported the first material damage of 300 million dinars. It was estimated that the total damage from the flood exceeded 10 billion dinars. The sewage and water supply networks were severely damaged, the pumping station at Rasce and the one at Kozle were destroyed. The Saraj was completely destroyed, and access to it was impossible. Underground waters appeared, breaking out even at distant places from the Vardar, such as near the railway station. The building of the National Theater in Skopje was damaged, especially the electrical installations, the mechanism for rotating the stage, and the wings. On the very first day after the flood, teams of soldiers and firefighters were sent from Nis, Leskovac, Surdulica, Urosevac, Kosovska Mitrovica, Belgrade, Prizren, and others. From Negotino to Demir Kapija, the Vardar was on average 400 meters wide. Near Gevgelija, a lake was 8 kilometers wide. In Gevgelija, 5 bridges were destroyed. Two kilometers from Gevgelija, trains were "floating" 200 meters through water. In Tetovo, 3,000 hectares were flooded, and 8 bridges were swept away. The archival material of the film production company "Vardar - film" was completely destroyed. The negatives of all feature-length and documentary films shot from 1945 until the day of the flood were completely destroyed. In the Skopje Zoo, only about 20 percent of the animals perished, while the rest were saved, including: lions, monkeys, an elephant, a hippopotamus, a tiger, and a reticulated python. In the efforts of the Yugoslav People's Army, the entire population and the People's Militia were joined by youth, who greatly contributed to providing assistance to those affected by natural disasters in all parts of Macedonia. Youth working brigades and groups made themselves available to the headquarters for combating natural disasters. Youth and student working groups participated in clearing the affected houses and rescuing endangered families. They organized the protection and cleaning of schools, dormitories, and other facilities. On November 19, 1962, 3,830 youths worked on clearing the streets in Skopje, while on November 20, 1962, around 5,000 youths were involved in the affected areas in Skopje and its surroundings. At the initiative of the Main and District Board of the Red Cross and the Headquarters for Combating Natural Disasters from the municipality of Idadija, a group of youth leaders and activists organized the transfer and care of children from the most affected families in the Idadija municipality area to the Red Cross center in Vodno. In this reception center, 72 children aged 7 to 14 were transferred. Such engagement of the youth was noted in other parts of Macedonia: Bitola, Titov Veles, Ohrid, Gevgelija, and other affected areas. Youth organizations also assisted in the actions of sanitary authorities for vaccinating the population to prevent the possible spread of infectious diseases.

The Fronleichnam flood refers to a weather disaster that occurred on June 21, 1984 (Fronleichnam day) in the Main-Tauber district in Baden-Württemberg, primarily affecting the areas of the municipalities of Königheim, Tauberbischofsheim, Boxberg, and Lauda-Königshofen, leading to torrential flooding. The town of Königheim was particularly heavily flooded. Dittwar, Kupprichhausen, and Lengenrieden were also severely affected. The total damage amounted to around 90 million Deutsche Mark.

f1 Map with all coordinates of the mainly affected watercourses, places, and retention basins of the Corpus Christi flood: OSM | WikiMap The trigger of the flood was a heavy rain on June 21, 1984, of up to 150 mm, which fell over the catchment areas of Brehm (⊙49.5580979.520383, ⊙49.6192979.668103) and Schüpfbach (⊙49.553749.571589, ⊙49.515249.693058). The rain started in the afternoon and completely flooded the partly narrow stream valleys with flood waves of up to three meters high downstream. Severe storms occurred in the area of Kupprichhausen (⊙49.5269059.62103), Lengenrieden (⊙49.5279999.64004), Oberlauda (⊙49.56669.6787), Heckfeld (⊙49.551299.63651), Dittwar (⊙49.5902789.636111), Brehmen (⊙49.5694139.554947), Gissigheim (⊙49.5942789.58725), Königheim (⊙49.6177789.595556), and Tauberbischofsheim (⊙49.62259.662778). The center of the heavy rain was in the area of Hof Esselbrunn (⊙49.5730479.590232) and Reisberg (⊙49.5759.6045). The water masses flowed through the Eisgrundgraben (⊙49.5647749.61033, ⊙49.5907679.631603) and Ölbach towards Dittwar (13.5 cubic meters/second) and over the Adelsgraben above Gissigheim as well as the Brehmbach towards Königheim (10 to 19 cubic meters/second) and streamed towards the underlying villages and towns. In Kupprichhausen and Lengenrieden, a two-meter-high flood wave rushed through the Schüpfbach valley at about the same time over a width of 100 meters. The flood reached its peak around 5 PM with a flow rate of about 100 to 120 m³/s. Subsequently, at 5:18 PM, the disaster alarm for the Main-Tauber-Kreis was triggered by District Administrator Georg Denzer. As a result, police teams and a SAR helicopter from the Federal Air Force were ordered to the disaster area. In addition, emergency services from the DLRG, fire brigades, and the Technical Relief Organization were deployed to the area. Shortly thereafter, and only about half an hour after the rain stopped, the situation worsened again: the dam of the Gissigheim retention basin (⊙49.5788069.567639) broke around 5:20 PM after being overflowed with extremely high discharges. Prior to this, the bottom outlet had been blocked, and the flood relief system could no longer discharge the water masses after debris had severely impaired its performance at the grid cover of the relief system. As a result, the dam was overflowed up to 65 cm high before the break, with a maximum estimated outflow of 54 m³/s. The second flood wave triggered by the dam break damaged a large part of the houses in Königheim up to the second floor. The dam, like most dams of that time, was not built to withstand overflow without damage, and its air side was therefore not erosion-resistant. However, the actual reason for the dam break was not the receding erosion, but the integration of the relief system into the dam body, where a interlocking of the overflow structure was missing and cavities were present due to the receding components. The maximum water level in the reservoir was 10.7 m, with a storage volume of 0.144 million m³. At the beginning of the dam break, 0.165 million m³ were stored. Due to the retention effect of the widening Brehmbach valley, the second flood wave in Königheim could no longer be recognized as a single wave in the general flood. The maximum water level in Königheim persisted due to the retention effect until about 6 PM. Despite the dam break, the retention basin prevented even greater damage in Königheim, as it delayed the flood wave of the Brehmbach, allowing the flood waves from the catchment areas below the basin to run ahead and preventing the waves from overlapping. It was not until around 7 PM that the flood in Königheim had largely receded. The railway embankment at the Dittwar train station, lying across the flow direction of the Muckbach from Dittwar (⊙49.603579.6438) of the then railway line Tauberbischofsheim–Königheim prevented even greater disaster for Tauberbischofsheim. The Umpfertal, Königshofen, Sachsenflur, Schweigern, and Boxberg also got off relatively lightly due to the high railway embankments. These caused a backwater, which, however, became a disaster for other municipalities. In the aftermath, police, fire brigades, the Bundeswehr, Technical Relief Organization, DLRG, and DRK were continuously deployed. Several missing person reports were not confirmed, and there were no fatalities, but nine injuries. However, over 1200 animals died, half of them large livestock. 24 buildings were completely destroyed, and 184 were severely damaged. Large areas of the stream and river floodplains were underwater, and numerous buildings were threatened with collapse. The electricity and telecommunications networks, as well as the water supply, failed in large parts of the disaster area. In addition to federal road 27, several state and county roads were no longer passable. Over 100 vehicles were swept away by the water masses, completely demolished, or piled on top of each other. Even in the evening, the disaster response team called for drinking water to be boiled throughout the disaster area. In an initial estimate, the emergency management of the district office assumed about 7000 affected individuals who were directly impacted by the flood disaster, meaning they suffered significant damage to their property.

After the heavy rains subsided the evening before, they finally stopped on the night of June 22, 1984. By morning, a large part of the water had drained away, and the levels at the Tauber were falling again. At 6:45 AM, technical response teams were formed in the four mainly affected municipalities (Königheim, Tauberbischofsheim, Boxberg, and Lauda-Königshofen). About 1,000 emergency personnel began the first cleanup efforts. District Administrator Georg Denzer stated in a press conference in the afternoon: "At the moment, it is not my task to assess the damage caused. The priority was and is to contain the disaster and avert danger to people and animals. Now it’s time to clean up and rebuild. And for that, we need help." The initial priority was the evacuation of people from buildings at risk of collapse. In addition, efforts were made to restore power supply, telecommunications networks, and road connections. In areas with destroyed water supply, the population was supplied with water by tank trucks. Since the suction baskets of the fire pumps were repeatedly clogged, divers had to be deployed in Tauberbischofsheim in some cases. The Baden-Württemberg Interior Minister Dietmar Schlee visited the site on June 22 to get a personal impression of the emergency situation and promised quick assistance from the state.

The Minister-President of Baden-Württemberg, Lothar Späth, visited Dittwar on June 23, 1984, one of the hardest-hit areas in the disaster zone. Meanwhile, the cleanup and securing efforts were progressing: with the exception of L 511 between Heckfeld and Oberlauda, all roads were at least passable again. The power and drinking water supply had been secured by emergency generators (including from Badenwerk) and water treatment plants. The structural securing of buildings and bridges, as well as the removal of about 1,200 animal carcasses, were the urgent tasks at hand. The floods had scattered the animal carcasses throughout the damage area, which was still partially flooded, or buried them under debris, making the cleanup efforts difficult. In addition, basements were cleared of mud, wood was removed, and apartments were cleaned. Another focus was on the removal of oil slicks after some oil tanks had toppled and leaked in flooded basements. The onset of disaster tourism on that Saturday was extremely disruptive for all involved. According to statements from emergency personnel, onlookers showed no regard for the people affected by the disaster and increasingly hindered the recovery efforts, necessitating cordons to be set up in an ever-widening radius.

The cleanup operations continued unabated on June 24, 1984, throughout the affected area. It became apparent that far more buildings were at acute risk of collapse than initially assumed. About 1,150 emergency personnel therefore supported or demolished buildings, primarily. Another focus was the removal of debris to ensure that water could drain away in the event of possible renewed rainfall. However, part of the emergency personnel had to be withdrawn from the main damage area after the collapse of the railway bridge over the Main between Wertheim and Kreuzwertheim was reported at 1:00 PM. According to eyewitnesses, the disturbances caused by onlookers gradually took on extreme forms, significantly hindering the operation of vehicles.

In Dittwar and Königheim, the public water supply was restored on June 25, 1984. However, to maintain the power supply, emergency generators had to continue to be used in Königheim. While the cleanup and securing work in Königheim continued unabated in the inner areas, the tasks in other damaged areas increasingly shifted to areas outside the villages. Approximately 820 emergency personnel were still engaged. For example, the streams and bridge passages were mostly cleaned by hand of coarse debris, as hardly any trucks or excavators could be used on the still soaked and muddy grounds.

The cleanup efforts continued, especially in the damage centers, with a large number of volunteers. After the masses of mud from the flooded houses had largely been removed, severe damage that had not been immediately visible became apparent, necessitating further safety measures. As the feed supplies for the surviving livestock in the affected area were running low and many access roads were still impassable, it became increasingly necessary to procure feed from other areas.

On June 27, 1984, about 720 helpers were still deployed, primarily focusing on the time-consuming clearing of stream bridges and water crossings. Heavy equipment was mostly not yet usable on the softened ground. Further buildings at risk of collapse were secured where possible, and some were also demolished. Areas that had already been completed became relevant again after numerous basements that had been pumped dry were refilled with infiltrating pressurized water. In the meantime, the farmers' association ensured the supply of agricultural businesses with feed and other necessary goods. Water tests by the State Chemical Testing Institute revealed that all water sources in the damage area were contaminated with coliform bacteria. The boil water advisory for drinking water therefore remained in effect until a threat to the population could be ruled out through daily sampling. Heavy clearing equipment was only needed to a limited extent, and the deployed federal units could be released from the disaster response. Although the operation was not yet finished on June 27, the number of aid workers could be gradually reduced a week after the flood. The Fronleichnam flood triggered the first and so far only disaster alarm in the Main-Tauber district.

After the Corpus Christi flood, the significantly affected areas were busy with reconstruction until the end of the 1980s. After this flood, effective flood protection measures for the future were repeatedly discussed. In the Brehmbachtal, where the retention basin in Gissigheim broke during the Corpus Christi flood on June 21, 1984, it took until 2019/20 for a new protective structure, the flood retention basin in Königheim, to be built in the Brehmbachtal before Königheim.

With the triggering of the disaster alarm, a so-called disaster response team was formed at the district office of the Main-Tauber district. According to a plan already prepared for such cases, employees of the district office took their place in this command staff throughout the duration of the operation, which coordinated the deployment of technical assistance forces. In addition, four technical response teams were established in the main damage areas, which led the units deployed there. The connection between all these locations was ensured by the telecommunications center set up at the district office. Whole_Text.header: Ruin of the Goglio on November 1, 1666
Whole_Text.content: The ruin of Goglio was a catastrophic event that occurred on November 1, 1666, affecting the towns of Valgoglio in the Novazza district and Gromo in the upper Val Seriana in the province of Bergamo, causing around seventy casualties, many homeless, and the destruction of many factories with serious social and economic consequences.

The Goglio is a mountain stream that originates from the lakes of the Orobie Alps above Lake Aviasco, flowing into the Serio in the valley bottom, in the Pranzera area of Gromo after a 5 km journey overcoming a height difference of about 1550 m. Since the 13th century, on the right side of the stream, from the hamlet of Colarete to the Pranzera area, its waters were used through sluices, serving factories that forged bladed weapons; this area was called the Goglio district. The extraction of iron and other minerals is documented as early as Pliny the Elder (23-79 AD), referring to the Christians condemned by the Romans to mine metals in the mines of the upper Val Seriana as Damnatio ad metalla in his Naturalis historia. The upper valley - along with other neighboring areas - was donated by Charlemagne in 774 to the monasteries of San Martino di Tours and Saint-Denis. Taken back by the church of Bergamo in 1026, it became the subject of disputes and clashes centered on mining rights between the bishopric and local noble families, who owned the lands with iron and silver mines. Among these were the Colleoni and the Rivola. In 1267, the town obtained the privilege of being called a borough, with the right to work the minerals enjoying the income derived from extraction and processing. The processing of iron in the upper valley became very important and more productive with the Venetian domination of 1427; it included not only the territory of Gromo, which was considered the small Toledo, but also the related industries of neighboring towns. The altarpiece of the Church of San Gregorio titled Madonna with Child between Saints Gregory the Great and Charles Borromeo, painted in 1624 by Enea Salmeggia, and the private property map drawn by the notary Bartolomeo Scacchi illustrate how the town appeared at that time and where the forges, houses, and other activities were located.

"[...] there existed along the Golio stream a district of Gromo, a noble land of that valley, of perhaps twenty families. They were celebrating All Saints' Day when a part of the overhanging mountain broke away, crashing down with such force that from the whirlwind that preceded it, boulders of immense size were hurled into the air with a terrifying noise [...] It destroyed to the foundations eighteen houses, a church, an oratory; two bridges, thirty buildings, twenty-seven of which were used for the manufacture of weapons, and crushed sixty-three people." (Pietro Antonio Brasi Historical Memoir about the Upper Seriana Valley, 1823)

The disastrous event occurred on November 1, 1666, All Saints' Day, at noon. Several events coincided that, although having different causes, developed in a concatenated manner. Written testimonies recount continuous days of heavy rain that had swollen the stream, a fact certainly not rare, given that its waters were not regulated by dams or artificial basins. The testimonies collected from the shepherds who were resting in the locality on the opposite side of the valley and who faced the event describe a strong wind that lifted people and boulders; subsequently, a loud roar was heard, caused by the collapse of a part of the mountain called Cima Bani, a collapse likely caused by the rains and the severe deforestation that had occurred over the centuries to meet the great need for wood charcoal forges, which had made the ground unstable; descending into the valley, the landslide carried with it trees and stones, brushing against the Novazza fraction of Valgoglio, until it reached the Colarete fraction where it settled above the Goglio stream, blocking it and forming a lake, which, swollen with water, earth, and debris, overflowed, carrying with it materials and everything found along its path, as well as the forges, with the furnaces, hammers, warehouses, houses, and even two small churches. The book by Gabriele Medolago states on page 26: the church was completely destroyed... with some goods located in the same area and there was no hope of being able to rebuild churches or anything else due to the instability of the river. Upon reaching the valley floor, this landslide blocked the Serio, which, swollen by the materials and incessant rains, overflowed, taking with it men and houses, beyond the border of the country. All this was accomplished in the time of an Our Father.

"[...] there was a remote district from the land of Gromo, the shot of two musket shots located above the river Golio [...] for the convenience of said river, twenty-seven buildings were constructed, all in order of arms manufacturing [...] when on the days of saints [...] a part of the mountain with hayfields, woods, and lands overlaid on said district at a distance of about a thousand paces detached" (notary Bartolomeo Scacchi, Municipality of Gromo) thus begins the report of notary Bartolomeo Scacchi; while that of the Captain reporting to Venice recounts "Most Serene Prince, it is worthy of the supreme news of Your Serenity the strange and frightening incident that followed the Land of Goglio in the Seriana Valley [...] the land lay above a peaceful stream named Golio, distant from there (Bergamo) about thirty miles [...] which continuously served various buildings and forges, for the work of blades, swords, as well as many ironworks [...] the day before yesterday, on All Saints' Day, around noon, a mountain collapsed" (Captain Giovanni Francesco Dandolo, November 3, 1666, State Archive of Venice) The geography of the country, divided into three distinct nuclei, located on the west side of the Serio river, and the event occurring on a holiday saved a good part of the villagers: indeed, the documented victims number between 63 and 67. The district of Goglio was located in the southernmost part of the country; there were 27 forges here; the houses of the workers; two small churches, that of San Rocco, the small oratory called Santa Croce, and two bridges that allowed access to the area north of the valley. In the upper part was the village, situated on a hill, with the castle and the palace inhabited by noble families, and further north in the valley, the parish church, which, given the noon hour, fortunately welcomed the faithful for the All Saints' Day services. The testimonies of the event have been documented since the first days. On November 3, a dispatch was sent to Venice by Captain Francesco Dandolo and Gerolamo Giustiniano, the podestà, with a detailed account of the events, damages, and victims; this document is preserved in the State Archive of Venice. On November 6, the archpriest of Clusone, Alessandro Ghirardelli, came for an inspection and, despite leaving a somewhat exaggerated testimony, describes not only the material damages but also the emotional situation of the villagers; as does the document of notary Gregorio Scacchi, now preserved in the archives of the parish of Gromo. The flooding of the Serio brought down not only debris but also the bodies of the victims, which are documented in the parish registers. The remains of the dead extracted from the waters of the river are documented in the archives of Parre, Alzano Lombardo, up to Seriate. The event was also reported by the historian Giovanni Maironi da Ponte."

The consequences were severe because, both in the municipality of Gromo and Valgoglio, the ruin had destroyed the main activity. The 27 forges, which could produce up to 1000 sword blades a day and employed the families of the community, were completely destroyed. The demographic decline within the first month was 30%; the flood had forced the labor force to migrate to other locations, suddenly finding themselves without work and unable to wait for the reconstruction, which could not be immediate; even the dead were not immediately extracted from the rubble, but are documented in the church records from December 1666 to all of 1667. In Venice, procedures were initiated for tax relief, which were initially granted for five years, and then renewed from time to time. The damages were estimated at 60,000 scudi, which justified the exemptions from the payment of taxes and rents, practiced from 1666 until the mid-18th century. In 1733, a list was drawn up of families entitled to compensation from the Venetian republic. The recovery and reconstruction were very slow; in fact, it took fifty years before the destroyed part of the settlement was reused; other forges were built, but the activity that had made the town of Gromo famous no longer yielded the same profits: times had changed, the demands were different; however, subsequent production is documented, not only of white weapons but also of arquebuses.

"In a ducal decree from the exalted Senate of Venice dated March 19, 1667, which grants the community of Gromo an exemption from all real and personal burdens for ten years […] due to the misfortune that occurred in the same municipality in the Goglio area, where sixty-three people lost their lives under the ruins of a piece of mountain that collapsed, and as a result, not only the homes of the entire aforementioned area were destroyed, but also the lands along with the ruins of thirty-two buildings that were their sustenance […]" (Maironi da Ponte – Odeporic Dictionary or Historical Political Natural)

Article_Name: Riuada de 1982 al Berguedà - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The flood of 1982 in Berguedà is the set of catastrophic effects caused by the historic rise of the Llobregat River and its tributaries in the Berguedà region during the days of November 7 and 8, 1982, due to intense rainfall that affected the Pyrenean and pre-Pyrenean area. In Berguedà, it had serious consequences for the economy, as in addition to destroying communication infrastructure and private property, it severely affected the textile industry and mining, the two economic pillars of the region at that time. The existence of the Baells dam prevented the damage from being even more severe in the Llobregat valley. Fortunately, there were no human losses, as there were in the Alt Urgell and Andorra due to these floods.

Since November 6, due to the phenomenon known as cold drop or DANA, exceptionally intense rains occurred in the Catalan Pyrenees that lasted 48 hours. At that time, there was no rain gauge in Berguedà that measured the intensity of rain per hour, but the total rainfall in 48 hours in the upper Berguedà was around 400 mm on average, meaning it is estimated that in two days it rained the amount corresponding to half a year. As a consequence, the flows of the rivers and streams in the Llobregat basin increased extraordinarily.

At 4 PM on November 7, a Sunday, the Baells reservoir, which was at an elevation of 621, was receiving between 400 and 500 m³/s. Considering that the safety level is at 625, and that the bottom and mid-level sluices can release up to 160 m³/s, it was already anticipated that the overflow sluices would need to be opened. Between 4 and 5 PM, the nearest towns were alerted: Civil Guard, Red Cross, Civil Protection, Water Confederation, and Berga Firefighters. The municipalities were not notified, as it was considered that no one would be found there at that hour. In the towns of lower Berguedà located by the Llobregat River, such as Gironella, concern began to grow over the rising river. Although it had rained in the lower part of the region, such a large increase in flow was not explained, as the magnitude of the rains in upper Berguedà was unknown. The intensity of the rains was greater the higher one went. At 8 PM, the water had already reached the level of the river street in Gironella, and the local Red Cross and volunteer firefighters began to work, monitoring the river's course. At 10:30 PM, the peak time for water entering the La Baells reservoir at 1,200 m³/s, a call was made from the reservoir to the Gironella Nursing Home, informing them that they had begun to evacuate the residents. Considering the time it could take for the water to arrive, the sluices were opened. They released 800 m³/s, while the usual flow is 7 m³/s. The reservoir level reached up to 631.48, one and a half meters above the maximum capacity (630). It was a delicate moment, as it was the first time the reservoir had reached this point and it was unknown how the dam would respond.

The flood caused a shock to the economy of Berguedà, with very significant losses in the region's businesses, on one hand due to the destruction of machinery and facilities, and on the other hand due to the halt in production. The quantification of the losses caused by the heavy rain and the flood to economic activities indicates that 49% corresponds to mining, 41% to industry, 8% to agriculture, and 2% to commerce. In terms of municipalities, those with the highest losses are, in order: Cercs (1.5 billion pesetas), Puig-reig (737 million), Gironella (180 million), Casserres (144 million), Guardiola (77 million), Berga (76 million), Fígols (62 million), La Pobla (52 million). On the other hand, regarding private property, the most affected were the towns with buildings along the river. The force of the water, when the water level reached the height of the buildings, demolished several homes, some completely and others partially. The affected municipalities were: Guardiola, Gironella, and La Pobla de Lillet. Additionally, these same towns, along with Puig-reig, Cercs, and Bagà, suffered damage to facilities, communications, and municipal public works such as bridges, paths, roads, retaining walls, etc. Overall, the damage to roads, bridges, and communications of local and regional roads exceeded 100 million pesetas.

Due to their nature, all of the numerous textile colonies in the region were intensely affected, as they are factories built near a river to take advantage of hydraulic energy to operate the machines. The hydroelectric facilities that generate the energy (or most of the energy) needed by the factory were not spared from the devastating effects of the flood, as the turbine, along with the canal and the dam, are located at the lowest level, at river level. The rise in the river level covered all the machinery and facilities, which meant that, in addition to repairing or replacing it, they were left without energy production. The affected companies in the turbines in Berguedà were: Filatura Berguedana (La Pobla de Lillet), Colònia Rosal, Cal Metre (Gironella), Filats i Teixits Fusté (Cal Bassacs), Viladomiu Nou, Viladomiu Vell, Ferrer (Vilada), Colònia Guixaró (Casserres), Colònia Prat (Puig-reig), Colònia Pons (Puig-reig), Colònia Marçal (Puig-reig), Colonia Manent (Puig-reig) and l'Ametlla de Merola. Secondly, to a greater or lesser extent, water entered the factories and damaged the machinery and materials (whether raw or processed). One of the most affected was the factory l'Ametlla de Merola, where the damages were estimated at 500 million pesetas and a suspension of contract was filed for the entire workforce, 350 workers.

The most important group of mining operations in Berguedà was the Fígols mines, which were mainly accessed through the mouth of La Consolació (Cercs). This operation, which consists of a network of shafts and galleries, all interconnected, with a height difference of 2,000 m, is located inside a mountainous massif, outside of which several streams and brooks flow. The different openings of the operation acted like a sponge through which water filtered, gradually flooding all the galleries and accumulating in the deepest part of the operation, where it reached a height of 75 m. All the machinery and equipment present became unusable. As a result, the company submitted a temporary suspension of contracts that affected 300 workers (although it was initially planned for 776 workers).

Whole_Text.header: Gironella, a village by the river
Whole_Text.content: The alert to the town of Gironella began at 8 PM on Sunday, November 7, when the water of the Llobregat reached the level of the street of the River. The Red Cross burst into the Cinema Victòria to warn if there were neighbors who had houses on the riverbank. The volunteer firefighters were watching over the Hospital building, the nursing home. Between nine and half past nine, a crowd of people had already gathered near the bridge of the Eres and the Old Bridge, where it was expected that the flood would have repercussions. At that same hour, a house on the river street, the Ferrer family (ca la Maruja), had already been evacuated, as the water was reaching above the door. Simultaneously, water began to enter the basement of the Sant Roc Hospital-Residence; however, the lack of communication about what was happening upstream and the lack of foresight meant that the evacuation of the elderly did not begin until much later. Access to the Old Bridge and the bridge of the Eres was cut off due to the danger of collapse, which eventually happened, isolating the Cal Ramons neighborhood and the Eres neighborhood from the urban center. The old town could only be accessed through the wall. The houses on the left side of Avinguda Catalunya were evacuated, from the bridge of the Eres to the Abattoir. The river street was also evacuated, where it was no longer possible to transit and water was already entering basements and ground-floor apartments. In this street, water entered all the basements and several homes were completely destroyed. As for the Sant Roc Residence, since the water reached the main door, all the elderly residents were evacuated through the ambulance garage and the passage leading to Avinguda Catalunya, and were initially moved to the Pearl Pub, the Cinema Victòria, and the basement of the Parochial House. The operation lasted until 3 AM. The Apolo building on Avinguda Catalunya was also evacuated, as the water was attacking its foundations. Power, drinking water, and telephone supply cuts lasted well into the next day, Monday. The Town Hall offered an apartment and financial assistance to families who had been left homeless.

Whole_Text.header: L'Ametlla de Merola, an example of recovery
Whole_Text.content: The textile factory of Ametlla de Merola was the most affected by the flood in Berguedà. The water reached a level of 1.5 m inside the factory, and 1.60 m in the weaving room. When the water level receded, the first to enter the building found that the machinery was rendered unusable—some machines were in irreparable condition—walls had collapsed, everything was covered in mud, and the thread was scattered. The Bonser warehouse, which was full of manufactured goods, was left empty. The initiative to try to return to activity began immediately. The company applied for unemployment for the workers. At the same time, the population, which largely depended on work at the factory, collaborated in the recovery efforts. The predominant feeling was to act quickly to return to normalcy. The first job that kept most of the population occupied was removing mud, using rakes and dumpers. Meanwhile, women and retirees also helped by cleaning small items. Efforts were made to save the electrical parts of the looms, and on the other hand, the mud was removed from the looms with the pump that was lent to them by the farmers of the municipality of Sagàs, which were later cleaned with kerosene and sprayed with antioxidants. The Vocational Training School of Navàs also provided personnel and tools to assist in the recovery efforts. In short, it was a model of cooperation to save not only a company, on which jobs depended, but to return to normalcy for a community, with the associated social and cultural aspects.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Benevento on October 15, 2015, occurred due to heavy rains that affected the basin of all the waterways in the province of Benevento. The waterways that caused the most disruption were the Calore, the Sabato, and the Tammaro. The most affected areas were Ponte, San Giorgio la Molara, Solopaca, Paupisi, Benevento, Montesarchio, Airola, and Pietrelcina.

The main causes are the abundant rains that have fallen on the ground, which has reached saturation, with the inability to absorb more water and the alleged opening of the Campolattaro dam on the Tammaro River, the watercourse that has caused the most disruption to the populations of Benevento. The river has reached unprecedented flood levels, and with the exceptional flood of the Calore, it has brought the capital and several neighboring municipalities to their knees.

The damage was multiple, starting from the agricultural sector, literally devastated by this event, then serious damage was suffered by livestock and the industrial sector. There were two victims. One, caused by the flooding of the Tammaro, was a seventy-year-old woman from Pago Veiano, swept away by the waters. The second victim, caused by the flooding of the Calore, was a man from Varoni di Montesarchio, who was swept away while trying to clear the basement of mud.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Piedmont in 2016 is one of the most violent floods recorded in Piedmont, classified in some areas up to level 3 by the alert bulletin issued by the Civil Protection Department. The event affected the regional territory between November 21 and 25, 2016, when a depression system extended from the British Isles to the northern African coasts channeled intense humid south-eastern currents close to the Alpine chain. This meteorological configuration was characterized by persistent and abundant rainfall, especially near the western and northern Alpine ranges and in areas bordering Liguria. The dynamics and meteorological configuration were similar to the flood that affected Piedmont in 2000. The flood in November 2016 caused significant damage across much of the regional territory, due to numerous landslides, mudslides, and flooding with frequent overflows of streams. During the event, there was one victim in Perosa Argentina, in the Pinerolo area, found only after several days by the firefighters, about ten kilometers from where they went missing, in the Chisone stream.

Analyzing the evolution in detail, the saturation effect of humid air masses induced by orographic lifting concentrated the phenomenon mainly along the Alpine ridges. Indeed, heavy snowfall was recorded above the medium-high altitudes, accumulating over 1 meter of fresh snow in Sestriere. Below are some rainfall totals recorded at the end of the worsening from some hydro-meteorological stations of ARPA Piemonte (Regional Agency for Environmental Protection) present in the area. In Niquidetto, 613.2 mm was recorded; 584.8 mm in Viù; 324 mm in Pinerolo in the Turin area; 586.6 mm in Barge; 547.8 mm in Ponte di Nava Tanaro in the Cuneo area; 574.2 mm in Calizzano in the Savona area.

The high amount of snowfall that remained on average above 1700 meters in altitude caused strong and persistent rains even at medium altitudes, resulting in a marked increase in the hydrometric levels of the hydrographic network, often exceeding the danger threshold, and numerous slope phenomena and landslides.

The most concerning aspect was the hydrographic network of the Tanaro, which exceeded the danger threshold multiple times during the event. The highest flood moment was recorded on the morning of November 25 when the hydrometric stations of ARPA measured 4.67 m at Ponte di Nava, 4.88 m at Garessio, 6.14 m at Piantorre, 6.5 m at Farigliano, and 6.14 m at Alba. Further downstream in the hydrographic basin, between Asti and Alessandria, the Tanaro exceeded danger levels on the morning of November 25, peaked in the afternoon (Asti: 7.71 m, Masio 5.79 m), and fell below danger levels between the evening and the following morning. In the Bormida basin, hydrometric levels rose but remained below warning levels until November 24, when they began to rise rapidly, exceeding danger levels and peaking in Alessandria during the day on the 25th, with 5.08 m at Cassine maggiore and 8.3 m at Alessandria. In Alessandria, it fell below danger levels in the early hours of November 26. In the Turin area, hydrometric levels increased significantly starting from November 24. In particular, the Pellice at Villafranca exceeded danger levels in the afternoon of November 24, reaching a peak of 6.12 m and then falling below danger levels on the morning of the 25th. The Chisola at La Loggia exceeded danger levels on the evening of November 24, reaching a peak of 7.41 m on the morning of the 25th, before falling below danger levels on the morning of the 26th. In Turin, near the confluence with the Po, the Dora Riparia remained slightly above danger levels from the early hours of the morning of November 25 until the early afternoon, reaching a peak of 4.29 m. The Stura di Lanzo remained above warning levels from the morning of November 24 to the morning of the 25th, approaching but not reaching the danger level with a peak of 3.09 m in the early hours of November 25. The hydrometric levels of the Po River began to rise significantly on November 24, exceeding danger levels from Moncalieri to Crescentino Po on the evening of November 24, while at Carignano and Casale Monferrato on the morning of the 25th; in Alessandria in the afternoon of the 25th. Peaks were reached at Carignano with 6.71 m, at Moncalieri with 8.72 m, and at Turin with 6.35 m between the afternoon and night of November 25, representing the second highest values after the flood of 1839. Levels fell below danger levels on the morning of November 26 along the entire river stretch, except for the section downstream of Turin between Castiglione and Crescentino, where it had already fallen on the evening of the 25th.

The valleys that have reported the most significant hydro-geological instability are the Val Chisone and Val Germanasca, in the Pinerolese, where some landslides and intense slope phenomena have isolated some inhabited centers and caused considerable damage.

Whole_Text.content: The flash flood that struck western and central Bohemia on May 25 and May 26, 1872, was one of the most devastating reliably documented natural disasters in Czech territory, reaching a thousand-year water level on the Berounka River. A cyclone formed at the frontal boundary in the Blšanka and Střela river basin, causing very intense torrential rainfall on the afternoon of May 25, with a record 237 mm falling in Mladotice in an hour and a half. In Beroun, the flow of the Berounka reached an unprecedented 2500 cubic meters per second, while the Vltava in Prague peaked at a flow of 3300 m³/s. Because the main flood wave arrived at night, there were significant losses of life: officially, 337 dead were counted, with Holedeč (43 people) and Nebřeziny (40 people) being the hardest hit. A large number of domestic animals also perished, thousands of people lost their homes, the dams of five ponds were breached on the Blšanka, a large landslide caused the blockage of the Mladotický stream and created the Odlezelské lake, while the extensive Mladotický pond was breached on the same stream.
