Article_Name: Inundación de la mina Delia II, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Flooding of the Delia II mine
Whole_Text.content: The flooding of the Delia II mine occurred in the early morning of June 9, 2017, at the mine owned by the mining company "Cerro Bayo" and left two miners trapped in the tunnels. A collapse caused the waters of Laguna Verde (Aysén), in the commune of Chile Chico, to flood the mine galleries. At the time of the flooding, which occurred in the early morning, miners Jorge Sánchez Martínez and Enrique Ojeda González were working on level 55. On the surface, outside the mine, it was noticed that the fans, responsible for injecting fresh air into the shaft, had stopped working and an alarm sounded for only 10 seconds. At five in the morning, a supervisor entered the mine and discovered the tragedy: the mine had been flooded. The location of the workers at the time of the accident is unknown, but it is presumed that they headed to a refuge on level 203, which was attempted to be reached in a second drilling attempt, as the first failed. Simultaneously, rescue teams attempted to contain the flooding through dikes. The miners' unions proposed bringing in robots and divers to cross the flooded areas and search for the miners in the galleries. After 18 days of searching, on Tuesday, June 27, 2017, the Cerro Bayo company officially announced the death of the miners.

Article_Name: 平成29年7月九州北部豪雨

Whole_Text.header: Heavy rain in northern Kyushu in July 2017.
Whole_Text.content: The heavy rain in northern Kyushu in July 2017 (Heisei 29, July) occurred from July 5 to 6, 2017, primarily affecting Fukuoka and Oita Prefectures. Although the scale of the damage was below the criteria set by the Japan Meteorological Agency for naming heavy rains (the number of damaged and flooded houses), it was named on July 19 of the same year due to the significant human impact.

The rainy season front that was near the Hokuriku region until July 4th moved south from the Korean Peninsula to western Japan starting July 5th. On the morning of the 5th, a line of rain clouds developed in western Shimane Prefecture, creating a linear precipitation band that resulted in record rainfall. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for Shimane Prefecture (including Hamada City, Masuda City, Onan Town, and Tsuwano Town in the west) at 5:55 AM on the 5th (which was lifted at 11:15 AM the same day). In the afternoon of the 5th, cumulonimbus clouds formed successively in the northern part of the Chikugo region in Fukuoka Prefecture, moving eastward while developing and forming a linear precipitation band. As a result, intense rain continued for a long time in the same location. Rainfall exceeding 100mm per hour was analyzed from radar observations in Asakura City, Ukiha City, Kurume City, Higashitake Village in Fukuoka Prefecture, Tosu City in Saga Prefecture, and Hita City in Oita Prefecture. In particular, around Asakura City, approximately 400mm of rain was analyzed over three hours and about 900mm over twelve hours. Outside of the Japan Meteorological Agency's jurisdiction, a rain gauge in Teranai, Asakura City recorded 169mm of rainfall in one hour until 3:20 PM on the 5th, while a rain gauge in Kurokawa (Kita Koji Community Center) recorded 778mm of rainfall over nine hours until 8:50 PM on the 5th (averaging about 86mm per hour). This one-hour rainfall approached the Japanese record of 187mm (Nagasaki Prefecture, Nagayo Town, during the 1982 Nagasaki flood), and the nine-hour rainfall significantly exceeded the twelve-hour rainfall record of 695.0mm observed by the Japan Meteorological Agency (Kochi Local Meteorological Observatory, during the 1998 Kochi heavy rain), indicating that the precipitation intensity in the mountainous areas of Asakura City was among the highest in Japan's meteorological observation history within that nine-hour timeframe. At 5:51 PM on the 5th, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for the Chikugo and Chikuho regions in Fukuoka Prefecture, stating that "the danger of significant damage is imminent." Furthermore, at 7:55 PM, a special heavy rain warning was issued for almost all of Oita Prefecture. At 3:10 AM on July 6th, the Japan Meteorological Agency added five cities and two towns in Fukuoka Prefecture to the special heavy rain warning area, which now included most of Fukuoka Prefecture and almost all of Oita Prefecture. At the time of the heavy rain, warm and moist air was flowing in from a tropical depression over the southern sea towards the rainy season front near the Tsushima Strait in northern Kyushu, while cold air was present aloft, creating a very unstable atmospheric condition. In this environment, cumulonimbus clouds formed successively at the boundary between the warm air near the surface and the cold air. The cooled air from the previously rainy regions of Chugoku and Shikoku flowed in and intensified the situation. Additionally, moist air flowed in from two directions surrounding the Sefuri Mountains on the border of Fukuoka and Saga Prefectures, merging on the eastern side of the Sefuri Mountains, which is believed to have strengthened the rainfall. The linear precipitation band was maintained through a process called back-building, where cumulonimbus clouds repeatedly formed and developed while moving eastward. The weather forecast for the morning of the heavy rain day predicted cloudy weather in the Chikugo region, with severe thunderstorms in some areas in the afternoon, while western Oita Prefecture was forecasted to be sunny then cloudy, with thunderstorms expected in some areas from the morning.

As of June 1, 2018, according to the Fire Department, 40 deaths have been confirmed in Fukuoka Prefecture (37 people in Asakura City and 3 in Higashitake Village) and 3 in Hita City, Oita Prefecture. Additionally, 2 people are missing in Asakura City, Fukuoka Prefecture. The total residential damage in Fukuoka and Oita Prefectures includes 336 completely destroyed buildings, 1,096 partially destroyed buildings, 44 buildings with some damage, 180 buildings with flooding above the floor, and 1,481 buildings with flooding below the floor (including damage from Typhoon No. 3). According to a survey by Professor Motoyuki Ushiyama of Shizuoka University’s Disaster Prevention Center, the causes of death and missing persons were 23 from landslides and 18 from flooding. Many houses were swept away by the flood, and despite the high number of flood victims, many (30 people) were affected indoors, which is a characteristic of this heavy rain disaster.

In Asakura City, Fukuoka Prefecture, the Katsuragawa River flooded in the Ninjō area, and the Hikosan River flooded in Soeda Town. In Hita City, Oita Prefecture, part of the Ōhi River overflowed, leading to the isolation of some areas. The Hanagatsukawa River also flooded in Hita City. A large amount of driftwood was observed in the disaster area, with the total amount estimated to be about 200,000 tons, or 360,000 cubic meters. Trees such as cedar, which were knocked down by landslides, flowed down the river, blocking the river's flow and causing flooding. The driftwood that surged into residential areas increased the destructive power compared to just the water flow, causing significant damage to houses. In addition to direct destruction, the driftwood also caused damage indirectly by increasing the pressure of the water flow. In Hita City, a bridge on the JR Kyūdai Line crossing the Hanagatsukawa was washed away, and it is believed that the driftwood got caught on the bridge, causing the water to be blocked and increasing the water volume, which exerted a great force on the bridge.

In the Ono district of Hita City, Oita Prefecture, a large landslide occurred around 10:30 AM on the 6th, causing debris to rush into residential homes, resulting in one person being caught and killed. The landslide blocked the river, creating a debris dam. The mountainous area with a geological formation known as "masago soil" could not withstand the sudden heavy rain, leading to surface collapses in various locations. The surface collapse caused cedar driftwood to flow into the river, resulting in the collapse of a reservoir. It has also been pointed out that the artificial forests, which are densely populated with trees like cedar, have not been properly managed, as thinning and improving sunlight exposure are necessary for the trees to grow and develop deep roots.

Whole_Text.header: Evacuation instructions and rescue from isolation.
Whole_Text.content: As of 8:30 AM on July 6, evacuation orders and recommendations were issued to a total of approximately 517,900 people centered around Fukuoka and Oita prefectures. Additionally, a total of 29 communities in both prefectures became temporarily isolated.

In Asakura City, the nationally designated historic site, the Asakura Three-Way Waterwheel, which is also registered as an irrigation facility heritage, has been buried by sediment, and part of the main hall of the important cultural property at Fumon-in Temple in the same city has also been buried in sediment. At least 20 cultural properties designated and registered by the national and local governments in Fukuoka and Oita have been affected.

Due to heavy rain, the mountains where fruit trees were planted collapsed, and sediment flowed into greenhouses, causing serious damage to crops. In Hita City, Oita Prefecture, which is known as one of Japan's three major forestry areas, many cedar trees were washed away. In the tourism industry, about 11,500 cancellations occurred in Fukuoka Prefecture for accommodations alone, and to dispel the negative rumors, a discount program called "Fukuoka Support Discount" was started in mid-August to support travel products that include accommodations and tourism.

At the time of the heavy rain disaster, the service was suspended for regular vehicle maintenance. After the maintenance was completed, service resumed as scheduled on August 22, but the route was changed to one that does not pass through the Kyūdai Main Line.

Whole_Text.header: The flood of the millennium in Wrocław
Whole_Text.content: Poland Wrocław flood July 12, 1997 – August 6, 1997 The millennium flood in Wrocław – a catastrophic flooding of a significant part of Wrocław during the millennium flood that struck Central Europe in July 1997. In Lower Silesia, the waters of the Odra River and its tributaries, including the Bóbr, Bystrzyca, Kaczawa, Kwisa, Mała Panew, Nysa Kłodzka, Nysa Łużycka, Olza, Oława, Ślęza, and Widawa overflowed. The floodwaters of the Odra entered the city on July 12, 1997, and finally receded on August 6. The millennium flood in Wrocław was particularly severe because two flood waves overlapped: from the Odra and the Widawa. Additionally, a few days before the peak, the residents of the village of Łany near Wrocław did not allow it to flood, which would have significantly reduced the damage. Due to the specific course of the river through the city, the overflow occurred independently both in the center and in the northern part of Wrocław. 40% of the city's area was underwater.

The flood that struck southern and western Poland, the Czech Republic, eastern Germany (Lusatia), northwestern Slovakia, and eastern Austria in July 1997 resulted in the deaths of 114 people and material damages amounting to nearly 4.5 billion US dollars in the Czech Republic, Germany, and Poland. Due to the magnitude of the phenomenon and the losses, it is commonly referred to as the flood of the millennium. In Poland, 56 people died, and the damages were estimated at around 3.5 billion dollars.

There have been multiple floods in Lower Silesia in the past. Only in the early 20th century, there were two in Wrocław: in 1903 and 1905. As a result, a modern protective system was built – by 1920, the Wrocław water junction was created, consisting of flood protection channels, 93 km of embankments, 11 weirs, and 10 navigation locks, capable of handling water flows of 2200–2400 m³/s (626 cm). This system proved effective during the floods in 1975 and 1985, but it did not account for the accumulation of waves from more than one river, meaning water flows of around 3600 m³/s.

The water rise below the Polish-Czech border began on July 5, 1997, and then in Racibórz-Miedonia, between 2:00 and 4:00 AM, the peak reached a level of 1045 cm (207 cm higher than the previously observed absolute maximum in 1985). The greatest losses in the upper Oder basin were recorded in the Wodzisław, Racibórz, and Opole counties. Just two days before the flood, the local edition of Gazeta Wyborcza reported: "In Wrocław, we are not at risk of flooding, but (...) some basements may be flooded." The highest flood wave began to reach Wrocław on July 12, Saturday, in the afternoon. The fact that the city's residents already knew from the press, radio, and television about the damage caused by the Oder in Racibórz and Opole, and that for most of them it was a day off work, significantly influenced their mobilization and ability to self-organize in response to the impending threat. Already on the preceding Thursday (July 10), the city's president, Bogdan Zdrojewski, alarmed by the situation in Opole, urged the residents of Wrocław to start stockpiling drinking water, and to the directors of the largest institutions in the city – to take appropriate preparatory actions in case of flooding. Additionally, just before Wrocław, two peak water levels merged: from the Nysa Kłodzka and the Oder.

On Thursday and Friday, the possibility of lowering the flood wave approaching Wrocław by breaching the dikes in Jeszkowice and Łany was considered. However, the opposition from a large group of gathered residents of these villages and Kamieniec Wrocławski, particularly in Łany, prevented the water from spreading over the local fields and residential buildings. Although preparatory work and the gathering of explosives by sapper units were already underway, and the dikes were secured by a police cordon, people alarmed by one of the residents poured out on the night of July 11 to defend the village from flooding. During the installation of explosives, there were skirmishes between the sappers and the residents of Łany. In the morning, the deputy voivode canceled the sapper operation, and the population was informed that "there had been a mistake." A new operation was undertaken by the voivode, who arrived in the village around 6:00 PM, but he also failed to convince the residents. The deputy commander of the Wrocław police, Jan Albrechciński, refused to use force. The Minister of Internal Affairs and Administration, Leszek Miller, who was in Wrocław that day, demanded the dismissal of the deputy commander. Another decision was made at four in the morning. The operation was carried out from helicopters, but the explosives turned out to be too small to blow up the dikes. The next day, the Prime Minister Włodzimierz Cimoszewicz, who was in Wrocław, signed blank promissory notes to compensate for the losses after the destruction of the village. The voivode and the marshal of the local government assembly, Leon Kieres, went to Łany with the promissory notes. They also failed to convince the residents. The situation in Łany was the subject of comments from politicians, ethicists, hydrologists, and even the Supreme Audit Office. A journalist from Gazeta Wyborcza commented on the residents' stance: Łany became a symbol. For some, the lesser evil, that is, the attempt to save a large city at the cost of flooding several hundred farms and houses in fifteen villages; for others, the determination of ordinary people against a soulless, arrogant authority ready to use the police and military to destroy their life's possessions in the name of saving Wrocław's monuments. On the same day, President Zdrojewski issued an order to evacuate residents of neighborhoods bordering Wrocław from the north and east. However, most residents refused and stayed in their homes.

On July 9 at 8:00 AM, President Bogdan Zdrojewski declared a flood alert, and two days later appealed to residents to make necessary preparations: gathering drinking water, candles, and gas bottles. Panic spread in the city, and some residents accused the president of collusion with mineral water bottlers. On July 11, work began on building flood barriers in the city. The action was coordinated by the flood committee, and work was carried out in shifts. According to estimates from the City Hall, between 300,000 and 480,000 sandbags were laid in Wrocław. Some bags were even brought in by air, including from Gdańsk. The bags were filled not only with sand brought in for this purpose from sandpits; there was widespread permission to use sand gathered for street repairs in various parts of the city (for instance, a significant section of the finished subgrade on General Józef Haller Street was dug up for this purpose); most children's sandpits in Wrocław were also emptied in the process. Soil was also taken from lawns. In the most flood-prone areas of the city, the bags were mainly laid by spontaneously gathering volunteers, especially in the first hours of the threat, who generally directed themselves to the appropriate places based on their own knowledge of the local topography, often also in response to announcements made on the radio and television. Later, organized groups of soldiers and firefighters from across the country also arrived at these locations. On Friday, July 11, the flood embankment in Siechnice was breached, which ultimately determined the arrival of the flood wave in Wrocław. On July 12, around 6:00 AM, police alerted the residents of the Księże Małe estate, announcing through megaphones the necessity of immediate evacuation in the face of the approaching flood wave from the northeast (the Oława River basin). However, a significant majority of residents remained in their homes and began preparations to fend off the flood wave. For this purpose, every available source of sand was used, for example, all nearby sandpits were completely emptied. Car owners tried from early morning to move their vehicles and park them in other parts of the city; some desperately searched for any elevations in the area to protect their vehicles from destruction. Around 1:00 PM, water overflowed onto Opolska Street and surged into the estate, reaching a height of 180 cm within an hour. Streets such as Katowicka, Chorzowska, Bytomska, Tarnogórska, and Głubczycka were flooded. For the next few days, food and water were delivered by military Mi-17 helicopters, whose crews dropped supplies onto building roofs or lowered them on ropes.

On Saturday, July 12, water surged into the city center, likely through Żabia Grobla and Traugutta Street, where the levees were breached. It then reached the city moat via Kościuszki Street and Komuny Paryskiej, flooding the surrounding neighborhoods, and by night reached Piłsudski Street and the Main Station to the south, while flowing towards Legnicka Street and the Szczepin neighborhood to the west. In this way, the northern part of the city was completely cut off from the southern part. It was only on Monday, July 14, in the afternoon, that residents managed to stop the water at Żabia Grobla. The Zalesie and Zacisze neighborhoods, located between the flood channel and the old Odra riverbed, were also affected, while Sępolno and Biskupin were protected before flooding. The Wrocław Zoo was also saved (only one zebra died, scared by the noise of helicopters), while the recently renovated Japanese Garden was affected just before the Eucharistic Congress. Water invaded neighborhoods built on flood-prone areas: Kowale, Maślice, Księże Małe, Księże Wielkie, Rakowiec, the Widawa neighborhood, and Pracze Odrzańskie. The Kozanów neighborhood was particularly devastated, where the waves of the Odra and Ślęza rivers overlapped. In this area, the water reached even the first floor. This neighborhood was built on floodplains, and due to delays in the decision to breach the flood levees and the flooding of recreational plots, the situation became critical at one point. Similarly, the water reached the first floor in Rakowiec (the so-called Bermuda Triangle), and the tenement houses there, many of which were built before World War II and often had wooden ceilings, were so severely damaged that many had to be demolished (a few collapsed on their own; no one was harmed). In Szczepin, the water remained exceptionally long due to the terrain's shape. The flood lasted the longest in Kozanów and Księż Mały, where even several days after the wave passed, access to buildings was only possible with the help of a pontoon or kayak. On July 16, the water began to recede from the city center. That day, bus services resumed. On Friday, July 18, the water level at the measurement point in Trestno dropped by more than 1.5 meters; water began to drain from Popowice. On the same day, a second wave of flooding was expected; the president ordered the immediate evacuation of residents from the northwestern districts of the city, including Leśnica and Pracze Odrzańskie. The situation was worsened by heavy rain falling during those days. It was only around July 22 that the areas near Siechnice began to dry out. Desperate residents of this town blocked the road to Wrocław. On July 23, the Ślęza river overflowed (due to backflow) and flooded Kozanów and Muchobór again. The second wave of flooding reached Wrocław on July 25 around 6:30 PM, once again flooding Siechnice.

The flood relief operation was conducted by the then-existing Provincial Flood Committee, the District Flood Committee, and the City Flood Committee established by a special presidential decree. A large operation took place on the night of July 12 to 13 on Ostrów Tumski, trying to save the most valuable monuments. In addition to volunteers, the fire brigade was working, controlling the flow of large objects: trees, containers, and even kiosks, which could strike critical points at any moment, such as a bridge span. Other important sites saved included the main train station, the Ossolineum library, and the collections of the National Museum. Efforts were made even at the risk of health and life. As Bogdan Zdrojewski recalls, at one point, one of the firefighters drove a pike too hard into a floating tree and, wanting to save it, nearly jumped into the water like a pole vaulter. The force of the water was simply enormous. He was barely kept on the shore. The same happened with a young man who tried to pull a floating object from the water while defending the zoo. There, the current was quite fast, and he probably owed his life to the reflexes of his colleagues. About 5,000 people participated in the rescue efforts, and during the entire flood period, 20,000 people helped. To protect the southern districts of the city from flooding, it was necessary to create a dam along the railway viaduct running from Brochów, through the Main Station, and further towards the Fabryczna district. As a result, the water was forced to flow through a narrow strip of the city to connect with the original current near Kozanów. This plan succeeded, and the southern districts were ultimately not flooded. The rescue operation also faced bureaucratic obstacles. The city president sought immediate vaccination of residents against typhoid and tetanus, which he did not receive approval for. There was a lack of cooperation between central institutions, and problems arose related to the division of responsibilities: state services were responsible for hydrotechnical facilities. There was also a lack of financial decisions. One of the bizarre accusations was the Supreme Audit Office's objection that President Zdrojewski did not sign the attendance list during the flood. Concurrently with the rescue operation, a humanitarian aid operation for the residents of the flooded city was underway. Convoys with aid were arriving in the city, despite the difficult access. The largest coordination center for aid was located in the Poltegor building (where, among others, Lower Silesian Television was based). The president, police, and volunteers worked there.

In the first days, the Odra flooded the cemetery and the garbage dump, and the lack of electricity also affected critical places, including hospitals. The supply of vaccines quickly ran out, and residents began to fear an epidemic. Water was shut off throughout the city, some neighborhoods were cut off from electricity, and phones and much of public transport were also not working. Food was delivered to buildings cut off from water by thirty military Mi-17 helicopters. The few wells were used, including one at the Powstańców Śląskich roundabout. People gathered on the roofs of flooded buildings, where social life took place, and from there they communicated with the outside world. The media, especially radio and Lower Silesian Television, informed about how to communicate with helicopters: white meant a need for emergency help, red for medical assistance. There were also pathological phenomena: the police arrested people speculating on the prices of mineral water, some demanded 200 zł for a ride on a pontoon, and there were also break-ins into homes abandoned during the flood. The police arrested a man who had gathered blankets and camping beds in his apartment, probably for resale at a profit. Those profiting from the sale of gifts for flood victims were to be punished under Article 204, paragraph 2 of the Penal Code concerning the appropriation of entrusted property, which carried a penalty of 6 months to 5 years in prison. During the flood, the most important task was to save the city. During a mass at the church on Wittiga Street, the pastor told the participants: we can pray another time, now take shovels and rubber boots and go save the zoo. Grocery stores in the center opened on Monday, July 14. Among the most sought-after items were bread, cigarettes, and batteries. Despite the difficulties, most had no trouble with supplies. The Wrocław PDT opened in the afternoon and sold the most necessary items from under the raised grate of the main entrance. The police asked stores to start mobile sales and from pontoons to flooded districts as much as possible. Due to the lack of electricity, some goods, such as ice cream, were given away for free. Pharmacies operated normally, and in cases of chronic illnesses, no prescription was needed; it was enough to show the packaging of the medicine. There were also humorous situations, such as young men diving into a liquor store. Another situation was recalled by then-President Bogdan Zdrojewski: I was surprised, for example, by the reaction of a very young man who slowed down his kayak at the sight of a red light at one of the flooded intersections. He looked left, right, and continued to paddle. Despite the serious atmosphere, numerous jokes circulated around the city, specifically referring to the flood, for example: A lady calls and says she has two dogs on a chain in her yard. – And how long is the chain? – they ask at the flood committee. – Well, about two meters. – Extend the chain – they hear in response – a three-meter wave will come. The reactions of residents to the flood varied depending on their age. For the young, it was an opponent to be faced, and they treated it with almost sporting engagement; the older ones saw it as a threat to their property and things of sentimental value, and even a threat to life. Nevertheless, there were no visible differences in action.

From the beginning, Lower Silesian Television was involved in the flood matters. On July 9, the flood response team announced a state of emergency for the Wrocław Voivodeship on the air of this television. Gradually, the airtime dedicated to information about the flood was increased, and from July 10, current information also appeared at night. From Saturday, July 12, until July 16, flood news was broadcast non-stop. The action initiated by the station was joined by President Bogdan Zdrojewski and Voivode Janusz Zaleski. The television also collaborated with the editorial offices of Słowo Polskie and local radio stations. In addition to its informational activities, the station coordinated the actions of services and volunteers fighting the flood, and the editorial office was transformed into a crisis management team. They organized sandbags, volunteers, as well as the distribution and coordination of aid for those affected by the flood. Dozens of phone numbers, both landline and mobile, were activated to help in the search for missing persons. The television returned to its regular programming only on July 28. The second information center, especially important for those without electricity, was Radio Wrocław. The hunger for information among the city's residents was great, and humanitarian convoys often encountered requests for batteries for radios. The flood also affected the editorial offices of Gazeta Wrocławska and the Lower Silesian Gazeta Wyborcza, but both of these newspapers had their printing houses in locations outside Wrocław; Gazeta Wrocławska moved its editorial office to a printing house in Bielany.

The millennium flood that affected Poland in July 1997 became an inspiration for filmmakers. On October 5, 2022, the series "Great Water" appeared on the Netflix platform. The production directly tells the story of the events from July 1997, when the flood wave was approaching Wrocław. The series was directed by Jan Holoubek and Bartłomiej Ignaciuk.

As a result of the flood, 2,583 residential buildings were flooded and submerged. During the rescue operation, historical monuments in Wrocław's city center were saved, including the entire Ostrów Tumski and Piasek Island, as well as the market, main train station, and Ossolineum library. The concert hall building was flooded, but pianos were managed to be saved. The ground floor of the Music Academy was also submerged. The Polish Theatre and the regional court were also flooded. Additionally, three sports halls, the city port, a water treatment plant, and the recently renovated Świebodzki Station were affected by the flood. Furthermore, 44 km of roads and 21 bridges, footbridges, and viaducts needed to be rebuilt. The repairs cost the city 132 million zlotys, and 115 million zlotys in grants were obtained: 66.2 million zlotys from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, 43 million zlotys from the World Bank, and 5.7 million zlotys from the Phare program. A decision was also made to modernize the Wrocław water junction and to construct the Odra-Widawa canal. In 2017, the Wrocław water junction was prepared for a capacity of 3,100 m³/s, new levees were built, and old ones were reinforced, while the Odra riverbeds were cleared and widened. The city's sand protection was also improved to 300,000 bags (20,000 m³). The renovation of the Kozanowska Embankment ensured that the neighborhood is safe in case of rising water levels.

Whole_Text.header: The flood of the millennium in Opole
Whole_Text.content: Poland Opole flood July 10, 1997 – July 16, 1997 The flood of the millennium – a common name for the flood that struck southern and western Poland, the Czech Republic, eastern Germany (Lusatia), northwestern Slovakia, and eastern Austria in July 1997, resulting in the deaths of 114 people and material damages amounting to nearly 4.5 billion US dollars in the Czech Republic, Germany, and Poland. In Poland, 56 people died, and the damages were estimated at about 3.5 billion dollars. In the entire Opole region, 8 people died. In Opole, the flood inundated part of the city, including a section of the center and the Bolko and Pasieka islands.

A flood alert was announced on many rivers in the region, as well as a flood warning for Opole on July 6, and two days later, at four in the morning, the water level, which had risen to about 590 cm, began to invade the city. The peak wave reached Opole on July 10, 1997. The southern districts were the first to be flooded. The flood breached the levee near the Metalchem housing estate, resulting in flooding of many factories located there. The wave then reached the Bolko and Pasieka islands. Many important institutions for the city were submerged there, including the artificial ice rink Toropol along with the hotel, the Fryderyk Chopin State Music School of the first and second degree along with its dormitory, the Consulate of the Federal Republic of Germany, the headquarters of Radio Opole and the newspaper "Nowa Trybuna Opolska," which relocated to the sales room of a computer store during the flood, a kindergarten and a gymnasium, an amphitheater, a zoo, as well as the Voivodeship Public Library and the Silesian Institute. The most affected by the flood were the districts of Pasieka Island, Bolko Island, and "closer" Zaodrze, where 100% of the buildings were flooded.

The flood also affected the Opole Zoo. Some animals were evacuated to zoos in Wrocław, Chorzów, and Płock. During transport, the animals were sedated. Some cages, those where items that the animals could climb on had not been thrown in time, were opened. Despite the rescue operation, some animals drowned, including kangaroos, antelopes, deer, and a hippopotamus. Some animals fought for their lives for a long time. Lioness Ryksa kept her head above water in a 20-centimeter space between the water and the ceiling of the cage all day. She was not saved. It is unknown what happened to the released animals, including a pack of wolves. This was the first major flood to hit Opole since 1903.

Intensified efforts to secure the city prevented the water from flooding the Old Town, which is located in close proximity to Młynówka. Flooded institutions forced the military to blow up the flood barriers protecting nearby Zaodrze. The first barrier was to be blown up near Winów, and then the barrier in the so-called close Zaodrze, which resulted in the entire Zaodrze being flooded, but the Old Town and the center were saved before the flooding. Due to the very rapid rise in water, the residents of Zaodrze were not evacuated. They spent many hours sheltering on the roofs and balconies of high-rise buildings, waiting for rescue. A help point was organized in the city center where people affected by the flood gathered; often their only surviving possessions were the clothes they were wearing. During the rescue operation, special attention was paid to areas around the flooded necropolises, as was the case on Wrocławska Street and at Metalchem. A campaign was also conducted to find sponsors for summer camp vacations for children from the flooded city. Over 1,000 applications were recorded. During the flood, there were also many thefts from shops, cars, and abandoned apartments due to evacuation. The water in the city began to recede on Wednesday, July 16.

Article_Name: Inundación de México de 1446, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The great flood of Mexico-Tenochtitlán in 1446 caused death and severe damage to the chinampa system in the city of Mexico-Tenochtitlán, during the reign of Moctezuma I. After the flood, there was scarcity and hunger. The situation did not normalize until the year 1455.

Tenochtitlán was located in the lower part of the Mexico basin, on an islet in the ancient lake of Texcoco. This geographical location made it vulnerable to flooding despite the adaptation of its inhabitants to their natural environment, reflected in the ingenious system of chinampas. In 1382, a partial flood had already been recorded that caused serious damage to the city founded in 1325. At the time of the flood, the Mexica, under the command of Moctezuma I, had defeated in the war of Chalco, a fact that consolidated their dominance in Anáhuac. In the same year of the flood, shortly before, a plague of locusts (chapulines) had affected the corn harvest.

According to the chronicles, abundant rains and hail fell in the year seven, ácatl (1446). The water level rose to the branches of the trees, causing numerous deaths. All the streets of the city were flooded, several houses were destroyed, and people were forced to travel exclusively by canoe. Emperor Moctezuma I, very distressed, sought advice from Nezahualcóyotl, lord of Texcoco, who advised him to build a causeway, from what is now La Villa to Iztapalapa, as a dam to protect the city from future floods. The idea was accepted, and it was executed with the labor of the towns of Azcapotzalco, Coyoacán, Tlacópan, Xochimilco, Iztapalapa, Culhuacán, and Tenayócan. Even the main nobles of Tenochtitlán participated in the work. In the end, the dam measured nine miles long and eleven fathoms wide. With these works, the flooding was partially repaired.

The disaster of the flood was followed by hunger, as in the next two years the corn harvest was very scarce. In the year 1450, the harvest was low due to a series of droughts and hailstorms, so by 1452 the need of the peoples of Anáhuac was "so great" that the upper classes opened their granaries for the benefit of their vassals. Despite this, the diet of the people was maintained by eating waterfowl, marsh herbs, roots, insects, and fish from the lake itself. The year of greatest scarcity and hunger was 1454. As a result of the hunger, many inhabitants left the region, some died in the fields, and others took refuge in regions like Totonacpan (now the Sierra Norte de Puebla) never to return. Ixtlilxóchitl states that the desperation was such that some sold their children to the inhabitants of Totonacpan in exchange for corn. Finally, in 1455 there were abundant rains and a good harvest that ended the hunger.

Whole_Text.header: Interpretation and political consequences of the flood
Whole_Text.content: It was believed that the gods were upset because sacrifices were not being made to them, and for this reason, the sacred war or flower wars were established. This meant that the peoples of the region had to periodically go out to battle. This fact continued the series of conquests of Moctezuma I and increased not only the renown and political influence of Tenochtitlán but also enriched it and made it the most populated city in the region.
Heavy rainfall starting from June 17, 2013, in the French and Spanish Pyrenees, combined with the resulting snowmelt, led to flooding in the Pyrenees in 2013.

The reason for the event was a smaller Biscay low (named by DWD Lars and Manni), which settled over Spain and France for several days. It brought moist Mediterranean air masses against the Pyrenees on its front side. Météo-France issued storm warnings starting June 17, which were only lifted on June 19. In Vielha, 115 liters/m² of rain fell from June 17 to June 18 within 24 hours. In winter, there had been up to 4 meters of snow, the largest amounts since 1980. In total, precipitation and meltwater reached a record level that had not been seen since measurements began in 1959. The area had already experienced a prolonged period of bad weather (in the context of severe flooding in central Europe in early June), causing the waters to drain immediately. The Gave de Pau reached record levels at several gauges. In Spain, the maximum flow rates were 10 to 20 times the normal (Noguera Pallaresa 160 m³/s, Noguera Ribagorçana 190 m³/s). The northern side of the Pyrenees was more severely affected, while on the southern side, the flood levels from October 2012, which had been the most severe event in the last 50 years, were generally not fully reached.

Affected were particularly the upper reaches of the Garonne and the valley of the Gave de Pau. Media reported a total of three deaths (in Lourdes, Luz-Saint-Sauveur, Cauneille). Especially the water masses of the Garonne caused numerous landslides and washed away several houses, roads, bridges, and countless trees. Several disaster management plans (crisis cells) were activated in the departments of Haute-Garonne and Hautes-Pyrénées. Authorities evacuated 3,000 people. In the pilgrimage site of Lourdes on the banks of the Gave de Pau, the underground Basilica of Pius X was flooded, and the Bernadette Basilica from the 19th century and the Marian grotto itself were also affected. In the city, damages amounted to double-digit millions, significantly exceeding the costs of the floods that had occurred shortly before in October 2012. The valley of Pays Toy at Bastan in the Adour catchment area was also severely affected. Approximately 9 million euros in aid funds were disbursed in the Garonne area.

In Spain, Ésera, Noguera Pallaresa, Noguera de Cardós, and other mountain streams in the Val d’Aran, Pallars Sobirà, Alta Ribagorça, and the north of Pallars Jussà were affected by the high waters. In Catalonia, people had to be evacuated in several villages. Numerous bridges and roads, as well as individual houses, were destroyed. The flooding events led to a review of the scenarios used and a refinement of the disaster plans.

Whole_Text.content: The Nanshan Castle Flood (Minamiyamashiro Suigai) refers to the flood that occurred from August 14 to August 15, 1953, in the southern part of Kyoto Prefecture (Tsuji County and Sagara County), caused by heavy rainfall that affected the tributaries of the Kizu River.

From August 14 to 15, 1953, the Nanzan Castle area was hit by heavy rainfall caused by a stationary cold front. The rain began in the evening of the 14th and turned into a torrential downpour with thunder in the early hours of the 15th, resulting in record rainfall exceeding 400 millimeters in mountainous areas. This rain triggered landslides in various locations, leading to mudflows containing large amounts of driftwood. Many reservoirs and embankments of tributaries of the Kizugawa River collapsed. In Ide Town, the collapse of the Taisho Pond and the Ninotani Pond upstream of the Tamagawa caused mudflows, which also led to the collapse of the Tamagawa downstream. In the area corresponding to the later Yamashiro Town (now Kizugawa City), the Fudo River and Narukogawa River collapsed, and in Wazuka Town, the Wazukagawa River flooded, causing significant damage. The term "heavy rainfall" is said to have first appeared in newspaper headlines during this event.

On August 14, it was drizzling in the evening, but from around 10 or 11 PM, it turned into heavy rain, and around the time the date changed to August 15, it became a torrential downpour accompanied by thunder. Around 2:30 AM, the first breach occurred at the Saida River, and flooding began in the low-lying areas of Ide Town. From around 3 AM, overflow and breaches started to occur sequentially on the right bank (north side) downstream of the Tamagawa River. Then, around 4 AM, agricultural reservoirs upstream (Taisho Pond and Nino Valley Pond) breached almost simultaneously, causing a mountain tsunami. This led to further breaches upstream of the Tamagawa River, resulting in significant damage to Ide Town. The Tamamizu area of Ide Town is surrounded by levees on three sides: the Kizugawa levee, the Tamagawa levee, and the Taga-Tanikawa levee, making it a typical area prone to internal water flooding. As a result, while drainage progressed early in other affected areas, the water level in this area did not decrease even days after the disaster, and many of the missing persons were found to have washed up in this location.

The southern Yamashiro region suffered tremendous damage due to this flood and the subsequent Typhoon No. 13. The human toll includes 336 dead or missing and 1,366 injured, totaling 1,702 people. In terms of housing damage, there were 371 completely destroyed homes, 381 washed away, 554 partially destroyed, and 4,370 homes affected by flooding above and below the floor, totaling 5,676 homes. The total material damage from this flood is officially reported to be about 15 billion yen, with recovery costs estimated at about 13.4 billion yen.

Among them, Ide Town suffered the greatest damage in terms of both human casualties and housing damage in the Nanzanjo region. The human casualties in Ide Town included 108 dead or missing and 428 injured, totaling 536 people. The housing damage included 107 completely destroyed houses, 166 washed away, 147 partially destroyed, and 357 houses flooded both above and below the floor, totaling 777 houses. The Japan National Railways line (Kansai Main Line and Nara Line) running through this area suffered significant damage, with the station buildings at Tamamizu Station and Okawara Station being washed away. Additionally, the Tamamizu Bridge over the Kizugawa River was also washed away due to debris being trapped against its piers.

In the August flood, bulldozers and crane trucks, which were rare at the time, were used, and emergency construction work on various rivers progressed. In the early hours of August 15, the application of the Disaster Relief Act was decided, and at the same time, relief activities and emergency recovery work began. On the 16th, relief supplies were transported by U.S. Marine Corps helicopters to Wazuka Town, Minamiyamashiro Village, and the Dosenbo area, which had been cut off from transportation. From the 18th, supplies such as salt, rice, and vegetables were recorded. Relief supplies were transported from the Noden area to the severely affected Dosenbo cattle and horse area. A diary of recovery activities since the flood has been left in the Noden area, noting that the residents engaged in recovery efforts. In September, operations on the Nara Line and Kansai Main Line resumed. At Tamamizu Station, a large stone that washed ashore from the Tamagawa River remains as a memorial. In 1954, a memorial tower for flood victims was established. The reconstruction of the washed-away Tamamizu Bridge was completed in November 1956. On the site of Taisho Pond and Nino Valley Pond, a new Taisho Pond was created under the "Yodogawa River System Improvement Basic Plan," which was completed in 1960.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Piedmont in 2008, an event also known as the flood of Villar Pellice since the latter was the most affected location, was a disastrous event that struck the region between May 28 and May 30, 2008.

Piedmont was the scene of other similar events in 1948, 1977, 1994, and 2000 that caused serious damage to the building heritage as well as many human losses. In particular, during the event of May 19-20, 1977, the Val Pellice was the victim of another terrible landslide: a massive amount of debris fell from the basin of the Rio di Garin, now Rio Cassarot, hitting the entire village of Garin, injuring 2 people. Other damage occurred in the Chisone and Germanasca valleys, including the collapse of the bridge between Bibiana and Bricherasio, which caused the death of seven people who fell with their cars.

On May 28, 2008, in Piedmont, especially in the alpine area of the province of Turin, extraordinary rainfall began that affected much of the valleys involved, causing many problems such as flooding, power outages, blackouts, landslides, and damage to homes. The highest peaks of rain were recorded at Col Barant, which measured approximately 312 mm (373 mm if all three days are considered) and at Prali, which recorded 219 mm (276 mm if all three days are considered). On May 29, the Amedeo di Savoia hospital in Turin was evacuated and closed due to a possible overflow of the Dora Riparia river, while several bridges in the city and province were closed. At 10:25, the most tragic event of the flood occurred: a large mass of mud and debris from the Rio Cassarot basin, approximately 40,000 m³, fell into Val Pellice, flooding the village of Garin in Villar Pellice in just a few seconds. Many homes were damaged, and 2 were completely destroyed. The flow also affected roads and fields up to the confluence of the Rio Cassarot with the Pellice. Rescue operations began immediately from the civil hospital in Pinerolo using helicopters, ambulances, fire trucks, and police and finance guard vans. Their assistance was supported by bulldozers for earth removal, and the excavations lasted two days. About 300 people were evacuated as a precaution. There were also disruptions in various areas of the province of Turin where landslides were recorded in Ceresole Reale and Pont Canavese. On May 30, the events came to an end, although the morning was still affected by moderate rainfall, followed by a damage assessment, which amounted to about 5 million euros promptly allocated by the region.

In the landslide of Val Pellice, a total of 6 people were involved: 4 were killed, of which 3 were in the collapsed houses and 1 due to being overturned by the flow of a car and a tractor; 3 people were slightly injured while 1 person was unharmed by the flow.

Article_Name: Powódź w Gdańsku (1829) – Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia

Whole_Text.content: Kingdom of Prussia Gdańsk flood April 8–9, 1829 20–99 The flood in Gdańsk – a flood that occurred in April 1829 in Gdańsk, in the territory of the Kingdom of Prussia.

On the night of April 8 to 9, 1829, as a result of the passage of an Atlantic hurricane over the Gulf of Gdańsk, there was a retreat of seawater that blocked the flow of ice from the Vistula River. The swollen waters flooded the Vistula Delta, the Old Town, the Granary Island, and Ołowianka on the Motława, the Main and Old Town, Lower Town, as well as the area of the present districts of Stogi, Olszynka, and New Port. This was the largest flood in the history of the city, which inundated 3/4 of the then area of Gdańsk and lasted almost 3 weeks (until April 28). Several dozen people died in it, and about 12,000 people lost their homes. The flood was commemorated, among other things, by plaques on the walls of the "Panna" granary on Ołowianka and the Kamienna Lock in Lower Town. To protect Gdańsk and the Vistula Delta from flooding, the Vistula Cut (7.1 km long) was built between 1891 and 1895, allowing for the quick drainage of floodwaters and ice from the Vistula River to the Baltic Sea via the shortest route.

Whole_Text.content: The Olsmässo flood was a heavy rain that began on July 27, 1649, and lasted for weeks. It primarily affected the central parts of Östergötland. The storm caused significant material destruction and resulted in such severe damage to the arable land that crop failure was the consequence.
The Danube flood of 1954 was an exceptionally strong flood event, triggered by rainfall in the Bavarian and Austrian foothills of the Alps from July 7 to 11, 1954.

Since June 27, it had been raining daily in the foothills of the Alps, and this rain intensified from July 1, turning into flood rain from July 7. The precipitation in southeastern Bavaria from July 7 to 11 amounted to over 400 mm, and over 250 mm in the Bavarian Forest. Caused by tributaries, the Danube experienced extreme flooding from Regensburg. The Inn River at its confluence in Passau on July 10 carried almost three times the amount of Danube water and nearly reached the level of the year 1899. In Bavaria, 9,000 people had to be evacuated, there were twelve fatalities, and over 150,000 hectares were flooded. In Upper Austria, this flood was the strongest of the 20th century. In the Linz urban area, 2,000 hectares were flooded, and 5,500 people had to be evacuated. The water level in Linz rose to 9.62 m on July 11, which was not reached again by the Danube flood in August 2002 (8.20 m). The flooding in the Eferdinger Basin was three times the size of Lake Traun. Since the rainfall in the areas of Enns and Traun was lower and the peak flows of the Lower Austrian Danube tributaries had receded a few days earlier, the flood wave flattened out from Mauthausen. In Vienna, among other places, Wehlistraße, Handelskai, and the cycling stadium in the Prater were flooded.

This is a verified version of this page regarding the floods of Bab El Oued. They are massive floods and torrential torrents after heavy rains that did not cease, devastating everything in their path and displacing entire families in 2001 in the municipality of Bab El Oued in Algiers. They left hundreds of victims swept away by the torrents towards the sea, some of whom were recovered and some of whom remain missing to this day.

Laz slide-flood (Qusar, 1993) — A slide-flood that occurred on September 10, 1993, in the area of the village of Laz in the Qusar region.

On September 8, 1993, an earthquake of magnitude 4 occurred in the central Caspian Sea. At that time, a weak tremor was observed in Laza, and cracks formed in residential houses. On September 9, the villagers witnessed a strange natural phenomenon. Countless eagles were circling over the carcasses of sheep that had been trapped under a suddenly fallen rock. On September 10, the residents of Laza were awakened early in the morning by a terrible rumble and witnessed mud flowing from the waterfall in the village. As noted by scientists, after the rains on September 9-10, a landslide-flood process began here. The process started as a landslide and partially as a collapse after the rain, and the moving mass collected from the source of the Laza River into the beds of its tributaries. Moving from an altitude of 2400-2500 m, it entered the river valley. Here, large landslide masses turned into a stony-muddy flood with a small amount of water. Since this flood poured down like a waterfall from a height of 80-100 m, its speed increased. It spread to the sloping plain part of the Laza River valley. This lasted for one day. The mass brought by the flood caused the relief here to rise by 3-6 m. In a village consisting of 19 houses located at an altitude of 1650 m above sea level, 3 houses were submerged by the flood. Among the materials brought by the flood were rock fragments made of limestone, weighing between 5-6 tons and even reaching 15-20 tons. Scientists say that this type of landslide-flood flow is a rare occurrence in nature. The mud brought to Laza by the flood dried up after 3 years.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Acireale and Giarre occurred on March 13, 1995, when a heavy downpour hit northeastern Sicily and part of southern Calabria, causing extensive damage, especially in the area between Acireale, Giarre, Mascali, and Riposto, where there were landslides and flooding. A total of 6 victims and 7 injured were recorded, along with 5 victims and 7 missing from the Greek ship Pelhunter, which sank off the Sicilian coast.

Already towards the end of February 1995, the Sicilian Civil Protection, after consulting the weather reports, had issued a medium alert between the areas of Catania and Messina for the risk of heavy rainfall and some landslides. In early March, the rainfall intensified and the alert was extended to the province of Reggio Calabria, but the situation remained mostly stable until Saturday, March 11, when a statement from the civil protection was issued declaring the alert to be at the maximum level. In the early hours of Monday, March 13, 1995, the rainfall began to become very high: peaks of 224.6 mm to 253.6 mm were recorded. The sewers began to flood the streets of Acireale around 7:30 AM, while Giarre was declared flooded around 9:15 AM. In Calabria, the rainfall events affected the areas of the Ionian coast and Crotone, where rainfall peaks of 178 mm to 191.6 mm were recorded. Soon, storms, landslides, and some swollen streams emerged, interrupting communications and road traffic. In Acireale, two old buildings collapsed and some cars collided, while in Giarre a truck overturned, crushing two parked cars. Around 11:00 AM, the municipalities affected by the flood urged citizens to stay home and go out as little as possible. Numerous buildings were damaged, and in the countryside, many agricultural fields were destroyed by the violence of the water and the force of the wind. A total of 6 deaths were counted: 3 people died in Giarre swept away by the waters, 2 in Acireale drowned in their homes, and one in Mascali, carried away by the waters into a manhole. Additionally, the flood caused strong waves, which were the main cause of the tragedy involving the Greek ship Pelhunter: the ship, having left the port of Riposto around 7:45 PM, was suddenly caught by a strong wave while exiting the harbor, about 140 km from the coast, causing the immediate capsizing of the vessel, which had 15 people on board. Rescue operations, due to the extremely difficult communication situation, only began after 9:00 PM, and they were able to locate the ship only at night, given the sea conditions at that time. In the sinking of the Pelhunter, 5 people died, another 3 were rescued, while 7 people were never found and were effectively declared missing.

Whole_Text.content: The 2018 Shouguang flood refers to the flood disaster that occurred in Shouguang City, Weifang City, Shandong Province, China, from August 19 to 21, 2018, due to heavy rain and concentrated discharge from upstream reservoirs on the Mi River, causing flooding in the Shouguang section of the Mi River. From August 19 to 20, influenced by tropical storm Bebinca, the Mi River basin in Shandong experienced extremely heavy rainfall, leading to rising water levels in several reservoirs, including the Yeyuan Reservoir and the Tangshuiya Reservoir in Qingzhou and Linqu, prompting flood discharge from these reservoirs. Although the reservoirs provided some warning to downstream villagers, the time was only sufficient for residents to evacuate, and their livestock and property could not be relocated. This event resulted in the highest flood peak in the Shouguang section of the Mi River since 1974, with several villages along the Shouguang coast experiencing backflow from the river, causing significant damage to numerous homes, farmland, greenhouses, and breeding farms, and potentially leading to instability in vegetable supply to Beijing. During the same period as the Shouguang flood, there was a continuous rise in vegetable prices nationwide, which was reported by Xinhua News Agency. According to official statistics, by 5 PM on the 23rd, the disaster had caused 13 deaths, 3 missing persons, and the collapse of 9,999 houses, with economic losses estimated at about 9.2 billion yuan. Due to the number of collapsed houses exceeding 10,000, the government had to initiate a national level 4 response, and the figure of 9,999 collapsed houses was questioned as being too coincidental, with possible fabrication. Phoenix News published an article questioning the fact that "9,999 houses were damaged in the Shouguang flood," citing data from the People's Daily client on August 23 stating "10,335 houses collapsed, 8,240 houses severely damaged, and 53,465 houses generally damaged," after which the article was deleted.
